GAME: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
RANK: 58
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Hasn't lived up to the hype or the promise of the design/concept. There was so much potential for amazing experiences, but after more than a dozen games they never seemed to materialize.

Issues include:
-fiddliness
-poorly defined story arc
-too much random swinginess
-some awkward rules/design.
-no suspense in the traitor mechanic.
-the game always breaks down into an optimization exercise. It turns into *unemergent* gameplay.

----
(bought)/ (traded for $60)

Wow, I was generous with this one. No need to play it again to go from 6.1 to 4.8. I really don't get the appeal with this one. I'd play it again under more ideal circumstances but I wouldn't expect the rating to go up much.

RATING: 6
I have come to accept that I really don't like cooperative games that much.

That being said, this is a good one. It may be a bit more complicated than it needs to be, but it has a nice mix of mechanics. 

The crossroads cards can seem to be unneccessary at times, but they really add a nice thematic element. The challenges are not as interesting as they could be, but they definitely add challenge. Balancing characters is important and adds a nice twist.

I enjoyed playing, which is novel for coops. I would play it again.

RATING: 8.5
An interesting semi-cooperative exercise, with unique and highly thematic mechanics, the game sometimes lacks the tension that I find in games like BSG - BSG is always a tight race to the end, with suspicion and misdirection flying until the final reveal, but DoW sometimes tends more towards being a few rounds of loyalty checking, before everyone being more or less harmonious.

The Crossroads cards are excellent, however!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
[I]tl;dr - An overdone theme and no real innovative mechanics make for a warmed-over BSG/Shadows over Camelot sequel. Hard pass from me.[/I]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

Words cannot describe -- I tried Dead of Winter and disliked it a lot. I won't be trying it again -- this isn't my type of game.

First of all, there's no semblance of a struggle to survive in this game. We had to just 'stay alive' for five rounds, but everything we had to do seemed obvious. We weren't over-run by zombies at any point, we fended them off easily, and there was nothing to do except that. Perhaps we tried a bad scenario, but even so, the basic mechanics of the game seemed really...boring.

I dislike zombies in general, and this is a game that would have profited without them. Set this on a desert island, add in some sort of sun beats down mechanic (kind of like Forbidden Desert), and make the zombies wild beasts. You've instantly got a better game just because the survival aspect matches the theme a lot better. The game still would need mechanical tweaks, but the zombie theme was just a huge turnoff overall to me.

The individual personal goals were interesting, but not enough to save it for me, at all. I also found the Crossroads cards (the big draw of the game for many people) not very compelling. It's possible the group I played with had a small role in my dislike for the game, but I think I'd hate this one if I played it with the designer himself. 

I prefer [thing=15062][/thing] for a more successful take on the semi-co-op.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
An excellent, immersive experience. I particularly love the crossroads deck, which gives it a different feel from similar co-op games. Brutally difficult game, but that feels thematically appropriate. The one flaw in it that keeps it from being a '10' is how easy it is for a traitor to win and how impossible it is to block a traitor from sinking the game. Still, it's a permanent part of my collection and definitely one of my frequent go-to games.

RATING: 10
This game is amazing.  The stories you will get from this game will stick with you.  The crossroad cards are a great touch, and the tension that the crises bring is palpable.  Group make up will make or break this game, our group focuses on the main objective while also trying to complete the personal.  The consensus is a shared half win is better that a total loss, not all gamers are like this however.  Easily my favorite of 2014, and in my top 5 of all time.

RATING: 6.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dead of Winter is a survival game with a very compelling twist. Not only might there be a traitor in your midst, but there might not be (which sounds really stupid, but is the difference between a foregone conclusion and suspense). Players are given every reason to be selfish, but they can't be too selfish or everybody loses. It's a fantastic game of motivations and shifty eyes, with a great deal of thematic flavor from the crossroads event deck. Sure, you'll probably hear the same crossroads cards pretty regularly, but you never know when a new one might pop up with a crazy decision that must be made. Dead of Winter is my co-op survival game of choice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Theme is great, awesome blend of teamwork and individual play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
We played a partial 3-player game. I got a good feel for how the game runs, but not how it finishes. It was selling well throughout GenCon and I do expect it sold out. It plays very smooth and is very simple to run - which I appreciate alot. The theme is spectacular indeed. I love the look and feel here - a wintery apocalypse is richly thematic and evokes the tension needed for this type of co-op. I like the idea of possible betrayal in your own ranks - everybody gets a secret objective. The general play is everyone rolls dice and then goes out exploring locations by drawing up cards. Want more selection? Draw more cards - but that risks attracting more zombies. And why draw cards? To complete the crisis happening each round as well as beef up your characters.

The main touted feature here are the crossroads card. Conceptually, these are brilliant. Your neighbor draws one of these cards and if the event listed occurs during your turn, they read to you the results and you pick which happens. But I have a few problems with this. First, of the cards we drew, ALL but one of them pertained to specific characters in the game. Only once was the character in the game - so they didn't get triggered. When one did get triggered, it pertained to one of my characters - and it wasn't my turn. I was *reading* the card. Very strange feeling to have your character's decision determined by another player. It didn't feel thematic - just clumsy somehow. Another one was a set up of a fight in the colony - but we only had a single character there so it made no sense. Second, the consequence of the decision is revealed to the player - which feels very odd in play. I'd rather know the choices, but not the consequences. This all made me feel the crossroad cards were a missed opportunity. 

That plus the rather repetitive play experience (search search search) left me a bit unimpressed. Don't take this for not enjoying the game - because I did and would gladly play again. But I didn't feel the need to buy it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
best new game...or am I the betrayer? 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I have found the genre of theme heavy, co-operative survival games to be one of the most (if not the most) difficult genres to make. Having played a number of them, I have come to a conclusion that most are horrible while only a few are actually good ones. Dead of Winter falls into the category of horrible.
 
My biggest complaint is about the down time. At the very beginning it is still ok, but once new characters start entering the game it all freezes dead. There are just too many moving pieces on the board and all cohesion is lost. To add to the horror of waiting, an event card is drawn at the beginning of every turn. Ok, this a common mechanic but the cards in Dead of Winter have way too much flavour text. When you have patiently waited for your turn for 10 minutes, you do not want to have the game stop for another 1-2 minutes turn.
 
It is a fine balance between keeping the game playable and adding “thematic” stuff that is supposed to help with the immersion. Easily this extra fluff is not meaningful from the mechanical point of view and does not actually add to the dramatic arc either, but only gives you random and unrelated events.
 
I am still waiting for the grail in this category of games, i.e., dripping with theme and stories while everything propels the game and the story forward. As of this writing, Arkham Horror is the closest to a grail so far. At least there the down time is not so much of an issue.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
At long last a zombie game I enjoy. Dead of Winter is designed by The same person who did City of Remnants and is a really nice take on a survival horror theme. It is like Shadows over Camelot and the Walking Dead had a baby. The premise is that you are one of a few factions within a town that exists in a post zombie apocalypse. You spend your time scavenging for resources and trying to meet one of several possible scenario objectives. The trick though is that there is probably at least one traitor in your midst who has a goal to undermine the community. So while most games of this ilk capture the external pressure of zombies well, this one also captures the internal one presented by other humans. Dead of Winter, a zombie game I will play :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

What a zombie apocalypse to have!

RATING: 9.5
Based on a single play. Lots of fun, great mix of coop and personal goals. The crossroads cards bring a level of thematic immersion which works much better than flavor text ever does. Many memorable moments, such as the time sparky ran up to the woman dying in her crashed helicopter and chose to run off with the gasoline rather than save her. 

Ummm. Good dog?

A few plays later... Still great. Love the cross roads cards mechanic. The game is tough, but winning is possible. My only small strike is that the luck can go against you. Just like the lotr lcg (and many other recent games) winning is a combination of good play and the luck of the draw and the dice. Still very fun and very immersive so far. 

Probably my game of the year for 2013

RATING: 8.25
Thematic, fun, tense, and really difficult.  Enough second-guessing during turns to mitigate the downtime between turns, and victories feel epic if they happen (they don't happen often).

More flavor text, more survivors, more secret objectives, more community goals, this is much better for players new to DoW than the expansion, even though the expansion has more stuff and a more forgiving difficulty curve.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Dead of Winter is a very original game and is incredibly unique. As a zombie apocalypse scenario fan, this game actually didn't interest me when I saw it on Amazon. After doing some research of the game, I became excited to try it out and the game *somewhat* met my expectations. First off, the game plays beautifully cooperative, it's a constant struggle of working together to survive a zombie apocalypse. The only issues I had with the game was with the traitor and how many damn pieces are required! We had a game last about 20 minutes and the traitor had already won (maybe need to test more games but the times we had a traitor was incredibly boring). Great game, just wish there was a way to have less pieces (set up takes 30 minutes sometimes!)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Another roll and draw American-style game. I can see why a lot of people may like it, but it's really not my cup of tea. I appreciate that the dice rolling is not as crucial as in other titles, but it still felt underwhelming to me... almost pasted on the game, just to appeal to dice enthusiasts. I don't see why those dice are there.

I wasn't thrilled by the secret goal mechanism either, as it seems to be there just to give opportunities to the traitor. This is made even worse by the fact that the objectives don't scale. In one game I needed to have 12 survivors in the colony and we played in 5, so I started the game with 10! It didn't even have to get to my turn for me to complete it! The same objective would have been a lot tougher in 2 players. This is just lazy game design.

Yet the biggest let down for me was the concept of the Crossroads cards. What's so innovative about them? It's almost exactly the same thing that Arkham Horror does and it's exactly one of the reasons why I don't like that game. I thought that I would have liked it better here, because the player couldn't tell whether the event would trigger or not. Then I discovered that the triggers are so generic, that the events take place almost every time... making the entire thing almost meaningless. You want a sense of story done right? Look at the adventure mechanism in Robinson Crusoe! Now, that's an interesting take on event cards in board games... not this.

So again, maybe it's just not my cup of tea. It's another game that it's just all theme and no mechanics. I really don't understand where is the fun in the whole "draw and see what happens" system. Not as bad as Arkham Horror, but still pretty bad for me. Pass.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love this game. It's great to introduce to friends who are casual board gamers, or are new to playing board games.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very good cooperative game based in a post-apocalyptic universe where you have to fight zombies. It is outstanding because although it is a cooperative game, each player has a secret task and if they do it , they can win the game, also there is a traitor whose job is to hinder the group's performance. What I miss from this game are the plastic miniatures: all the zombies are made of paper, but the other visual aspects are nicely done. I can recommend this game to groups who are into cooperative gaming, but also prefer a level of competition, so the alpha player is not so accentuated.

RATING: 6.5
Uma cópia descarada de BSG, porém uma cópia bem feita e com alguns mecanismos interessantes. O fato dele copiar as principais mecânicas de BSG (enfrentar crise, votação secreta, traidor no grupo) foi algo que me desagradou, mas achei o nível de dificuldade bem condizente com a proposta do jogo (sobreviver ao apocalipse zumbi no meio de uma nevasca). O fato de não ter eliminação de jogadores também foi algo que gostei e a ideia do exilado (uma cópia da cadeia em BSG) é algo interessante porque o jogador ainda participa, mas de uma forma diferente. RATING: 8
VF
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]23.10.2014 - After 4 plays[/b]
[b]BACKGROUND[/b]: For this game, I feel the need to explain my gaming background concerning this type of games (cooperative/zombie). Although many games played a long time ago, the cooperative genre is not a preferred one for me. In fact, I find "OK" only Pandemic (a classic of the genre) and Eldritch / Arkham Horror (mostly due to the theme). The other games I have played are ranked as "meh" - Battlestar Galactica, Shadows over Camelot, Robinson Crusoe and Red November.
Regarding the "zombie genre", the only game that I have played is Last Night on Earth and I thought it was weak.

[b]GAMEPLAY[/b]: Dead of Winter is set in a small colony of survivors/runners from the zombie apocalypse. Every player controls a team of survivors (starting with 2), each having three basic stats and an ability. There is a main objective which needs to be completed, as well as secret objectives for each player. A player must complete also his secret objectives in order to win, with some objectives being "betraying" ones. Furthermore, each turn a Crisis needs to be faced, which can have brutal consequences if failed. But what makes the game shine are the CROSSROADS cards, some random and thematic events that MAY be triggered by the player taking his turn.

[b]ART/COMPONENTS[/b]: The art is gorgeous, almost black & white with some color highlights (especially the bloody red). The components are nice, especially the cardboard "miniatures" of the survivors and zombies. There is just one thing that bothers me: why did they make the non-colony location from thick paper, instead of cardboard as the colony map? 

[b]DIFFICULTY[/b]: If someone listens to the complete rules explanation, she may find the game is very complex (there are over 10 actions a player can take) and with many rules. Despite this, the game is easy to grasp and with someone "watching" over the colony phase, it can go very smoothly. The scarcity of the resources, the constant zombie threat and the need to complete the objective make up for a tight and very "stressful" game.

[b]THOUGHTS[/b]: There two reasons why I like this game and will continue to play
1. It is a SEMI-cooperative (due to the personal objectives), SEMI-ameritrash game (it has dice, but they are rolled just at the beginning of the turn, instead of every time you have an "encounter"). Because of this "semi" nature, it can attract different people, even those that usually don't play these genres (like myself). I think that the "betrayer" element is done excellent in this game, compared to BSG and other games with hidden traitors. 

2. It is VERY thematic. Almost all of the actions can be explained in the context of the story. For example: you need to roll an exposure die (D12) every time you move a survivor or attack a zombie. The results may be: BLANK (nothing out of the ordinary happens) | FROSTBITE wound (you traveled/fought too long in the snow, so some parts of your body got frozen) | WOUND (you tripped/zombie fought back, so you are wounded) | BITTEN (the zombie transformed your survivor, so you lose it. On top of that, if there are more survivors present, each one may get bitten by the "new" zombie).
Also, the Crossroads cards shows you glimpses of the story, with hard choices to be taken.

I didn't like that, near the end of the game, it may become clear if the main objective can be fulfilled or not. If not, then the non-betrayers have just one option - to exile the betrayer so that he doesn't win. This is a little anti-climatic.

According to Plaid Hat Games, this is just the first game of a family of games that uses the Crossroads system. So, I cannot wait to try the others!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Fantastic coop game. Yes, there's a lot of luck needed in the game (especially regarding your secret objective card, which can be either a walk in the park or devastatingly difficult), there can be quite some down time (which I generally hate), but each time you play it's just a blast. The crossroads cards are great, the theming feels right and really helps the mechanics, the strategic options are diverse, the variety in each game is wonderful (various missions, other starting characters, new crossroads...). It's truly a fun game to play.

Theme (artwork/story/...)
2/2
Gameplay (smooth play/player interaction/strategy&tactics/depth)
4/5
Fun factor (can you afford a smile during play?)
3/3

RATING: 5.5
Feelings towards this game are decreasing over time. Part of it is them, for sure, but I start to feel pulled down by a game this capricious as well.

RATING: 6
In many ways, Dead of Winter almost soars as a co-op. The art is great, the tension is tight, and it has a lot of neat thematic touches. But then there's secret goals, which I find incredibly boring / annoying. It's an added layer of plain annoying luck muddying the waters of a more pure co-op experience. And the traitors are harsh. The game is already hard. Plus, as thematic as the game is, I really do hate zombie anything. I have no love at all for the 1 in 12 chance characters have to die for moving without gas or, God forbid, killing zombies.

RATING: 6
September 10th 2014: Dead of Winter, newly acquired. 

Rated: 8.5.

November 24th 2014: Sold Dead of Winter. 

Updated Rating: 6

Let me be clear, Dead of Winter is an enjoyable game. It just didn't work for me and my group. I say this with a touch of lament, but after a few games, it just never seemed to sing like I had hoped. 

Detractions: 

1) I found the game a touch messy. Cards are constantly being discarded to the box, while other cards are getting attached to survivors, nothing exists in the game to track 'once a round' use items, yet turning cards sideways does little to minimize the clutter (and cards will invariably get there on their own after equipping several to a sole survivor). Cards from one deck will get shuffled into another if a survivor with equipped items dies outside of the colony, and decks discards find themselves being tossed haphazardly. 

2) Vestigial design elements detracted from the teaching experience. Minor complaint, but stuff like the Group Leader having little communicable purpose in the design left the impression of a haphazard design. Influence also has minimal use, save creating a hierarchy for overrun and bite calculations. Rumor has it some of these elements will be expanded upon in the upcoming (though officially unannounced) expansion, but I'll ultimately have to judge the finished product before a repurchase. 

3) Lots of downtime. I tend to stay engaged in games when it isn't my turn, but for whatever reason the sheer number of actions available to the players in Dead of Winter tended to cause my attention to fog over by mid-game (when with two). I prefer threading player actions, but I'll be the first to admit this would hurt the betrayer (if one is present). 

4) I hated playing the Crossroad cards police. Lovely element to the game, at least at the low play count I've had (probably 6~ sessions). I can imagine they might get repetitious after a while, but they stayed a joy in my experience. What wasn't a joy, however, was having to constantly remind people to draw them. 

5) Semi cooperative games just aren't my thing. I've never played Archipelago, but I imagine the overt competitive subtext to the game would work better for my group. Dead of Winter matches the source material brilliantly, but not everybody I brought to the table was versed in the "everybody is an untrustable jerk" mentality depicted in media like The Walking Dead. Betrayer mechanics also strike me as a touch gimmicky, and often encourage sessions to devolve into jokey stabs and accusations, as if players feel the need to play up these mechanics to validate their inclusion. Sure, after several games, the novelty will wear off and people will just sit down and play the game, but I find it tedious. 

So, yes. A litany of complaints, yet I still rate it relatively highly. Something about it just got into my heart. 

I may repurchase the game if my group begins meeting more frequently and a quality expansion hits. As it stands, I'd rather be playing Keyflower.     
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Some good ideas here, and I love the different scenarios, but ultimately you are searching through decks of cards the entire game and hoping you don't hit that 1/12 chance of instadeath. The individual goals are kind of a way to prevent this, but don't really work well enough in practice.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
First impressions was that of a flawless game; the game immediately loses its appeal when crucial imbalances appear, specifically within the traitor mechanic. The game sorely needs house rules because so much of the game relies on the secret objectives.

The traitor would work better if there was a ramp up of sabotage ability - maybe the first allowed sabotage action is a spiking of the crisis, followed by the ability to eat excess food tokens.

I wish there were inquisition actions where you waste action dice to secure things - food cannot be eaten for dice values, crisis cards have to go through your hand, attacks cannot be made with exposure except at the threat of an overrun. Something like that would be fitting to the theme where tyranny emerges out of the distrust.

Anyway, it's a good game that with a few minor tweaks could be a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like it BUT
I don't think anyone should face the game as they would face most games.
First the group should talk about the metagame. For us, making everyone lose just because we can't win is just stupid. We accept taking the risk trying to get our personal goals even if that could make everyone lose. But that's it. Sometimes our personal goals won't be achievable, so we end up playing without being able to win. We take it as a "well, we kinda won even if I don't".

I accept the game and its flaws because I think about the game as a experience, and not as a fair competition. I understand not everyone will think this way, and if this sound as a problem to you, you maybe end up disliking this game.

Also, is pretty random. The exposure dice can kill someone in just one roll. The resources are limited and some people could be more greedy than others in crisis/objetives and they'll probably achieve victory while other more cooperative players don't.

That said, this game definitely has decisions. When I can be greedy. When I should cooperate. Where I will go, depending of what I need, or what the group need.

For me the game is great even without a traitor, although I think being the traitor makes the game more easy than it should be in some games.

The standalone expansion sound even more unfair and more difficult, but it sounds so awesome in paper. I hope to be able to play it soon, but it looks that there are less location-specialiced characters (good, because they kinda force you to go there and keep them digging there) and the modules look awesome. I don't think having less characters would get stale faster because getting the same characters for me it's more special than boring. You remember other games and can have a few favorite ones. Also, even if it gets stale for you, you can always add one of the modules to mix things up.

So yeah, without having played the expansion I only can recommend the base game, but it looks like one could skip this game and buy the standalone expansion The Long Night and having a really similar game, but with more things to add when you get bored of it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A zombie game that borrows from Battlestar Galactica (a crisis each turn, players all getting the chance to put in cards, the possibility at least of a traitor).  Dead of Winter also throws in some darkly humorous events and - in case hoards of zombies are not enough - a touch of frost bite. Add personal objectives intended to make this a less cooperative game and you have a very tricky balancing act in terms of victory conditions; one that I don't think always succeeds.

One more thing that the designer should have taken from BSG is short player turns.  You will want to play this with a full complement five players, but you really shouldn't because the downtime will be terrible. What's more, there isn't quite enough for the characters to do, beyond searching for items, killing zombies and averting a crisis.  

For my taste the characters cycle all too quickly. I want mine to stick around long enough to build a story, I want to get into role.  That doesn't really happen when you know that any one of them will likely soon be dead.

Production quality is pretty good.  The artwork is distinctive and chillily thematic.

RATING: 2
Tried playing several games of this with people who owned it. I found it beyond aggravating and completely unfun. Rolling a d12 repeatedly to see if you're dying is an odd mechanic. RATING: 8.5
Juego semi-cooperativo. Toda la colonia refugiada por los zombies intentan un objetivo general, mientras cada uno esconde un objetivo secreto individual.

Un gran juego temático. El fin de un juego temático es dar inmersión en el juego, con personalización, trasfondo y narración. Este juego lo logra muy bien, todo el tiempo se siente la tensión de estar en una mala posición, de no poder cumplir los objetivos o sobrevivir. Es un juego denso y emocionante, sobre todo en las últimas decisiones.

Es un juego que puede asustar a la gente no jugona, porque en el turno suceden muchas cosas, pero una vez jugando es muy intuitivo.

RATING: 7.5
This one is a conundrum. For gaming it is typically only my wife and I. So having any game with a traitor element in it is a bit dodgy. We picked this up after seeing all the hype and after playing a three player game with a friend. We had watched a play through online with someone playing it as purely co-op. Regardless of whether it not it stays in our collection we are still keeping the "Lucky Luke" and"Felicia Day" promos.

RATING: 10
Excellent semi-cooperative game in which players have to balance the needs of the colony with their own secret objective. These questionable intentions lead to added tension between players, who never know who to trust with a potential traitor among the group. The Crossroads cards add so many tension on each turn, and the stories really pull you into this world. 

Great theme that is incorporated well into gameplay. Adjustable difficulty level. No alpha player problem because everyone has to look out for themselves in order to win.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Played twice, keen to play again, as a social experience this is hard to beat.
There are lots of neat mechanics going on here. I particularly like the fact the once you play a card it's not simply discarded from the game, it goes into a trash pile which literally becomes a pile of trash in your colony which you must clean up or suffer adverse moral consequences. The mechanism by which a traitor, if there is one, can sabotage the colony's attempt to fight a crisis is simple and effective. The dilemmas that the game forces on you are fascinating (you're running short of food so do you bump off a couple of helpless colonists who are useless extra mouths to feed)?
Essentially this is a game of fire-fighting: should your priority be to fight-off zombies? Get more food or fuel? Clear that trash? Other important questions are: is there a traitor? If so who? Probably my favourite mechanic is the fact that each player has a secret objective which can make someone appear like a traitor when they are merely chasing their own goal.
This isn't a game of strategy and isn't meant to be, it's a game of survival, of beating each new crisis, and it succeeds gorgeously in capturing the desperation and paranoia of such a struggle.
Not much downtime because even when it's not your turn you're watching other players to see if they pull their weight and contribute to the general good.
Potential misgivings: the individual secret goals don't seem balanced - eg one is to end the game with three medicine cards, another with just two.
Secondly, the presence or otherwise of a traitor must hugely effect the outcome and I can't help wondering if the game will prove either too easy to win without one or too hard with one, but I haven't played enough to judge.
Third, luck. In my first game, one of my two colonists died on his very first move thanks to an unlucky roll.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
41$
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Impressions after first play:

First of all we had fun and I would absolutely want to play again.

Crossroads Cards:
I had read a number of complaints that these cards almost never came up and were therefore under utilized.  I imagine that this will change somewhat from game to game but in our game we had what I would consider a perfect amount of crossroads come up.  Enough to keep the game flavourful but not so much that it lost its punch.

Traitor:
We had no traitor in the game, and the set-up seems to make a traitor appearance fairly unlikely. (2 non-trator cards to each player and then 1 traitor card).  It seemed to be obvious fairly early that no one would was the betrayer so there wasn't much tension there.

Secret Agendas:
these would have been more fun if there was ever a thought that someone might betray but they were still a neat mechanic.  I didn't really notice it on other characters but there was certainly  one time at least where people pointed out that the better move for the team was for me to stay in one particular spot but I moved elsewhere anyway based on my own objective.  Maybe the group was too trusting but it wasn't enough for people to accuse me of being a bad guy.  We all lost at the end being unable to fulfil the main objective but 3 of us had no hope of winning anyway :)

Dice:
I was concerned about the exposure dice making the game too swingy (and I think it still could) but we had a very nice distribution of results in our game so it didn't really come up.)

Downtime:
With 5 new players downtime was a factor and made the game drag here and there.I assume it would be less of an issue on subsequent plays but I think it's always going to be a strike against with a full compliment of players.  We played a "short" scenario and the overall game length wasn't too bad at around 2.5 to 3 hours.

Decisions:
I'm not sure there is room for a ton of interesting decisions - but as this is more a thematic experience maybe that's not a huge issue. I wouldn't say it's totally devoid of choices but it wasn't chock full of them either.  I mostly camped out at 2 diff locations and searched when I could, killed when I needed to, and leftover dice sorta just went to trash/barricades.  The lack of traitor tension probably brought this aspect down a notch as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I usually avoid rating this style of game because I don't like them and I don't think it is fair to pass judgment.  Kind of like any dish with eggplant.  On the flip side, I continually try to find a game in this genre and am determined to keep playing them until I find the one that works for me.  Part of me feels like I have to b/c so many in my regular gaming group enjoy this style of game.  Part of me really enjoys a strong narrative in a game and you'd think this genre would fit the bill.  The problem is that there is almost never any tension in these games that isn't related to the randomness of a die roll or card pull.  As such, then tension doesn't really build - it just happens,,,and I'm not really even sure if it's tension at that point . . . 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Very good game idea. Game play is simple, your objective depends on the cenario objective, and your personal objective. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
1- Turn order moves clockwise, First player marker moves counterclockwise.
2- How zombies Overrun an entrance (we mistakingly removed them all, not just the overruning Zombie
3- Each Survivor may only move once per turn.
4- You do NOT have to play Event cards (i.e. add 1,2,3 survivors) as you draw them, you may keep them and play them like a any other card.
5- You may eat Food Tokens from the colony to enhance an unused action die you've rolled.
6- You may attack survivors belonging to other players.

Karten beim Suchen kommen immer zuerst auf die Hand und können bei belieben gespielt werden und auch an andere Spieler weitergegeben. Diese müssen die karte aber sofort ausspielen.

RATING: 7
Dead of Winter is, let's not hide behind a finger, Walking Dead - the boardgame.
It is a cooperative psychological and narrative zombie game, with secret objectives driving tension between players.

Gameplay is quite simple, and it is definitely playable by non gamers. It will excel when role played.

I quite enjoyed my first outing, more than expected: tension and pathos were palpable.
Hopefully other scenarios are varied and tense enough.

RATING: 7
Initial Impression: I'm not a fan of the cardboard standees or card quality but the artwork on the components of this game convey the dark, cold theme very well. As I don't particularly enjoy cooperative games I appreciate the hidden objectives and betrayer mechanisms in this game. The designers have liberally borrowed from FFG's BSG and streamlined the crisis mechanism into something that doesn't feel quite as repetitive. I'd like to play some more sessions to explore the different objectives, main objectives, and see if the situations create more tension.

RATING: 8
A fun, social affair with a cool traitor aspect.  Can create some tense moments and the crossroads story cards really bring out the thematic aspect of this game.  When this game is going well, it is a lot of fun.

The problem is that it is somewhat inconsistent.  Sometimes personal obectives incentivize people to derail the game for the other players, even if all involved players are non traitors.  Sometimes a player can gather a bunch of colony members, which means that their turn is 3 times longer than everyone elses.  Also, the game can be a bit easy when there isn't a traitor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I received this as an early Christmas present. I have played through about 8 games, in the 2 player variant with my daughter and another 2 with my girlfriend yesterday. 

The scenarios are tough, and we are not even playing on Hardcore mode. That may become a little easier with more players, as you have more people collecting resources and whatnot. The zombies still add tend to add up quickly, and the crisis/crossroads cards really add an extra twist in the road to your objective. It's been a blast so far. It's pretty nonstop and also pretty unforgiving. A bad situation can quickly snowball and drop your morale to 0 in an instant. The rule book has been a touch hazy on one or two things, but the internet has been a good resource there.

The two player mode, is a lot of fun, but I am very excited to get more people together and start playing with secret objectives and betrayals. All in all, this game is everything I hoped it would be so far. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.25

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Okay this game COULD have been great and given an alternative theme to the social interaction genre games.  Unfortunately the rules are written poorly for this genre.  

Playing as the traitor is WAY to easy to win the game and you can basically tank the game in one turn if you don't feel like you're going to win.  Both of which should never be the case in games like this.

The combat die is far to random and having a chance on the die of just out right dying is ludicrous.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A semi co-op game that has quickly become a favorite.  It's a game that has a compelling story line that just sucks you in (even if you're not a fan of zombies).  I love the balance of helping the group out in completing the main objective while also making sure your own objective is satisfied.  And, of course, I can't get enough of those Crossroads cards; you never know when one of those things will give you the boost you need to win the game or give you a tough decision to make that will hurt your game either way.  It's a different game every time you play, even if you play the same mission.

My two slight knocks against the game are that, even though the game comes with 80 Crossroads cards, you will go through anywhere between 10-25 each game, so you'll start repeating fairly quickly (they all don't trigger each game, though, so this is just a minor quibble), and the overall complexity is probably too much for casual players.  It's a really hard game to win, especially with so many things to balance as well as intricacies of the rules.  However, I have to give the designers credit for making the rules very intuitive and easy to follow (and for making excellent reference sheets!).  This being said, we've found it best to play a co-op game with new players before introducing the secret objectives so that they can see how everything works.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A very narrative and interesting experience.  People who only want to "win" need not apply, because you may still have to play the game out even after you can't win anymore.

RATING: 7
Dead of Winter is a solid game, and I find that the theme is usually enough to draw people in because of its similarity to the ever-popular Walking Dead. I have used it on several occasions as a game to introduce new(ish) players to gaming with great success. That being said, I am only willing to give it a 7 because, after 14 plays, it's starting to feel a little stale for me. Although the crossroad and scenario cards give the game a fair amount of variety and replayability, the variety is only superficial; all of the scenarios revolve around either killing lots of zombies or gathering lots of supplies. But I've never had a BAD time playing it, so I would be able to recommend it in good conscience.

RATING: 7.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For the betrayer, the game is a 10. There is this tension that boils below the surface, just waiting for the perfect moment to explode into brilliant backstabery. Then everything falls into place perfectly, and you screw everyone!

For the non betrayer, you spend 1.5 hours working towards a goal, with the paranoia that someone is working against you, just to have them destroy you on the last turn. While they revel in their brilliance, you look at the board and think, "well, that's 1.5 hours I'll never get back"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not as good as Eldritch Horror. Both in theme as in mechanics. Yet another Zombie fest which is not really suited for pure co op play in my view.

The zombie story lacks an overall compelling adventure telling. With games like EH you can produce very diverse stories which can go further than just counting up bodies of zombies.

The game I played was fun and tense to the last die roll but I think if the theme changed a bit the game could have been better. 

By this lack of a varied theme, I also think the solo play is not compelling in the long run.

I think the best possible Zombie play is something like Run, Fight or Die. No movement of your heroes, just roll combo dice and a competitive game of who dies first (game end) and who wins with a simple seperate solo option.

RATING: 8
I don't really care for the zombie theme but this is a very thematic game of survival in an apocalypse setting with immersive story telling. This game can be quite unforgiving, difficult to win even without a traitor (which may or may not be present). I enjoy playing it fully cooperative even. Crossroad cards are very well-done and especially fun if triggered. For all the quality components in the box, I wish the location mats come in thicker cardboard instead. A great game to pull out once in a blue moon.

RATING: 9
One of my best purchases in 2015. People often ask, how would I describe this game. I always say to imagine if Battlestar Galactica and Pandemic had a child, and add a zombie apocalypse theme to it. That's DoW. I love almost every aspect of it. ALTHO, the crossroad cards could be bit trimmed down text-wise. The game is quite fast paced imo and some of the XR cards slow it a lot sometimes. You draw one and there's literally a wall of text there. Don't get me wrong, I like story telling in board games but they are a bit too long. Especially when you are "lucky" and get an XR card 3-4 times in a row. It feels like the game stops for a bit. "OK, now we read". Other than that, I LOVE IT.

RATING: 5.5
I had high hopes for this game but it hasn't lived up to expectations for me. Between the location equipment decks, crisis cards, Crossroads card, and the D12 rolls that could insta-kill you, there is just waaaay too much randomness for a game of this length. You need some randomness in a semi-coop game no doubt but overall it just feels like winning and losing is tied too much to all that randomness. Also, the traitor can win pretty easily without even having to work too hard at it. Good artwork and theme but the mechanics are just too broken to make this game worth bringing to the table that often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
DoW is a good game for sure, but worth game of the year consideration? I was really surprised by how easy it was to pick up, and how easily my decisions were to make. I thought it would have more of an "umph!" factor, but it fell somewhat flat for me. Move to this location, search, take care of the colony, take care of myself... A lot of hype surrounds the Crossroads cards, but I don't see them as much of an innovation as they are being made out to be. However, maybe the best representation of a semi-cooperative game to date. Kudos for that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Holy Moly. One of the most THEMATIC games I have ever played. You live the struggle of a colony of survivors during the zombie apocalypse. You want your group to progress, but you must also worry about keeping everyone fed, about the hordes of the undead banging at your walls, about the group of raiders threatening to steal your stuff! The threat of death is ever present, and the undead slowly fade to the background as you begin to distrust your fellow survivors. Fear, suspicion, and ulterior motives. This game takes the psychological zombie thriller and converts it flawlessly into a board game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A meta-cooperative psychological survival game where players lead a faction of survivors in a test of the group's ability to work together and stay alive while facing crises and challenges from both outside and inside the colony.  Players are working together toward one common victory condition--but for each individual player to achieve victory, they must also complete their personal secret objective.  The secret objective helps create the tension and suspense that makes the emergent story all the better.

:chalice: Best New to Me Game of 2014

{win:loss::3:5}

RATING: N/A
Claudia
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Average. Take it or leave it. 

Reasons for Selling
1. The game really requires group discussion on everyones turn, so that you aways feel included. Else given that a player can do a number of actions on their turn, it can be a long wait till your next turn. However, all that discussion each turn means that this can be a long game if everyone is not fully engaged.

2.I get that this game is all about theme but the scenario text on the Crossroads is too long and also extends the game length. I'd of preferred a sentence rather than a paragraph on the cards - to help the game play quicker. Also once you eventually get to the 2 choices - they are not even that interesting.

3. Outcomes too reliant on the exposure dice roll. 

4. Hate it when games state that they play with 2 - this game does not play well with 2. You really need 3-5.

Crisis
- in a 2P game the crisis cards are too simple and repetitive. Simply contribute two of the required items to the crisis. Crisis is different in 4P game due to face down and shuffle being relevant.

Secret Objectives
- I feel that these are such a fundamental part of the game that not having them means that game is just not enjoyable to play with 2P

Crossroads
- often the condition under which a crossroads card should trigger doesn’t happen in 2P. Not enough characters in play doing relevant actions.

RATING: 5
I have such a strange relationship with this game. 

I've never really enjoyed playing it with others. It's a lot of bookkeeping, the mechanics the game is centered around aren't that interesting (yay, searching decks for that one card you hope for is so much fun...), and so many crossroad cards are so hard to actually have trigger that I'll only actually see 10% of the ones we draw per game. The whole betrayer aspect didn't seem quite what I expected either, I just didn't experience it as this ever-present threat

But I enjoy this a lot more while playing by myself, controlling multiple groups of survivors. I feel like I'm much more able to sit back and let the game tell it's narrative this way without dealing with those that are trying to min-max things.

I preordered The Long Night months ago, but I'm honestly considering cancelling it. I watched an early play through and it just looks like more of the same.

RATING: 8
I can’t see how a zombie-themed cooperative game can still be considered innovative: nonetheless, as a matter of fact Dead of Winter is a very good game of its own.

The secret objectives - as well as the possibility of having a betrayer in the group - help make it less of your usual cooperative and more of a competitive game, where everyone shares a common objective (that is, survival to some extent) but sees to his own interests first.

Kind of like the real life.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Initial Impressions:
----------------------
WAY overrated.  The Crossroad cards were interesting, but in thinking about it, they really are not that different than what's in Robinson Crusoe (other than a different player reads the card?). Also, I thought the secret objectives were eh.  Most of them seemed to be related to hoarding some type of resource. I think if i wanted this xp in a coop, I would rather just play Robinson.  If I wanted the traitor element, I would rather just play BSG. Didn't hate the game, and I would play it again, but as much hype as this game was getting I expected way more...

Update 1(3/13/15):
---------------------
After playing a more interesting scenario (other than the first one) with 4 players, I found the game to be much more enjoyable.  While I still don't think its as interesting as many of the review will lead you to believe, I actually do think I like this one better than BSG (Ignore my comments above).  It is more stream lined than BSG, and also takes half the time (plus it has the cross road cards with give some thematic flavor)

Nice thematic game...looking forward to playing it several more times at least.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Bought at Euroquest 2015 auction 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One play with four players. For what it is, it's a fun game. The theme is really strong here. If you like zombies and co-ops and don't mind if a game takes a good bit of time to play, this is a great choice. Also if you like games with a touch a story for flavour, it's very good, just keep your expectations within check -- it's not a story-driven game.

The Crossroads deck is fine but it's just event cards with a minor twist -- not the revolutionary new mechanism that some people seem to be claiming. More clever are the secret personal victory conditions that mean there will often be a push-and-pull when it comes to discussing what to do and how to do it. Games that play around with the black-and-white win-or-lose victory conditions have a special place in my heart. Excellent idea and for the most part a good implementation. Except for one aspect.

My main problem, mechanistically, is the secret personal victory condition of "betrayer". I don't dislike hidden traitor games, and have enjoyed SOC and BSG in the past. But in that type of game, typically the traitor is limited in how much damage they can do at once, so they have to act over time, which means they have to be more subtle so they can get away with sabotage for longer. In this game, the traitor can do a colossal amount of damage in a single turn, meaning they don't even have to try to hurt other players much before the end of the game, which means that there is nothing to go on to allow you to suspect anyone. It becomes a game of complete co-op for 98% of the game, then you find out in the final turn if it was all worth the hours of effort because the presence of a traitor will seemingly almost ensure a loss.

This is a really big problem that turns me off from playing it again. I'd prefer it as a pure co-op, but apparently the pure co-op doesn't have the hidden objectives. I think this is a really great innovation, I would definitely prefer keeping those. And I see then *why* you have to have the possibility of a traitor, so people working slightly against the group to achieve their hidden objective will be placed under suspicion. I get it.

My only problem, truly, is the the traitor is simply too powerful. Nerf that and I'd be pretty happy with this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like the idea of this with its possible hidden betrayer and people with secret objectives and the possibility of actions being triggered by what you do on your turn through crossroads cards. But, with all these things, it doesn't always work - cards can sometimes rarely (or never) be triggered. And people don't always efficiently pursue their goals. More plays may help this.

RATING: 9

Random event cards provide a really nice spice to gameplay

RATING: 7
Reasons to avoid -- the game doubles in length with 5p compared to 3p.  Also, it can be complicated to decide which variants to use and how to resolve certain rules (i.e., Johnnie will be bored).  The game is supposedly best when played with betrayer variant & player elimination variant (b/c otherwise there's only a 45% chance of a betrayer meaning frequent fully co-op games and the rules if player loses all of his characters aren't so great).

RATING: 9
This is a really special game. It's not just that this game is in the discussion for the best traitor game available in an already strong field of competitors. It's not just that it balances key elements in the game which give rise to some terrific emergent, social play. The game is something special in the tone that it creates - a feeling that playing the game is doing something serious. I love the fact that the rule system has created warring cultures fighting about the "proper" (even "ethical!") way to play the game, provoking some interesting meta-game discussion. I love this about it - not to mention it's fun. I have yet to see whether it can equal Battlestar but I look forward to exploring further.

RATING: 8
The buzz was loud!

And for a reason... the game is very good indeed! 

A lot have been said about this one, so I'll not be long.

I'd say that DoW is the most accurate The Walking Dead rip off translated to a boardgame. Are the walkers the biggest danger in the game? Not! Not even close! The humans are! The selfish nature of human beings will create a sense of paranoia since the begining of the game. Is there a traitor out there? Maybe not... or is it? Why would the other player do such actions? Is he protecting him to achieve his goals or is he trying to screw all of our plans? You'll never know... or will you?

That's the game! The dense interation that is created by personal goals! The drama created by the Crossroad Cards only makes it more enjoyable!

One of the best co-op games ever! Co-op? Hmmm let me think about it!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Another coop/semi-coop game set during the zombie apocalypse. Same(ish) as most of the genre with a bit of a twist in the things that might happen during each player's turn (the "crossroads" cards). One of you might be the "betrayer" (also common for the genre) as one of the players might secretly be trying to sabotage the team and thus win instead of them. Each player also has a "personal" objective on top of the group objective. So, unless you are the betrayer who wins if the group fails, in the case of a team win, you can still "lose" if you fail to meet your individual object. All these ideas sound better than they appear to play out based on only a small number of plays so far.

Has a way to go to out-do Battlestar Galactica, but I'm willing to see if I've missed something...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
BSG this isn't. The crisis is done after everyone's turn, and you pretty much twiddle your thumbs when everyone else has their turn. Characters are disposable, so I struggle with who I'm represented in the game ... But as each character has a special ability and stuff they are good at and stuff they're not, the decisions are fairly trivial when it is your turn.

Overall, much much rather play BSG for a traitor/coop game.

RATING: 5
The appeal of this game isn't in its depth or amazing layout or components. I can see this as a roleplayers dream! The best thing from this game is the player interaction. All the crisis feel the same and the only thing that feels "gamish" is trying to decide if there is a betrayer or not.

Even though there are a few different objectives to play through, it all feels the same. If you are playing a "short" game or a "long" game.....it doesn't really matter cause your doing the same thing from game to game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I'm growing to despise this game, and I may begin to turn it down because my lack of enthusiasm is rubbing off on people and ruining the game for others.

The crossroad cards are just awful.  If you read both results before choosing, they're inconsequential and gamey, and if you don't read the results, they're wildly unbalanced.  Players can also horde survivors, which hordes actions, creating significant downtime where players spend so much time doing nothing.

It's a less tense, less fun, less thoughtful version of Battlestar Galactica (which it ostensibly replaces) with tons of exploitable holes in the ruleset.  I've tried so many times to get the appeal and I just can't...

What a spectacular game.   Dripping theme, and a lot a events and strategy to boot.   I will start off with say this, move on from the recommended starting scenario "need more samples".   It is very boring compared to the other scenarios.

RATING: 8
Semi-coop game where you're trying to accomplish a shared goal but also your own secret goals.  And it's that push and pull between contributing and being selfish that makes the interesting.  There's also the possibility for a betrayer and I like the betrayer variant which increases the likelihood of having one.  The crossroads cards give the game a good sense of story.  The theme is great and fits well with the mechanics- it does feel like you're a group of survivors in the zombie apocalypse like in Dawn of the Dead or The Walking Dead.  And strangely, although there's so many zombie games, very few seem to capture this sort of struggle for survival.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Quite easily one of the best board games I have ever played.  Here is a list of all the things you have to keep in mind on your turn:  Does the colony have enough food?  Is there too much waste in the waste pile?  Are we going to solve the crisis for this round?  How close are we to completing the main objective?  How close am I to completing my secret objective?  Is there a betrayer among us?  If so, who could it be and should we cast a vote to expose them?  Maybe I'm the betrayer, so how do I stay incognito until the right moment comes to make my move? What kind of curve ball will get thrown at us if a crossroads card is triggered this turn?  So much awesome tension from turn to turn.  The game is played with 2 to 5 players.  The more players, the better the game.

RATING: 8
Pros:
1.) Good elements of teamwork and betrayal
2.) Multiple problem solving mechanics keeps the tension very high throughout the entire game.
3.) Great artwork.

Cons:
1.) Setup time (too many decks of cards to shuffle).
2.) Zombies are not too much of a threat.  
3.) Co-op only mode will become stale after a few plays.
4.) No models.  The game only comes with cardboard standies.  I replaced the Zombie standies with models from other games.
5.) Poor storage solution.

Conclusion:
Very good game, highly recommended

RATING: 8
Very fun co-op game with a possible 'traitor' mechanic. Great theme, some luck although minimal, great quality components. We played 5-player and had a traitor in our group; on reflection with the victory conditions we had it seems like it would be very easy for the traitor to sabotage the entire group, if not win themselves.

Edit June 2015: Have played multiple times. One of the best co-ops, if not the best, I've played. I even don't mind the complete randomness of the Exposure dice, it does just spice things up and you feel like you have a 'story' to tell after your game is done. Fantastic game.

Edit May 2017: Knocking down to an 8. I don't have nearly the desire to play this as I used to: in part perhaps because the expansion was so underwhelming. Would still happily play, but I'm not "itching" to play any time like I am with any game rated a 9 or higher.

RATING: 8.5
This one is slipping for me, but only because of the length. It makes it hard to get this to the table with five (though I have had excellent five player games). I would still consider it one of my favorite games for the stories and the feeling of success and failure that it conjures. My main group tends to not love co-op or semi-co-op games, or if we're in the mood they'd rather throw down Battlestar Galactica. I still prefer dead of winter for the agency you have on your turns. I love the storytelling side of it, and I consider it a bit of a Next Step game where if I have casual gamer friends looking for a dramatic, tense and longer evening, I can throw this down. However, with five and mostly non-gamers, I've had at least one terrible, slow, drawn out experience. A great story in a box, an excellent deep challenge for a group of friends, but definitely depends on your group being willing take it seriously and to dive in for 2.5 to 3+ hours, and that's with someone cracking the whip. Try it with four if anyone's new.

RATING: 8
-sold-

I had huge expectations before playing this particular game and I wasn't disappointed at all.
In the past I've often thought about getting Shadows over Camelot or Battlestar Galactica because of the traitor mechanism. The idea of a Semi-Co-Op is really appealing to me and with Dead of Winter I have finally gotten my game.

I really like that game a lot. You don't know wether there is a traitor or not and everybody is accusing everybody else. You can never be sure if just the world is beating you down or if there is really someone who tries to sabotage...

And the crossroads cards are also a really cool thing that push the story forward. But I'd rather play it that way that you don't read the consequences of the card so you can't think what might be worse. You want to see what that decision brings? Choose it and you will see.

I'm really confident that this will be one of my favourites very soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great thematic game. Basically, it's a streamlined, simplified, story-driven version of Battlestar Galactica. Crises are resolved with cards contributed anonymously by players, traitors can sabotage the crisis by adding bad cards, and then the suspicion begins...

The crossroads cards are awesome, and contribute greatly to the game's flavor and fun. The secondary objectives also add lots of suspicion among the players. I do wish this game had something similar to BSG's destiny deck, which added some uncertainty as to the presence of a traitor. On the other hand, in DoW it's so undesirable to be discovered as the betrayer that it is in players' best interests to prevent their discovery as long as possible. Overall, a fun game that my friends who hate zombie games will gladly play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 9
This game has alot going for it. There is quite alot of complexity there, for those amongst us who like thinking situations though. But its still, in essence not that difficult a game to learn (and to enjoy as a first time player). There is a ton of replay value, with alot of characters to discover, situations to overcome and just alot of depth to keep you coming back for more and more (i introduced some friends to this game and we acutally played it 3 times in a row because they loved it so much)

What is this game about? Survive! Against hunger, against zombies and sometimes even against other players (because there is always a possibility that one (or more) person draws a traitor card). Manage your survivors, hunger, clean up your garbage, scavange for the needed supplies in the many locations included in this box.

Why you should not buy this game? If you don't like the whole zombie apocalypse theme (if you cant immerse yourself in the theme then you will not enjoy it as much, obviously).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Co-operative or semi-cooperative game.  You're a colony of survivors with a possible traitor among you.  You must explore for goods and take out zombies while also trying to simply survive and achieve a personal and overall objective before the last round (or before morale bottoms out).

Survivor cards are assigned randomly and a lot of them are pretty cool.  Personal favorite is Sparky when he gets a bunch of weapons.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good cooperative game despite the zombie that didn't really appeal to me. Players must survive a zombie outbreak by gathering supplies ta various locations and make sure to feed the survivors and foil the zombie attacks. I'm usually not keen on co-ops but the replayability of this one is very impressive the multitude of characters, the different scenarios, and the crossroad cards that insure that that each game will feel different than the one previous one. I also love that the scenarios have different lengths so you can make the game last as short or long as you want. I also like the include of the possible traitor which keeps the tensions alive throughout the game. The dice rolls and card draws are a bit too luck-dependent for my taste and the game would probably become repetitive if played too often but it's still a game I'm happy to play every now and then.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
2-5 players (best 4)
Cooperative; Traitor
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dead of winter is an amazing zombie survival game, where secrecy and strategy play a massive part. Although the board and rule book can be daunting to look at/read; the game is actually quite intuitive after the first play through. The steps of each turn are clearly laid out on player cards that each player receives when playing the game.

Each player has a goal that they must complete along with the main objective and crisis cards, making every game different. You can play a few ways (definite traitor, possible traitor and no traitor) and each way is fun in it's own way.

The set up and pack down of the game can be a little clumbersome and take a while, but is worth it and is made slightly easier by zip-lock bags that come with the game. 

New players can sometimes be daunted by the rules, so what I do when teaching this game is to lay out the basic rules (How to move, Use an action, Exposure dice and searching) and then say that the easiest way to learn the game is to play it. After a few turns, everything makes sense and everyone is playing with ease.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Only played solo so far, to get the feel of the game before teaching it to others. It's refreshing that zombies are so easy to kill.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Traded in Origins Math Trade 2017
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm surprised at how well this game works. I was surprised to see a game of this type actually carry a narrative fairly well (and by narrative, I'm talking about the interactions between characters and the decisions they take that form a story, not a series of chained events that barely make any sense like you find in most story board games (EH, AH, FanG, TotAN...).

I was shocked to see that the only die rolled for resolution was the die of death and that most die rolls are done to create the decision space where you choose your actions for the round. I expected dice for resolution all around based on the other games from this company.

I am in love with this game creating a game where the number of winners can range from 0 to everyone, depending on personal goals and the group goal (the tension between those two is what really drives the narrative). Also, for those who think this is a coöp, wait until someone proposes exiling you, not because they think you're a betrayer, but simply to make it easier for the rest of them to win.

I am super glad they went with standups because this many minis would have resulted in the same thing as in Flying Frog Games games where you have trouble figuring out who's who (you can easily have 18 different characters on the board at once in a four player game, imagine trying to tell them apart as two or three cm high unpainted minis with typical levels of detail for a board game).

The game's biggest flaws are, for me, it's complicated rules, and the fact that I wonder, if I want to create a story at the table with my friends, why not simply play a story game?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

A great combination of player interaction and resource management with secret agendas.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Sold-sleeved with Daedelus Bloody Insert
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very tentative review based on 1 play with 3 players:

I really did not get a good feel for this game based on the introductory scenario. Perhaps our mental approach to the game was wrong, but the objective was easy enough and it was obvious that there was no traitor that we could all just work together and accomplish our goals, so the game's entire shtick didn't really come into play.

On paper, this seems like a cool idea but the first game just felt like any other themeatic American game - there weren't a lot of truly interesting choices to make, but perhaps they'll feel more interesting in a harder scenario. But oddly for an American game, there were a few things that really hurt my ability to get into the theme.

I guess maybe I have trouble feeling attached to my characters when they can come and go so easily. It's for this reason that the secret objectives and traitor actually feel themeatically awkward to me - it's not a character that's a traitor, it's me, the player. It's not a character that's trying to complete these objectives, it's me, the player. It's the difference between feeling like "Oh no! I'm going to die from zombies!" and "I'm going to lose the game." - the stakes feel more themeatic and intense in the first sentence.

Perhaps if you didn't gain new survivors as you went on, I would feel differently. In Lifeboats, for example, it doesn't take long for our group to be at each other's throats in a BIG way as we start watching our only guys die and our numbers dwindle.

The Crossroad cards are a cool idea, but I suspect they won't stay interesting in a narrative sense after a few games when you've seen them before. They serve a gameplay function, but it's sort of at the expense of making them more thematically and narratively interesting - if you didn't know the exact outcome of your choices until you made them, that would make things more emotionally and themeatically tense and interesting, and give you an added reason to play again and make different choices. As they are, even under all that flavor text, they feel a little cold and mechanical to me.

So we'll see if a harder scenario can make this game really shine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
A mediocre cooperative with traitor gaming experience. All it does is remind me of every other zombie game I have played. Go to a location, search, try to get weapons, kill zombies, achieve bizarre random mission. Lots of moving, searching, killing - moving searching killing. Is this what RPGs are like? Ugh. The individual goals are completely arbitrary and depending on how the scenario plays out can be essentially unachievable.
 
The traitor aspect creates some tension, but it all feels forced by the players, desperately trying to get into it. It isn't strategic tension, or decision-making tension. Just the tension of uncertainty - like someone has a secret that you're not in on. Game seems very easy without the traitor, and very difficult to win with one if they time it well. 

A decidedly meh experience that brings nothing new to the table.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
As many others I also looked forward to try this semi-coop game as it sounded like it would replace Battlestar Galactica. Now, I’ve never been a fan of that game as it’s waaay too long, but I do love the traitor mechanism and love social deduction games with hidden roles and agendas etc., so DoW sounded like a game right up my alley. I’m pleased to say that my high expectations were met!

I don’t really care about themes in games, but I guess the zombie theme is kind of neat, and it integrates well into the mechanics (or rather vice versa). The game can be played in various ways due to the several scenarios available, and there are both scenarios for short games (~1 hour) and longer games. So far I’ve tried 3 different scenarios, and because of the winning condition each of them played out differently.

Speaking of the winning conditions, one of the best things about the game is the fact that everybody needs to achieve the overall goal of the game, or everybody loses. However, you can only win if you have achieved your own private goal as well! This means that sometimes players will act irrationally – and this is why it’s awesome that there is also a traitor included in the game! He has his own goal/objective and tries to get the morale to 0 etc., and the tension about who is the traitor is awesome – and actually there might not even be a traitor in the game due to the way the roles are dealt at the beginning of the game! But the tension alone and the fact that there probably is, but you’re never sure, a traitor, is awesome. The traitor obviously needs to not be too suspicious at the beginning of the game in order not to be exiled, but there are many subtle ways the traitor can wreak havoc (I won’t list them here as you need to find out yourselves!)

I’ve been the traitor myself in one of my playthroughs, and I would most likely have won on the following round, but one of the other players rolled a tooth 2 times and another player 1 time, which meant the morale dropped to zero a round before it should have in order for me to win! We were swarmed by zombies and the good guys had no chance of winning, but those die rolls can be brutally random and made me lose as well! At least it was a lot of fun so I don’t mind. In another one of our plays the traitor got exiled in the same round as the game ended. He had no way of winning, but as he was exiled he got a new objective, which he was extremely lucky to accomplish on his last action! The game certainly creates some memorable moments…

I like the different characters and the fact that you control multiple characters that each have special abilities. The way you all need to contribute to the crisis deck is neat too, although be aware of the traitor! It also felt like a zombie-film, sort of, because more and more zombies arrive where you are or if you make too much noise. I didn’t care for the crossroads cards; their primary job is to add some randomness and uncertainty to what can happen/is happening, and also to include a bit of story and background theme. It works, I guess, but I’m not the target audience for that kind of thing.
All in all, DoW is definitely a good coop game with a traitor. I think it’s slightly better than Shadows over Camelot and a lot better than Battlestar Galactica, Police Precinct and most other games of that type. It plays rather fast, there is a lot of tension due because of the traitor, and the way you win (need to accomplish both the overall and personal objective) is great!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I liked the theme, fitting title and components which are well done and better than countless grey plastic miniatures. The teleporting of items between characters searching different locations and the dog equipped with martial arts abilities detracted from the experience and once you decide what your characters are best at there aren't many interesting decisions to be made each turn. Also because the red infection die can kill off a character in one roll, there's even less incentive to change locations. It has a similar feel to BSG (co-operative with hidden traitor) but plays faster which is a plus.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1.1
The game is really a 7, so this low rating is a protest against poor playtesting. The game often rests on a razor's edge. That is great! But it does so even WITHOUT a traitor.

The traitor can lay low until what is the de facto last round of the game. That round in which everyone knows that the game will be won or lost. The traitor will often realize that he can't fulfill his objective during this last round. The traitor goes all-in on the contribution and tanks the game. So no one gets to win. And there is no way to exile a traitor who doesn't show himself until the last round. No extra turns in which to exile him.

I just wish the game had something, anything, to prevent this sad ending. I've seen it happen in ALL THREE games I have played. It's just WAY TOO easy to tank the game. Frankly, I'm surprised I have yet to see a good guy tank the game when he can't complete HIS secret objective.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The whole idea of winning and losing is messed up beyond belief. Traitors can tank the game "just because," fellow non traitors can make you lose "just because" without affecting their own personal odds of winning. The crossroads mechanic is entirely disruptive to a player's turn. Downtime between turns is horrid and only made worse by the Crossroads cards (to the point where if one of those triggered I was frustrated more than anything else). It's everything that's bad about thematic gaming and very little of what's good. That said, there's some neat ideas here, but far from being a fun experience.

I also find I generally dislike these traitor co-ops where the traitor can pretty much do everything in their power to try to *help* players win only to simply tank the game at the very end, even if the odds of victory are already very slim. Makes the traitor nigh on impossible to find, makes an already difficult to win game beyond difficult to win, and distills all traitor decisions down to a simple "eff you" gesture at the very end. I feel like BSG and Dark Moon fall into this camp too. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
