=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Got this game after seeing it featured on an episode of table top.  The concept of simultaneously working with a group to survive (all while one of them may be a secret backstabber) is fantastic. 

The game's pace can be optimized for long, medium, or relatively short play sessions.  I liked that you were controlling a group of survivors, rather than a single person who may live or die.  

Sometimes the game is punishingly difficult.  While it gives you the opportunity to avoid rolling for exposure, sometimes you simply must do so and rolling the dreaded "bite" mark means instant death.  We had this happen a few times on the very first move action and it immediately made the game much harder. 

Overall there is some replay value.  The game comes packed with a huge assortment of different missions, each of which has a "hardcore" version.  Each time you play you'll be using different characters, finding different items, and you'll have your own secret objectives.  

The "crossroads" cards are a really nice addition to add an extra dimension of choice and randomness to the game.

Ultimately, Dead of Winter works well.  It has a ton of concepts (and pieces) but they're easy to understand and mesh well together.  It teeters on the brink of doing too much but manages to pull it off and I'd recommend this game to any of my friends.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A game i love! but it does not get enough of love on the table. 
It takes some time to play and it is very hard.
I like hard games but some of the people i play with does not. 

In this game you are a character living in a colony after a zombie outbreak destroys the world. 
You need to find resources to keep the colony alive and also to stop crisis that happens every round. 
The art work is very good and the cardboard cutouts is really good so you are not missing minis. 

It is a bit like Battlestar Galactica but much better and sometimes no one is a traitor, but you will probably still be eaten and let your colony burn. 
Great fun and hard as trying to sneak by customs with a pineapple without a suitcase.

RATING: 8.25

I really want to try the expansion (though as it is the cost of the game it might be a while before I can justify it).

RATING: 9
3~5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I was swept up in the hype for this before it came out. When I finally got it and played it, I was a bit underwhelmed. I've been trying to figure out exactly why that is over the past couple plays, but I haven't been able to put my finger on it yet. It's certainly not a bad game by a far shot.

I think one of my main issues with it are the secret objectives. Most of them (nearly all, in fact) are some variation of "make sure you have X number of Y items by the end of the game", which isn't a terribly exciting goal to chase after. I get that some of them, like hoarding medicine or guns, might cast suspicion on your actions and make the other players think you're a traitor, but I haven't seen this happen in practice. In fact, the traitor objectives that I've seen seem so ludicrously difficult to achieve that most people half-heartedly go after them but give up near the end of the game once they realize it's impossible to win. That, or they wait until the last few turns and just absolutely wreck morale. It's a weird setup that I'm not sure works for me.

I was also disappointed with the quality of the writing on the mission conclusions and crossroads cards. They seem overly dramatic, verging on campy, and the style just doesn't seem to flow with the tone the game is trying to create.

If I seem overly negative it's only because I can see what an interesting set of ideas this game is. I do like the co-operative aspects of it, with the added tension of a possible traitor (assuming the traitor's goals are actually attainable) I'm definitely going to play this more to come to a more concrete conclusion on it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This is an interesting game with some mechanisms built in to build mistrust between the players in an otherwise cooperative game. I think the crossroads cards helping to tell the story of the game and the scenarios that add story make this much more enjoyable than the game would be if it was just the actual game mechanisms. If you really value the story and narrative aspects of game this game can really sing. I personally think that this one is a little shallow mechanically but can still be fun especially if you get into the theme.

RATING: 7.6
A welcome change from most zombie games where the goal is to kill the undead (again).
Here it focuses on the survivors and on keeping the colony alive. You still need to deal with the undead, but you need to be much more careful since your survivors are more fragile and each death could mean the difference between winning and losing.
Possible hidden traitor actions make for a tense experience, too.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Let's get the big negative out of the way: downtime. In a five-player game, there's a lot of sitting around doing not a whole lot but watching people ponder their moves. That said, I like those moments when you're offered choices on how to handle a situation, I really like that one of your fellow players MIGHT be a traitor, and I LOVE how the game encourages you to start forming opinions about your survivors (like Sparky the Stunt Dog ... such a good fetcher!). There's even a funky-fun card that requires you to watch and wait for another player to yawn, thus triggering a special action. That's great: it rewards staying involved in the game. If only the game didn't drag so long, especially with five players!

Also own deluxe wooden token bundle

Aside from the Zombie threat, there is the threat of hunger, sickness, a possible (but not necessarally a) traitor.
It's a fun survival game, all round.

RATING: 6
A common victory condition and a personal victory condition. Okay, that's clever.

The game is pretty interesting thematically, and it does implement the traitor mechanic better than BSG does. The action dice mechanic feels a bit unnecessary and the game may feel a bit repetitive after a few rounds, but from what I see, no two games will play the same way. I'd like to give it another go to see if it's worth playing or leaving.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I reeeallly wanted to like this game. I ended up selling it (which I don't do often) after I think 4 plays. It's the kind of game that I found myself checking the rulebook every 10 minutes (which is dense and poorly organized) to try and figure out some minute detail to make sure we were playing it right. So exhausting. We often forgot to grab crossroads cards. My last play was at a con with total strangers, most of whom were also new to the game. This ended up being my clear favorite play of the game. One guy kept trying to convince the rest of us that he was the traitor (he didn't end up being the traitor) but we never believed him. It would have been the perfect camouflage for a well-played traitor game. We all had the right combination of humor and focus that the game played out kinda-sorta quickly and was MOSTLY fun throughout. Still, the dang nit-pickiness of the rules and all of the different cards and how they interact with one another, it just kills the momentum of the game. Also, just me but the storytelling aspect never really panned out that well with me or my groups.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I really love Dead of Winter. It is always a favorite at game night. It has such fun mechanics and great interaction. The stress it puts on the players of "hey, why did you do that, are you the betrayer?" I just love it. 

Looking forward to The Longest Night as well!

RATING: 8
Eljött a zombi apokalipszis, néhány túlélő összeverődik a Kolónia nevű helyen, és megpróbál életben maradni addig, ameddig az adott küldetés sikerül, vagy elbukik. Lehet köztünk áruló, aki titokban a többiek ellen játszik, de a kooperáló csapattagok is egyéni célokért kell megdolgozzanak, ha a nyertesek közt akarnak lenni, ami tovább bonyolítja az összképet. Van 6 darab külső helyszín amiket felderíthetünk, de minden lépésünkkel aktiválhatunk egy eseményt, ami egész érdekes történetekké tud összeállni a végén. Folyamatosan csökken a morál, éhezünk, hullanak az emberek, egyre több a zombi körülöttünk, de vajon tényleg nem talált élelmiszert a vegyesboltban a mellettünk ülő, vagy ő az áruló, aki így akarja elbuktatni a csapatot?

RATING: 8.5
Great theme, unforgiving, and tense gameplay.  Really enjoy it, with or without the modules from The Long Night.  I haven't even bothered playing any of the scenarios on the Hardcore variant, as the game is difficult enough!

Can take a while to teach new players, and unfortunately rounds/games can falter if people don't understand mechanics.  Example: food cards only count as 1 towards the end round event, not the number on the card.  Had people burn high value food cards even after being told at the start...

Highly recommended for those willing to invest time and immerse themselves into the game.  Better with 4-5 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Player's mostly just go to locations to mill decks for what they need. With the right group, it's immersive and great fun. With a group that doesn't get into it enough, it's painful and boring.

RATING: 9
I've played a lot of games with a traitor mechanic, but nowhere else does betraying your friends in the most devastating fashion feel as satisfying as in this game. Mechanics are tight, thematic and well realized with the possible exception of "teleporting" gear when scavenging. The infection die adds a fitting measure of unpredictability and dread to even the simplest actions. All things considered, I REALLY like this game.

RATING: 5
If you don't play this game the way it's meant to be played, it's not very good.  That's some Zen stuff right there.  I played it with two players in the two player pure co-op variant, which is technically supported on the box, but in the same way I'm still supporting the Seattle Supersonics.  It's a pathetic support for a poorly thought out idea.

With two people and no secret objectives, it's a ludicrously easy and theme-free co-op game that is significantly worse than literally any other co-op activity you could partake in, especially the naughty kinds.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
At first as I heard the rules of Dead of Winter being explained, I thought it sounded like a mish-mash of other games. Clearly I was going to prefer those.

To my surprise, it all came together nicely! It really moved along once we got a grip on the rules, and I felt like the playtime was perfect. Two of the strongest aspects of the game for me were the hidden goals for each player, and the Crossroads cards - where something may or may not happen depending on the player's actions.

While I don't think I need to own this game (not sure it would get played often), I will be happy to play anytime I was asked.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The bulk of the game (zombies, barricades, locations, searching, food, weapons, other items, etc) is entirely serviceable, but no more so than many other zombie / survival games. (Note: I can't recall a zombie game I've bothered playing more than once, so take this comparison with a grain of salt.)

But the psychology of it - the motivations introduced by the secret personal goals, and all the follow-on consequences of those motivations - is *phenomenal*. Individual victory conditions mean players may engage in odd / not-necessarily-good-for-the-group behavior, which in turn makes ascertaining traitors harder, and keeps an atmosphere of wariness even when there aren't any traitors. You can judge something of what people's motivations are through their actions and responses to Crossroads events. There's the crisis each turn for people to contribute to - or not - or sabotage. The option for Exiling a player - and how it's not the end of the road for them whether or not they were a traitor, they're still in the game but with altered victory conditions - adds teeth to the inter-player tension. Absolutely perfect for the type of game that it is.

There's more chance than I tend to like in my games, and having ten zillion figures on stands was a little inconvenient (they kept falling over), but other than that, fantastic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
No se merece para nada el hype que tiene. No es mal juego, pero ya le querria llegar a la suela de los zapatos al Galáctica. La paranoia que se supone que genera el posible traidor no es tal, ya que sabes que todos van a putear a la colonia por culpa de su objetivo secreto. Y las misiones son muy dirigidas y estáticas, una vez tienes claro qué hacer, lo habitual es tirarse varios turnos repitiendo las mismas acciones. Los personajes, una vez llegan a una localización, pocos motivos tienen para irse a otra. Una pena, porque prometia mucho, pero al final resultó una leve decepción.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
winter is coming...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Tried the Italian edition preview on ModenaPlay 2015, then received for Christmas some months later thanks to my wonderful wife. Wonderful game and great artwork & atmosphere, with some really nice additions such as the Crossroads Cards and the Traitor/Exiled mechanics. It is basically a state-of-the-art cooperative-with-traitor game, with a lot of efforts to improve the genre with new, improved mechanics and a glimpse of RPG-like experience. 

Highly recommended if you love games such as Battlestar: Galactica, Pandemic, Defenders of the Realm (3 games I love) or Shadows Over Camelot (which I personally don't like): as a matter of fact, I find DoW better of all these for the steady mechanics and the super-cool "zombie apocalypse" setting.

See my review here (in Italian):

http://www.ryadel.com/2015/04/25/modenaplay-2015-report-impressioni-recensioni-board-game/#Dead_of_Winter

Had this rated a 7 after the first 2 plays, but the first game was 5 players learning so was painfully slow.  After the third play I find this is a fun co-op with deep theme and less problem with Alpha player compared to other co-ops.  I'm not a zombie fan but the mechanics and theme are so relevant here it sucks you in.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Only two plays, very different. My first playthrough I was the betrayer, and too cautious. Not the fault of the game, and I personally found it very tense as I chose (poorly) my moment to strike. However I imagine that the other players enjoyed it less. Still, I think even with significant downtime between turns it was enjoyable overall for everyone.

The other playthrough was a disaster. One of my starting characters (the better one) died first turn, and I never found another. Another player had a brainfart and managed to convince the other two that he was the betrayer and get himself exiled (it turned out that none of us were). The other player did very well, to the point that he had the vast majority of the characters, so his turns took a long time, and mine took 10 seconds or so. Technically we both won the game, but I certainly didn't feel like it.

It's far from a bad game, but I don't really want to play again.

RATING: 6
Two plays.  For what it is, I like it.  The difference between this and BSG is that in BSG, finding the traitor is basically the meat of the game, whereas with DoW you can win the game without finding him.  I do not like hidden-traitor games where it all becomes about who is the best at bluffing.  The hidden agendas mean that even non-traitors may not always be acting in the best interest of the group.

To enjoy the game though, you have to be extremely patient with random events and things out of your control.  This is not the game for people who want to puzzle out even decision.

RATING: 10
Best or worst of the zombie genre, the deciding factor being your play group. Why do I say that? Because it is all about trusting your fellows to not stab you in the back while they try to do their own goals in a very difficult and brutal game world. Just cooperating effectively is hard enough, hell, surviving is hard enough, but add in that extra element and you have this. There is no need for any more zombie games, this one is it. Bravo.

RATING: N/A
Savez-vous que le zombi est devenu extrêmement populaire dans le monde ludique (63 pages de jeux de zombis référencées dans BGG !). Savez-vous aussi que les zombis adorent les batailles de boules de neige ? Ils n'ont certes pas une cadence de lancé bien grande, mais ils ont l'avantage du nombre. Dead of Winter, c'est un peu ça. Un jeu coop où vous incarnez des groupes de survivants dans une colonie enneigée, et où il va falloir s'habiller chaudement pour aller chercher des medocs, des armes, du miamiam et survivre aux zombis qui veulent faire de vous un bonhomme de chair. Ce jeu a un petit goût de Battlestar Galactica avec des zombis, un traître, des joueurs qu'on peut virer de la colonie par vote, ... le tout scénarisé par des cartes où les choix seront cornéliens.

Pour 2 à 5 survivants pour des parties de 2H environ

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Dead of Winter is such an excellent game that I can completely overlook the zombie theme (which I do not like.) Every game I have played has been tense and exciting: each choice is meaningful and impactful; the objectives are difficult and everyone feels a huge sense of relief and accomplishment when they are met; the betrayer aspect puts everyone on edge and suspicions lead to player tension and unexpected development; the crossroad cards introduce surprise scenarios that randomly alter the tempo. All of them work perfectly together to make each play an experience rather than just a game.

Even though the rules make thematic sense, I find it a tough job to teach to new players because of how many small rules there are. Even small mistakes can significantly affect the balance of the game, so typically the first game with a new group is a write-off.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This game is thematic as hell.  But that doesn't make up for the fact that after you figure out if anyone in your group is a traitor, the rest of the game is just searching for items and trying to complete your side mission so that you will win the game.  The zombies become something on the periphery, and often can be ignored.  

There are moments of greatness that come from the crossroads cards actually taking effect, but that seems to happen only in rare instances for our group.  When it happens, it is magical.  But most of the time, someone draws a card and then just ends up discarding it.  It feels like a letdown every time we pass a turn with nothing happening.

This game is still fun to play with a good group, but I can see it getting stagnant over time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I really wanted to like this but was very disappointed. The card mechanism is clever and works really well, but in most games not enough cards come out to make it interesting. In those games you are left with moving around, collecting stuff, and trying to complete a goal...all pretty dull. The semi-coop thing doesn't help, since the individual goals can be very unbalanced in how easy they are to achieve. Having a traitor makes it more interesting, but doesn't save the dullness of a normal turn--so playing a game with no traitor (or one who doesn't play well) and few card coming out to shake things up can be about as dull as a three hour gaming session can get.  Spending my game cleaning up trash every turn, or building barricades, just doesn't do it for me. 

And by the way, what's with the tonal shift? In a game that should be grim and tense, having a dog with a rifle and a mall Santa that everyone wants to kill (and Kodiac Colby) seem to be out of place.

My understanding is that the expansion adds some interest to the normal game turn, but I have no interest in investing more money in a game to try to make it good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Whenever anyone asks what we should play this ends up being my first suggestion for groups of three or more.  Social deduction, zombies, group survival, darker adult themes, all the best aspects of other games but rolled into one nearly flawless funfest.  Some groups read the crossroads cards more effectively than others but that's been solved by the phone app if needed.  It never falls flat.  I've even whipped this out with groups on initially disinterested nongamers and had it win them over.  It's more intuitive than a lot of games with this much complexity.

My one comment for improvement would be the addition of aftergame flavour text for scenario decompression post victory/failure
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is the best co-operative game i knew so far.

Usually i am not found of games with zombies, but this is a special case: these zombies are just an excuse to put pressure on the players, as they must be controlled to not enter the compartiments where are the players, a possible reason to lose the game. These zombies appear in automatic form (depending on the players actions) and are represented by little image tokens, as are the players. Each player controlls one or more of the different characters with special, but equivalent, skills.
Through action points, players must decide where to go and what to search, collecting itens face down (only known to the player) required for the survival of the entire group.
The problem is (and here comes the great features of this game) there could be one or two traitors among them but no one knows for sure if any of them (or both) are present in that specific game (except, of course, the traitors themselves).
This way, the traitors must try to undermine the global effort without giving way their role, while the "normal" characters will be always in doubt if there is one or more traitors among them, as a "normal" player might choose not to help the team because he can´t or because he just wants to score more points at game end, not necessary on account of being a traitor...
Anyway, players might, at any given moment, vote to decide if a certain player should be expelled (remaining in the game as an outcast), but they might be wrong and expel the wrong guy...meaning that the real traitor (if there is one) remains among them!...
A real clever concept for a game and a very immersive adventure! 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
It is a good semi-cooperative game with fine storytelling mechanisms such as each player having their own objectives, and also Crossroads Cards that inject further flavour into the game. Mechanically, it does have some flaws due to the fact that players need to have complete both their individual and group win conditions to "win". My suggestion is that you should probably play with people who are "nice" (aka not mean-spirited people who will tank the game for everyone for no reason apart from pure spite if they themselves can't win).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A zombie-themed BSG of sorts. Borrows some mechanics from various games. In addition to BSG, it also shares ideas from Mall of Horror (locations with characters attract zombies), Castles of Burgundy (roll dice, then choose action based on die results), and Robinson Crusoe (events, crises, food/item requirements). Would be much less interesting without a betrayer, IMO.

My only criticisms are that 1) the voting mechanic doesn't work well. There should be 2 tiles (one "Y" and one "N") for each player to use rather than the simultaneous thumbs up, thumbs down.
2) The players can either make or break the game. Like most "experience" games, the mood of others at the table can affect the gaming experience in both positive and negative ways. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I still prefer Battlestar Galactica
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Pros:
- Good components, great theme
- Challenging and can be tense the first few times.
- A little faster than Battlestar Galactica, but not by a significant amount.

Cons:
- Still kind of long for what it gives you, depending on the scenario's round count.
- The hidden personal goals are a cool idea but I don't find that they add much value to the game experience. Feels gimmicky after a while.
- Really boring if you end up with no traitor. It then devolves into a standard group cooperative game of action efficiency.
- Not much to do when it isn't your turn besides group discussion or accusations. That might be fine but if you find yourself in a traitor-less session, the best actions end up being pretty obvious or mechanical.

RATING: 7
A very solid game with many a nice component and a excellent presentation. The cardboard is beautiful, the artwork great and the mechanisms intriguing and interesting... BUT: somehow it is not that exciting a game to me. It suffers a little from the same problem as pandemic does; which is not necessarily quarterbacking but that once you understand the mechanisms, you can see that there mostly is a best move to make, making the life for possible traitors pretty hard.

The theme at times stops being there, thanks to the often clunky mechanics. I do LOVE the crossroads cards (better: the idea of crossroads cards) but the vast majority of them just seem to 'trigger' on "If X/player visits location Y".

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I like the "story" part of the game. The feeling is like being part of a chapoter of series like the walkin' dead. In this sense, I liked it a lot.

I like a lot the mechanics. The "Cross-roads" cards are cool and I like the way the interaction with the zombies is done. It is threatening but somehow sutile.

On the other hand, I don't like the fact that you lose if you don't achieve both the team objectives AND your individual objectives. This means that, as non-traitor player, if you cannot achive your individual objectives, you no motivation to achieve the team objectives. 

Another problem with the objetvices is that some times, there is not much you can do to influence them. You have just to sit and wait hopeing that things will happen. 

 Keeping that there is lots of luck (your character can just die with one unlucky roll), I think that the game take a bit too long for me. I also don't like that there is quite a long waiting time between players until your next turn.

Even with these negative points, I enjoyed a lot playing the game because of the thematic/story/mechanics aspects. 

I would definitely play the game again with the same group of people but I don't think I would buy it to play with other groups or solo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[28 Feb 2016] - 7.25 (5 plays)
Finally got the game to the table with the right mix of people to see the game at a different level. I still feel like it's fairly easy to guess who the traitor is in the game, if there is one. The crossroads cards are pretty fiddly - it's hard to remember them and sometimes decode the trigger event. A solid zombie game that adds some nice player interaction.

[18 Oct 2017] - 6 (7 plays)
Pulled out Dead of Winter because it's nearly Halloween and I haven't really played any of the horror themed games in my collection. We only had 2 so we played it as a co-op zombie game. It worked but felt like a fairly generic co-op game. Without the betrayer there isn't much tension other than staying alive in the colony. This game requires the right type of players and higher player counts in order to really shine. If you have players who aren't emotionally invested in their mission, or who need a lot of guidance in the beginning or you just have lower player counts, the game can turn out to just be a zombie game.

RATING: 9

RATING: 7.7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
Excellent semi-cooperative game (can be cooperative, and always is with 2-players) where survivors at a post-apocalyptic colony try to fight off zombies, and search for supplies. Always intense, it is challenging to balance the problems at hand...try not to get overrun by the zombie horde, try to feed your people, try to search for desperately-needed supplies, and don't forget the dreaded RED DIE that you have to roll every time you attack a zombie or move to a location. So even if we stop right there, we have a great game on our hands. But what really pushes this game to the next level with me is the Crossroads deck, where events can trigger depending on what you do on your turn. It really adds a depth of narrative and decision-making that is truly innovative, and just plain cool. One of my favorites.

RATING: 10
Thematically one of the best games I've played. The swings that can happen in the game, from finding the wrong card at the wrong time, to triggering a Crossroads card that throws a major wrench in the works, really ramp up the tension. This is seriously one of the most immersive games out there. The artwork is superb, the components are great quality (especially for cardboard chits), and it looks impressively intimidating on the table. Yet, it's a blast. A "Medium" game can last about 2.5 hours or more, so I wonder how long a "Long" game would go.

One of the best purchases I've made, and one of the few games I've given a 10-star rating to.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[January 2018 - 7]
Haven't really played it much since the first rush.

September 2015 - 7
Good co-op, and first and foremost fixes the issue of the over-controlling player. Everyone has their secret missions, so there's a sense that you're also doing your own thing, and I love how playing your secret mission can start to cast doubt on whether you are the betrayer or not.

Secondly, in my opinion, you play this game for the experience and entertainment. Your group has to find some humor in it, or else it can fall flat. I enjoy the game play and there's definitely strategy on which of your characters does what and in what order, but there will be those rolls where one of your characters die right off the bat and that's that -- you're a man down for awhile.

It can be a little lengthy -- even the short main objectives -- and like most co-ops feel a little old after multiple plays in a short period of time.

All things considered, it's a little overrated but fun in doses.

RATING: 8
This is a very nice zombie-game, with some interesting mechanics, like the cross-roads-card, the traitor card, the missions and the event-cards. All these in combination make for alot of replayability, since you never know who the traitor will be, or what missions you will be playing.

Each playthrough requires a new playstyle, according to your personal mission, which I think is a very nice touch. 

All these mechanics do also make for a slightly cumbersome game, that takes a while to setup and get a hold of, but as soon as you've played it a few times, the turns will be quicker and you'll have an easier time playing it.

In other words, it's what zombie games should be about rather than just running around killing zombies. A really excellent game if you are into this style of game and the theme.

RATING: 8
2-5
45-210 min
Kjell
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
An enjoyable and accessible co-op/possible-traitor post-zombie-apocalypse game - think 'Walking Dead' theme via a more streamlined, and shorter, version of Battlestar Galactica game mechanics and you are most of the way there.

Having your own objectives to complete on in addition to the group objective and the possibility of a traitor ('betrayer') does solve the issue that besets many co-ops in that they turn into group problem solver with an alpha player who bullies the game.

I do have a couple of concerns about the game:-

- Cycling of the Crossroads cards after a few games will reduce the surprise and challenge of the game.

- Is it too easy for the group to win without a betrayer but too hard for the group if there is one?

- The personal objectives I have seen so far don't always drive enough conflict with the group's main objective to create the paranoia they are probably intended to - it does need to be stressed when teaching the game that hitting your personal objective is paramount over the group.

Still good fun so far.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There is a good balance of co-operation, competition and decision making under uncertainty.

Give it a try.

RATING: 5
Dead of winter is a semi cooperative game based in a zombie apocalypse scenario. The mechanics are based on The typical American style equipment card and rolling dice mechanic. There isn't anything particularly special here but the seem certainly does come through and with the right people it is a lot of fun. The biggest negative thing is that you can't wait for your turn for quite a while. Then you will do two or three random actions with only a few choices that might be mitigated by the other players giving you advice and then you have to wait for another 10 to 15 minutes for your turn. There is really very little to think about when it isn't your turn and there is only so much trash talk you can do. I'm afraid that this game isn't anything too new. But if you like Themeatec games with a traitor element you might enjoy Dead of winter.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[b]Tipo:[/b] Semi-cooperativo // [b]Interacción:[/b] Media // [b]Azar:[/b] Alto // [b]Rejugabilidad:[/b] Media
[b]Cartas:[/b] 329 de 63x88 mm
[b]Fundas recomendadas:[/b] Ultimate Guard "Supreme" (tamaño "Standard size")



[b]OPINIÓN PERSONAL:[/b]
Mi desilusión con este juego fue, en gran medida, culpa de la distorsionada imagen que tenía de él: cuando por fin nos pusimos a jugar, después de haber leído las reglas con detenimiento, esperábamos una partida ágil y trepidante... y los largos entreturnos acabaron rápidamente con nuestras ilusiones.

No es que sea un mal juego, pero si quieres abordarlo tienes que tener en cuenta los siguientes puntos:

 -> Hay que estar dispuesto a jugar una partida lenta: la duración de las misiones más cortas creo que se estima en 60 minutos... pero siempre suelen alargarse (sobre todo si hay algún jugador novato), y al tener un desarrollo tan pausado dan la sensación de durar mucho más. Hay que sentarse con la mentalidad de que va a durar mucho (aunque luego no sea así), y que vas a tener que esperar bastante mientras los demás jugadores hacen sus turnos.

 -> Es un juego cooperativo. Sentarse pensando en un juego semi-cooperativo tirando a competitivo es un error: es bastante posible que ni siquiera haya un traidor, y aunque lo haya tendrá que disimular para no ser descubierto, así que durante la mayor parte de la partida será como si todos los jugadores fuesen aliados. Es más, el juego en sí te impulsa a hablar y debatir con los otros jugadores sobre las acciones a tomar, pues si fueses "a tu aire" los entreturnos se te harían todavía más largos (dado que, básicamente, no te interesaría lo que pudiesen hacer los demás en sus turnos).

 -> Hay que meterse en la historia. Es recomendable leer la introducción de la misión y el texto de todas las cartas que vayan saliendo, intentando meterte en el ambiente que describen. Si te limitas a leer las reglas se te hará bastante soso.

Si cumples los tres requisitos, es muy probable que puedas vivir partidas memorables con este juego, y que para ti sea digno de un notable o incluso un sobresaliente... por desgracia, en mi grupo de juego no encaja demasiado bien.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I agree with everyone that this is a good game. Possible traitor, obfuscated by everyone having a hidden objection - good. Heavily thematic struggle for survival - good. Crossroads system - friggin' excellent.

All that said, I just don't enjoy playing the game. The stress of 'struggle to survive' is too over-complicated by the fact that everyone will, at the worst moment, do something terrible for the sake of their goal - and we all just have to accept it or throw them out of the camp (difficult to justify, when everyone's doing it.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The original Pandemic with some role-playing and story-telling thrown in.  I think what I like the most about this game compared to the original Pandemic is that it solves the alpha-player problem by giving each player an individual “Top Secret” objective and each turn offers a great more variety of possible options.   In Pandemic the best option for a player to perform on their turn is usually pretty obvious and is quickly pointed out by the alpha-player and everyone generally sits back and agrees.  In this game, there are so many more options and players don’t really know what is in the best interest of an individual player to solve their particular objective.  Often described as a ‘traitor’ game, this one is a bit different.  To solve individual objectives, players are often given neurotic needs (for example, to win, a player may need to hoard gasoline canisters), which makes pointing out a traitor much more difficult.  And the traitors’ personalities are much deeper than just being a ‘bad guy’; they seem to be just really crazy personalities with extreme neurotic needs that are to the terminal detriment of the other players.    
Additionally, while the Zombie Apocalypse theme is there, it really is just an extra thrown on top: this is NOT a game about going out and taking down zombies.  It actually felt a lot more like the game “Arctic Scavengers” to collect needed cards: especially when you have to ‘dig’ for resources and supplies.  
However, I recommend that you play this with someone who has the rules down-pat to chaperone this game.  The rules are fiddly and we were often forgetting little things (did we add ‘frost bite’ to a character?  Did we remember to roll for this or that).  We were all over that rulebook (which needs a better Appendix).   When we were in a conundrum with the rules, I would jokingly repeat, “Okay, time to pull out the Dungeon Master’s Guide.”  
For a cooperative game and ‘traitor’ game, this is an evolutionary step forward.  However, with a stated average game time of 100 minutes, that seems too long for this kind of game where either ‘you win’ or ‘you lose’.  The group of players I played this really like these type of thematic ‘traitor’ games, but they seemed very somber and subdued while playing it.  Afterward, with this same group, we played a game of “Saboteur” from 2004, and its like suddenly everyone was injected a with a burst of espresso and everyone woke up, came alive and started to express having a good time (with that game).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.25
One of the better semi-coop games I've played.  It dodges some of the problems the genre has, but not others.  

So, the theme.  Zombies yet again..  However, it must be said that the meat of the game isn't fighting off zombies (the mindless minis spawned by the game), but managing the colony, keeping tabs on the other players, and the tension of surviving versus fulfilling your own individual goals.  Zombies as a backdrop are forgivable, in this instance.
I like the whole 'group goal plus individual goals' idea, however it suffers from the usual problems.  Once you know the game, you'll start to have an idea which goals people are working on.  Some of them are easy, others really tough.  Many, if not most, are highly dependent on random factors outside your control (whether you draw medicine cards from the search deck, whether you can recruit/kill off followers, etc.).  We haven't seen a lot of traitors in our games, so I don't really have a feel for how their goals stack up.  The vaunted 'crossroads' random event cards will eventually become repetitive as well.

A few of the design choices bug me.  I really feel like the dice are mostly superfluous.  Only a few actions are limited by what you rolled; the rest can be done regardless of value.  
The 2nd thing was noted by other people during playtest, and that is about the way zombies and barricades interact.  Instead of keeping out zombies as you'd expect (same number are there, but you're buying time by raising the limit of how many can exist), barricades act more like mines, killing off zombies and being destroyed 1:1 as they come out.  Going out and fighting a zombie accomplishes the same exact thing, but A. is more risky, since you have to roll the exposure die and B. requires a certain action die value, while barricading can be done with any.  So why would you ever fight when you could barricade?

I haven't played enough times to know more than that.  I'm not sure I see it replacing the current favorite, BSG, around here, but who knows.

Ed. So, it seems I was wrong, as BSG has dropped off considerably in the past year.  I've also played this several more times recently, and am liking it less as a result.  
The most recent few times we've played, there has been a traitor.  And I hate to say it, but a competent traitor can really break the game.  Both times, they've been able to map things out, and discover that they're going last on the last round.  If that happens, you have [i]zero[/i] chance to win.  They get the hammer on the last turn, suicide all their chars (and some of yours as well) and tank morale faster than a downpour at a baseball game.  Your only counter to this is voting to exile them, but you can't, since every loyal player has already had his/her turn.
Even if it isn't the last round of the game, they can still do the same thing on some other turn when they're going last.  The only thing stopping them is getting their objective done.  

In general, I've been more disappointed with the objectives.  I hate the fact that you can have everything set up, then get hosed on the last turn because you moved back home (and moving is something you often [i]have[/i] to do) and got killed by the exposure die.  That thing can be so painful, and rolling a bunch of frostbite wounds early on can drain the table of medicine.  The objectives that require you to search for a specific type of card can be even more troublesome, as other players can come in and make off with all the stuff you need while you draw nothing but food or junk.  And in many cases, they couldn't even help you if they wanted to, since any card you gain by request has to be played immediately.
Edging the rating down as a result.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
One play with 5. Similar enough to Pandemic that I'll compare it to Pandemic: as far as I can tell, it's more complicated, more isolating, and potentially much longer. The traitor mechanic was buried under so many layers that I didn't find myself trying to see who was bluffing. The traitor (who was an experienced player) won in a complete surprise, leaving no clues that he was a traitor beforehand. Is a surprise ending like that fun? For me, it's not more fun than a game that emphasizes bluffing among all players. It's not more fun than a competitive game where you know you're competing. And it's not more fun than a purely cooperative game.

I would try it again if someone wanted, but I wouldn't ask for it.

RATING: 8.5
My wife and I do not like Battlestar Galactica. We like the tension, and the mechanics are solid, but a game takes far, far too long. So, we were attracted to Dead of Winter, which was billed by playtesters as a short BSG. They were mostly right. My wife and I are big, big fans of Dead of Winter, and will never refuse a play. Even new players can easily get into the game, and the manual is well enough written that any rules questions are quickly answered.

RATING: 8.76
Maybe the most American game I own, just because it's worth it.
The theme is strong with this one, think "The Walking Dead" and "Resident Evil". You will be there, almost.
Even though the board and locations are less fancy than say "Zombicide", the game is thicker, satisfying and it's one of the best "narrative game" examples I've ever played.
Every player will guide a group of survivors, trying to defend the colony and find enough food and items to endure the harsh conditions of this post-apocalyptic world. But a traitor could be lurking in your colony, and could be secretly working against us! Danger and suspicion will rule the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.64
Interesting game with traitor mechanic and excellent zombie apocalypse theme where zombies are not the central problem. It is full of intrigue and poor choices because every resource is extremely valuable and they are always in deficit.

The big drawback of this game is huge downtime with more than 3 players. Crossroad cards are interesting mechanic, but they only involve player to the right and they don't come up too often. They are also full of favour text where important key words are non distinguishable which only increases downtime. 
Also the principle where you have a group of people that share your secret individual goal is a little bit strange to me. 

I would still rather play Battlestar Galactica than Dead of Winter.

[b]Edit:[/b] Downgraded from 7.1 to 6.0 for obvious reasons.
[b]Edit:[/b] Sold!
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Surprisingly, the crossroad cards. They are making the game much more interesting, require at least one other player to pay attention outside of his own turn and they are adding to the story (if you actually read the story).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love games that have a traitor mechanism built in.  The longer I play games, the more I think this is just one of those things that I really enjoy about modern boardgames.

The fact that the game actually surrounding the mechanism is good helps a lot (okay, I'll be fair, the traitor isn't necessarily the pillar of DoW).

As I once wrote for Arkham Horror, one of the biggest draws to the hobby for me was narrative.  While over the years I have sort of strayed away from that aspect of the hobby, DoW was like picking up an old habit and going, "omg, why did I stop?"  Sounds horrible, but you don't know how good it felt to sit down and read event cards out loud to weave a story around what we were doing at the table.  Couple this with the secret objectives and the Resistance-style levels of mistrust amongst us, and you've got one hell of a thematic game.

It's kind of a pain in the butt to set up and tear down, though, but hey, there are worse games for that - many in my collection!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Highly thematic semi-cooperative survival game.

The good:
-Excellent representation of post-apocalyptic survival. 

-50 or so interesting potential characters. 

-Emergent story telling, with surprising scripted events. 

-Cooperative (well, most of the time).

The bad:

-Players will realise whether they can complete their secret objective or not prior to the game ending. If they can't win, and they're Timmy Powergamer - then why should they bother continuing to play?

-Some scenarios are nigh unwinnable (e.g. Kill Them All)

-Some characters are just better than others. Anyone that gives you a free action equivalent with minimal conditions, or prevents you from rolling the exposure die.

-Most of the game does really turn into EITHER 
--Go to location X and search for loot Y
--Kill zombies

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dead of Winter is a game with a some similarities to BSG. You have a crisis you need to deal with each turn and players submit cards secretively to help or harm the success of it.  This is mostly where the similarities end.  Like Shadows over Camelot, you are not always guaranteed to have a traitor.  The two big aspects of the game that set it apart from others traitor games is the secret objectives and crossroad cards.  There is a visible main objective/scenario and each player has a secret objective.  Non-Traitors need to complete both to win.  This secret objective usually enforces people making selfish moves to sow distrust amongst the players. As for the Crossroads cards, the player to the left of the active player reads the trigger on Crossroad cards. If a player does the trigger action, there will be an event that usually is thematically tailored to the action.  Overall, I like BSG more, but I can see many people preferring this due to the quicker player time.  This is a good option to play a BSG-esque game, but don't have 5/6 people for BSG.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fantastic cooperative game with a nice story element and great tension due to the possible traitor aspect. Wonderful components. Gameplay makes sense. The variable length missions with two levels of difficulty are well thought out. I'd love to see an expansion with additional places to go and explore.

RATING: 6

Everyone freaked out, and several have since gone out and purchased their own copy. I have witnessed many people have "Oh! I didn't realize there where board games like this..." moments, but none have been as fast nor engrossing as those that DoW has insighted. The co-op nature of the game keeps it accessible, while the 'traitor' aspect keeps it tense. It also has one of the best risk-reward mechanics I've seen as players must balance food/resource scarcity, and the dangers associated with venturing out of camp. And the red die is ruthless.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
"Crossroads" is a new series from Plaid Hat Games that tests a group of survivors' ability to work together and stay alive while facing crises and challenges from both outside and inside.

Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game, the first game in this series, puts 2-5 players in a small, weakened colony of survivors in a world where most of humanity is either dead or diseased, flesh-craving monsters. Each player leads a faction of survivors with dozens of different characters in the game.

Dead of Winter is a meta-cooperative psychological survival game. This means players are working together toward one common victory condition — but for each individual player to achieve victory, he must also complete his personal secret objective. This secret objective could relate to a psychological tick that's fairly harmless to most others in the colony, a dangerous obsession that could put the main objective at risk, a desire for sabotage of the main mission, or (worst of all) vengeance against the colony! Certain games could end with all players winning, some winning and some losing, or all players losing. Work toward the group's goal, but don't get walked all over by a loudmouth who's looking out only for his own interests!

Dead of Winter is an experience that can be accomplished only through the medium of tabletop games. It's a story-centric game about surviving through a harsh winter in an apocalyptic world. The survivors are all dealing with their own psychological imperatives, but must still find a way to work together to fight off outside threats, resolve crises, find food and supplies, and keep the colony's morale up.

Dead of Winter has players making frequent, difficult, heavily- thematic, wildly-varying decisions that often have them deciding between what is best for the colony and what is best for themselves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Bagged, played a couple times, all promos except FD and DT incorporated

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I’m surprised to find myself saying this but the whole ends up feeling less than the sum of the parts. There’s so much here I should love from the BSG-like paranoia induced by the hidden loyalties to the personal win conditions to the crossroads to the fact I happen to be one of those people who still actually likes the zombie theme, but the sessions have all been tame so far and after my last one, I can’t say I’m in a hurry to play it again.

I think my problems with the game boil down to it being a great idea that is, unfortunately, not well executed. Granted, it’s an ambitious idea, but I don’t think it succeeds enough to rise to the compelling level that BSG does, and I would rather play that one hands down every time given a choice. What should be a lot of paranoia doesn’t materialize much because the traitor is so in fear of getting found out and exiled. In BSG, you start messing with things and even if you get found out and brigged, you can reveal and continue to be an effective outed Cylon. 

Here, if you get exiled, your endgame goal will change and you very well may have to start all over again. Better to hang back until things go wrong on their own and then try to pound in the final nail. Even when the traitor wins, it feels more like due to the vicissitudes of the game than their efforts. Furthermore, the individual goals encourage hoarding and sandbagging the team but I’ve yet to see that inspire any real paranoia.

The crossroads cards are a wonderful idea that should happen a lot more than they do. As it is, they happen very rarely which makes them feel like a missed opportunity. I want to feel myself at a crossroads every turn not maybe once a game. I think they need to be revised both in terms of how easily they activate and the choices you have. Even when they activated the choice was too often too easy to make. 

In short, I think this “Crossroads Game” needs more crossroads.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Engaging, but perhaps a little samey after a few plays?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Christmas 2015.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Foamcore Insert

If I recall correctly, this was our first 'new hotness' purchase.  I picked this up from my FLGS when it first came out.  It was still pretty hard to find in stores for probably another 9-12 months afterwards.

The game itself still remains a favorite.  We want to get it to the table more often, but there's always something else to play or more the player count isn't conducive to good play.

I'm looking forward to the expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I love, love, love:
- the semi co-op gameplay
- the crossroads cards adding story and tough decisions
- the secret objective cards adding personality quirks to the survivors
- the survival challenges/scenarios
- the dice results = available actions
- the number of dice equals number of survivors plus one

I dislike:
- that we haven't played all of the scenarios, still
- that we keep forgetting to do the crossroads cards stuff!

Final verdict: Fun co-op game that combines good moments of humor, bewilderment, frustration, sadness, anger, and more all into a good zombie drama roleplaying game.

RATING: 5
The crossroads cards are the most entertaining element of the game, but they are not backed by a strong mechanism; You can have a game where no crossroads cards trigger. I am baffled by people that say the crossroads system is innovative. There are much better mechanisms supporting narrative out there e.g. Robinson Crusoe's cause/effect system. Also huge downtime.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
CoG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great semi-cooperative game. The players are survivors of a zombie apocalypse. At game start, a random team objective is chosen, and the players are given secret individual goals. One or more traitors may also be in the mix, trying to keep the team from achieving their objective.

The players start by controlling two characters, who move around the various buildings trying to search for necessities and kill zombies without being bitten. The game has a lot of moving parts, with crisis cards popping up every round that must be solved or failed, and crossroads cards potentially affecting each player on their turn, all in addition to the group objective and the player's individual goals. However, the variety adds a lot of repeat playability to the game.

I like the ambiguity that the secret objectives add to the game, as they make it much harder to suss out if anybody is a traitor. Any weird activity by a player may just be them trying to fulfill their secret goal.  I also really like that the game is tough.  Even without a traitor, the players have to work hard to beat the game.  The component boards and stand-up characters are solidly built.  Highly recommend this game. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 8.5
very good coop game, don't play the easy scenarios, they are way to easy! I'd rather lose with lots of action, then winning with no action or any difficulty at all. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Our four player game lasted 3 hours (which is why I'm not giving this a 10) but we had a blast. The theme is pure and true. I felt like I was watching the first season of a new zombie show. No-strike that. I felt like I was LIVING the first season of a zombie show. The characters are all interesting and the hidden objectives kept me feeling off balance and nervous.

The crossroads mechanism is wonderful. I hope to see this implemented in future games. Crossroads system gets a 10 out of 10.

I did notice that there was about 20 minutes downtime between my moves because each player needed like 7 minutes to run their turn. This will likely speed up as my gaming group gets to know the system better - but I can't give Dead of Winter a perfect ten because of down time. Otherwise, I LOVE this game.

RATING: 8.5
First acquisition a "tabletop gamer". Really tense and challenging experience, very good from the psychological point of view as well. Recreates the feeling of zombie apocalypse and struggle inside the group with different objectives. Recommended for gamers and zombie genre fans.

Includes:
* Dead of Winter - The Long Night
Quality expansion for the first game, but redundancy of components is annoying. If you have both, you end up carrying two boxes around for one game. If a non-standalone version ever gets released, becomes 9 as expansion.

Recommend getting this first and buying the base game for added cards and tokens. Still worthwhile if you own the base game.

RATING: N/A
After one play: structured like a co-op, but a blend because you don't win if you don't meet your private objective (which includes the global objective, except for the traitor).  So, you want to pursue your private goal at the team's expense, but cooperate just enough to keep from losing completely.  The mechanic of kill or pick a card in different rooms works nicely.  But, the zombie theme is not so compelling and the card board stand-ups are hard to distinguish while playing.  They need player color coding or something.

RATING: 7

The game play itself is pretty straight forward, so once you get the first play under your belt and know more of what to expect I'm willing to bet you can start coming up with some really tricky and devious plays for the win. I like that everyone has their own distinct win conditions each game, and it's possible to lose even when the group is successful with the scenario.

RATING: 9

RATING: 6
I highly recommend using the variant that increases the chance of a traitor. The co-op game by itself is okay, but having a greater chance that there is a traitor really ramps up the paranoia. Seeing a game go from almost certain success to dire failure within one round is when Dead of Winter is at its best.
Only tricky part is teaching new players as there is quite a bit to teach, it sounds like a lot more is going on then there is, but explaining what actions can be taken, the scenario win conditions, crisis conditions, food, waste and how zombies are added can confound initially. After one round most people realise they take about 2 actions and move on and the rest takes care of itself.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I really like this interesting zombie survival colony game. The die rolling before you turn to determine what you can do in your turn is really nice and you can always add pips to dice (at a cost ;)). Rolling for exposure is brutal, as is fighting zombie (as you would expect).
I love the flavour of the chain reaction if you get bitten, in that you must then choose to kill the next lowest influence player, or let them roll  the die, which if they get bitten transfers to the next player and the next .... and the next !:zombie: everywhere!
Crossroad cards are interesting but many depend upon the player being a certain character therefore often it is not possible for the card to trigger. 
Secret objectives vary greatly in difficulty and there are betrayal mechanics (although we have yet to add them)
Lots more left to explore with this game and looking forward to that exploration :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Let us start with the good, the art and components are gernally great throughout the entire production.  That is it.  This doesn't meant that it is a bad game, but so much of it is crushingly mediocre.  Be it the Zombie theme (yes I know the real monsters are the human players), the crossroads system that fires every now and again and offers a random choice for a random reward, the lack of threat from a possible traitor or any defining need to cooperate beyond the bare minimum whilst endlessly searching for that second book you need to complete your secret objective.  There is so much that just misses the mark.  

I played this after owning and playing Archipelago for a while, and there are enough similarities that after I introduced that group to that game, DoW hasn't been played since.  Add in Battlestar Galactica for some genuine threat from hidden traitors, and the only purpose this game serves is fuel for the fire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I usually like semi-cooperative games, and this is no exception.  I've heard that some don't like the secret objectives because it makes everyone seem like a traitor, but I think it adds an extra challenge, and a touch of realism.  No other game is closer to the Walking Dead in a box.

RATING: 8
Excellent co-op game with a fun storytelling element. And I stress the co-op, because unlike games like Pandemic where one player can ultimately end up playing for everyone, it's much easier for players to actually have a say and to play for themselves.

This is aided, in part, by the betrayal element of the game, which, in theory, sounds fun. I say in theory because, in all our plays, we've only ever drawn one traitor, and it was ridiculously hard for him to achieve his goal, so we've yet to delve into the exile portion of the game.

RATING: 6

[b]DEC/15 -1st play-[/b] had just enough of interest that I feel I have to give it one more chance at least, but my gut feeling is that this game isn't for me. 

There were a few problems with the presentation: the theme isn't interesting to me, the graphics are so snowy that they look samey to me, and the game played way longer than I feel it should have (2.5 hours for a short scenario with my two opponents both being experienced players. I was the fastest player).

I also found problems with gameplay. I found myself drawing Food and Junk cards nearly the entire game while my opponents drew Weapons and Survivors. A lot of the characters are variations on each other. The individual win conditions aren't terribly interesting, again being variations on each other.

It felt inevitable that I would compare this to Robinson Crusoe, and later the same day, I pulled out Robinson again to compare. Dead of Winter has the whole potential traitor (which is great), but the different win conditions were uninteresting. DoW also has a bit more event cards in a single deck (as opposed to RC's five separate decks), so let's call that a draw. Otherwise I think RC wins in every category: visuals, board layout, ease of play, component mechanics, special tools, unique scenarios.

RATING: 6
Overall I liked it.  I thought it captured the zombie apocolypse very well.  I felt like I always had something to do, even with a poor die roll.  Getting people equiped from the start with a weapon of some sort is key to keeping the zombies down.  But you need to be searching for stuff all the time since you'll be spending it all the time.

Don't play with 5 new players as the game went about 3 1/2 hours before we failed.
I would play again with 4 max, and one of the shorter scenarios as I think you'd get the same experience as the longer ones.  Even with the long time, the gaming session went quickly and it didn't feel that long.

RATING: 6

If you love co-op games, this is great.  But for me personally, I'm just not going to play it unless its what everyone else wants to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pros
-Lots of characters, good variety of objectives and scenarios
-Secret objectives, changing objectives, optional traitor elements
-Crossroad cards are neat when they trigger
-Fairly fast paced, downtime isn't too high
-Players are usually kept in the game due to possible traitor element, and coop style
-Theme is overdone but suitable here
-Set game lengths due to set number of rounds

Cons
-Very minor but I find board looks a little bland. Fully functional though
-Crisis cards are very bland, they are mostly clones of each other
-Very little surprise at the end of turns since Crisis is revealed at the start of the turn
-No randomization to crisis contributions can out a betrayal player early on
-Very deterministic crisis resolution, every card contributed is just worth 1 (contrast to battlestar galactica's votes which are more exciting since you can be close or far off)
-Crossroad cards don't always activate, and that is where the main story/narrative elements arise from, and also where the interesting social decision making comes from (e.g. votes, debates)
-Lots of repeating items in search decks
-Each player having a party of characters makes the game feel very awkward logistically. I find an item but I can give it to anyone in my party? How do I contribute to crisis for afar?
-Can be gamey where players intentionally play a certain way to get exiled to get a new objective
-Use of D6 seems inelegant since having a high dice roll often doesn't make a big difference (e.g. a 5 and 6 usually serve the same function).
-Not a lot to do at the colony; also despite there being a good variety of actions available, it usually comes down to just two primary/interesting actions: searching and combat. Game can get somewhat repetitive.
-Lots of small number/rules to remember such as rolling a 4+ for noise is a new zombie, but fighting another survivor is rolling less than their combat strength
-Need to remember to draw crossroad cards every turn
-Objective cards and crossroad cards often depend on several factors and players may need to interrupt the game and ask the exact count of things (e.g. cards in a players hand, or who moved where), giving away information
-The concept of having a leader of your group is not further explored and serves no purpose
-Game can be on extremes, it will be much easier if you have no traitor, and much harder if you have a traitor
-High price point to purchase game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Played only twice. Nails its theme and is very immersive, with intense story bits mainly in the form of the crossroads cards. And you have to be on the lookout for possible betrayers or they will screw the colony if they manage to pull their act while sneakily undermining everyone else's efforts. Downtime can get a bit long, but this is somewhat mitigated by having to manage crossroad events for the active player and by analyzing their every move for tells on their secret intentions. I also like how you can choose from multiple scenarios with varying flavor (e.g., fully coop) and duration.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Designed by a near and dear friend. I played an early prototype that I enjoyed thoroughly, which is crazy as I typically dislike playing prototypes. I got to play the near production version recently as well. 

This game is the best I have seen at telling a story yet managing to keep gaming elements. The traitor element and the personal goals elements make it a tense experience in that you cannot entirely trust everyone yet everyone needs to work together to save the colony. 

The theme integrates beautifully. It provides a strong sense of impending doom while giving the players choices that feel meaningful. Those choices are individually decided because of secret personal goals which removes the most common complaint of cooperative games - that one person takes charge and controls all the decision making.

The only complaint I can think of is that a central mechanism of the game is running to various locations to search for items (specific decks of cards) needed for survival. It's not my favorite mechanic, but it works quite well for this game. I am not sure how I would do it better anyway.

This is a powerful storytelling game that evokes desperate feelings and can simulate heroic struggles to survive. I eagerly anticipate getting my pre-order and introducing this to many many people.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

My first impressions were pretty good. It mainly comes from the theme, which I enjoyed a lot. Having a dog with a cape driving a car to the grocery store and doing whatnot is really funny for a post apocalyptic game. Also the crossroads deck was very cool. What I don't know is how well-balanced the game is, cause it didn't feel that way at all. Also, with five players the game took super long to finish and there was generally not much to do during other players turns. One player was doing their thing while the others were chatting or making phone calls. But somehow that didn't bother me.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
I can't get enough of this game. First off, it's ridiculously easy to explain to new gamers. The action allotment system with the dice just makes sense. You need to roll at least this number to do this action with this character. Done. You can pretty much play the game. The exposure die is hilarious and crippling. The hidden objectives really makes this game come to life. The Crossroads cards add awesome theme and tension to the game as well, and cut down on what could be some lengthy down time. Could not recommend this more. It deserves its high ranking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have wanted to try DoW considering I am a fan of zombies and semi-co-ops, plus it's very highly rated. I was a bit of a let down, sadly. The Crossroads mechanic is interesting an adds some narrative and a "choose-your-own-adventure" option system, which is neat. I actually wish it was better formed, as sometimes the Crossroads text was sometimes poorly timed or completely irrelevant.  There were some other things I liked as well: making noise, survivor unique effects, dice action selection. But the game as a mechanically interesting experience is quite boring. The crises are extremely repetitive, finding items are a chore, and watching other people take their turn is a sleepy time. Thematically, it works okay. I can see this game is more of a social experience with passable mechanics to drive the story. However, the story drives you most the times instead of leaving it up to the players to make a unique, interesting narrative for the game. And what the game's narrative seems a bit of an interruption at times.  ("Let's celebrate Christmas, when we're at morale 1 and 25 zombies are at the door and we just ate a horse?!") Anyway. Better as a social experience, but I need a little more meat mechanics wise to get into a game like this. Merchants & Mauraders does it best for me when it comes to balancing Ameritrash with mechanics. And yeah - I would rather play BSG any day over this. So I can't imagine wanting to play this again. A bit flimsy.

RATING: 3
A very polarizing game. I think this one really depends on who you are playing it with

For me, traitor lying games aren't my thing but I could overlook that part and try and enjoy other parts of the game. I like the concept of hidden personal goals that help the traitor out but I did not enough the balance of it in this game.

Unlike BSG where I felt every game was winnable, in this game I feel the opposite. Most of the time, the game is super hard and you are struggling to get by. This coupled with the fact that people will openly tank the game if they can't win because of their personal goal makes leaves a sour taste in my mouth. I don't play the players for this as this game makes it seem like you should try to win as it is not as much of a narrative games as I thought.

Also the fact that sometimes people can get a lot of actions and other times you have a character that dies and you are stuck waiting between turns

The crossroads is a positive thing that came out of this game, I wish the game had more narrative elements to it and then I care less about trying to win it and more about enjoying the experience.

RATING: 9
[BGCOLOR=#33cc99][b][COLOR=#33cc99]_[/COLOR]9[COLOR=#33cc99]_[/COLOR][/b][/BGCOLOR][b]:[/b] Excellent game. Always a pleasure to play. Shines under most circumstances.

Starvation tokens (among other things) are an a$$hole.

Believe the hype. A fantastic thematic experience without being fiddly or cumbersome. Have played this with 10 different people and everyone really liked it. 3 of us bought it after our first play. I enjoy it more each time we bring it out.

[b]Update:[/b] This should be obvious, but if your group isn't invested in the story or his particular survivors the game can fall flat. This was very much the case with the last group I played with. Unfortunate, because they usually like hidden role / traitor elements in games.

[b]Update 2:[/b] Played again with some of the original players. Everyone wanted to play a second game immediately afterward. Still surprised by the different reaction to the game between the two groups. I'm just glad I have a group as enamored with the game as I to enjoy it with.

RATING: 6

So I figured our personal objectives might make me feel like there was still a traitor but it never felt that way & mostly felt like we lost because of poor draws & dice rolls instead of poor decisions. The game did have great art, theme, & ease of play (we played this with a person who thought board games ended at Monopoly & they had a blast with it), but the mechanics just didn't click for me with our 2 plays. Don't get me wrong, I feel like this is a good game, just not the game that has been hyped. Maybe with some more plays I'll feel differently.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is quite fascinating. The core mechanics are basic and boring (dice rolling, card drawing), some aspects of the game are definitely fiddly (for instance, if one of your characters finds an item, you can immediately equip your other character with it even if he's on the other side of town; there is little incentive to bring characters back to camp once gone as it would mean alerting more zombies and needing more food, you can find survivors and keep them in your back pack, if you loose your two survivors - so be it, you get a new one, in fact the game is significantly easier with a smaller group, rather than being equally difficult in a different way, In hard core mode, whoever is the traitor is much more likely to win, without having to do much to destroy the group).
But the game is awesome. The theme is splendid thanks to the semi-cooperative aspect and the cross-road cards. 
It really feels like a bunch of survivors having common interest to work together for some time. Trust is quite central and each decision feels important. It always feels a balance between the group interests and my own personal interests. Selfish people will lose. Altruist people will lose too. You will need to find the right balance. Just like in the real world. 
It is possible for a player to can the game if he sees he can't win it. But if he does, the game is doing you a favour because just like in the real world, is that person worth spending your gaming nights with?
I also like the dice mechanic. We get the nice feeling of throwing many dice and we don't get punished that bad by bad roles. You'd rarely lose a game because of a roll.
This game is good. It is by far the game I play the most and I am so looking forward to the upcoming expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
This game reminds me of Munchkin, which I find silly and annoying, and Shadows over Camelot, which I find mostly annoying, but with an attempt to have more of a game.  The idea of secret objectives and betrayer are good in this semi-coop, but the mechanics and cards make it clunky, and the whole thing bogs down for my taste.  It's too fiddly for lots of players, and yet with fewer players, the social dynamics don't shine.  It's clear a lot of story work was put into the game, and I can see why a lot of people LOVE it.  Just didn't work very well for me, who frankly is not really part of the target audience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Semi-cooperative game (there is possibly a traitor) of killing zombies and trying to fulfill some conditions.

This kind of game, with endless special powers and abilities, doesn't do it for me. Every card is different, every character is different, you control several characters...to no real purpose.

The Crossroads mechanic is definitely interesting, and forcing you to make choices adds to the game. But the effects were often not worth the trouble of reading the card. Starfarers of Catan did this the best because it was so much simpler, but the effects were so much more important as well. 

The game wasn't horrible, but it wasn't that fun either. It overstayed its welcome even at 90 minutes. We played with five, which is too many since you just don't have enough to do. And zombies are definitely one of the most overdone, boring themes ever.
