RATING: 6
The narrative cards and scenarios add immersion but this makes it so close to a roleplaying game that I might just be playing a roleplaying game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game is heavily inspired by another popular game, Battlestar Galactica, but I will skip the ethical part of tthis.

If you like BSG, you will love this game. If you dislike BSG, there's still a huge chance you will love this game. 
* First off, the game manages all the players to get into a role play mood (and you don't have to watch a B-class TV series for that).
* Secondly, the main goal, crisis, and crossroads cards are very clear and everyone always knows what they're supposed to do (unlike BSG, where newbies are always clueless about crisis cards and easily manipulated).
* Third, each player building his own team and equipping them is super fun. You specialize on the go, unlike BSG where you choose your role upfront.
* Fourth, there are no jumps whatsoever so you don't do anything that won't matter in a few rounds. Every turn & every action matters.
* Fifth, a new scenario each game changes the way you play.
* And Sixth, the only resource that'll make you lose is morale so you can compensate stuff with other stuff.

The only downside is, each place you go do not have specific actions as in BSG, which was a good thing and gave you purpose to move around.

Overall this is an unforgiving, solid strategy game that never lets you ease. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.5
I have issues with the traitor mechanic in this game. On the one hand, the possibility of a traitor increases the tension. You never know if someone is just fulfilling his own, additional mission goal or if he is a traitor. Without the traitor mechanic the game would lose tension. On the other hand, I feel uncomfortable being the traitor and playing against all other players while constantly lying to them.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great mix of mechanics that create a good and thematic game! The secret player goals combined with the traitor is perfect and the crossroads cards are always exciting. There's a lot of stuff to remember and some player goals are impossible in a short game, but that may be helped with more plays. 

The problem is that the game feels broken unless you play the long scenarios, but those scenarios are way too long and the game gets into a routine and overstays its welcome. Also, there's a bit too much luck and dice rolling for me.

EDIT: I'll add a recent post I wrote about the theme:
[q]I'd argue that DoW is a very thematic game, but that the crossroad cards are the least thematic thing in the game. What really sells the zombie theme for me is that you're in constant risk whenever you venture out of your comfort zone due to the exposure die and that you can never be sure about your friend's true motivations. 

What draws me to the zombie theme is not the zombies themselves, it's what the post-apocalypse does to the psyche of your fellow humans. It's your friends that are truly dangerous, not the zombies. I can agree that having everyone be forced into acting suspicious is a crutch for a traitor game, but I both think it's thematically brilliant and not an important part of the game. It can be played completely cooperatively, the traitor mechanic is just an added, optional difficulty as far as I'm concerned.

I prefer zombies to be not immediately threatening but eventually unavoidable, they continues to chip away at your defences day after day until you give up- those are the zombies depicted in DoW. They are only dangerous in large groups and you should be able to easily handle them, but if you ignore them for too long they can mess you up.[/q]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.75
We'll play this two player quite often, purely cooperatively.  It definitely plays better with more players and when you have the hidden traitor.  I rank the original (Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game) a little higher since it has more scenarios than The Long Night.

The most memorable game was a three player game where someone had contributed an unnecessary card towards the crisis.  One of the players did not contribute at all, and accusations were had back and forth as to who had sabotaged the crisis.  The innocent player could not agree on whose side to take so there was no one was exiled.  In the end, we achieved the main objective, and when we revealed our hidden objectives, we all completed them as well... no one was a traitor.  We still do not know who added the useless crisis card (or how it got there).

RATING: 6
I like the game but there's one thing that rub me the wrong way. The fact that there might be a traitor in this co-op game I've found to be more annoying then fun. That's a problem because it's one of the core aspects of DoW. But because it's there, and because people have their own agenda, ánd because your not guaranteed a joined victory (you can lose if you don't complete your personal objective) there is this strange competitive/hostile atmosphere. It kinda makes thematic sense? But it's not necessarily fun mechanically, hurting the overall experience. 

The components are good though, I like the characters, the standees and all of the different cards that add story to this game. I just wish the traitor aspect was either removed or a guaranteed part of the game like in Betrayal at House on the Hill.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
On a trip to Yellow Submarine with fellow board game geeks, we found this one in English for a second-hand price. When we enquired about the game's maintenance,  the staff told us only rule book was open, everything else was intact - the pieces haven't even been punched out. Did not think twice.

Got it, took some time setting it up - man 'oh man, after setting up it looked gorgeous. Absolutely stunning. I just wanted to know all the details about it. So once we familiarized ourselves with the rules. It BEGAN!! The first night in the Dead of Winter!

So the gameplay itself after round two felt easy to grasp, it's more about surviving as team than about killing and going on a blood-lust zombie hunt. 
The 'Crossroad Cards' were quite unique to me (also considering the fact that I am new to board games when writing this review). That damn exposure die was so scary and it would ramp up the tension, so the game went on for couple of rounds. But soon it somehow went into the "let's get this over with" territory (it was quite late in the night). I played as Mike Cho and Grey Beard, both of them ended up getting killed. We chose not to eliminate players from the board if their survivor dies.

I loved many aspect of this game, one of my favorite is the "traitor" part where one of us was a traitor (could have played without it, we chose to have a traitor card). 
I love that tension, but not sure if we played it wrong or what happened, the traitor player wasn't revealed to be one until the last moment. Things got frustrating as we waiting for a long time for one player to finish and it was getting a bit of chore by then.

So in short, I really enjoyed it - but need to play more of it to kind of grasp the in & outs, understand the traitor aspect of the game a bit more. And I want the traitor to play his/her game of selfishness at the beginning, that will keep everybody awake and tensed.

RATING: 6
This game is so-so. The theme is interesting. It is fun to race against the clock. The traitor mechanic is fine, as is the crossroads mechanic. It just seems too overwrought for what it is trying to do: a semi-cooperative experience with a traitor mechanic. Battlestar Galactica and its expansions do it better...but not simpler. Ironically, BSG requires more set up and understanding of the rules but its thematic tie in is so strong that the game works in spite of its heaviness.

Dead of Winter is simpler, easier to learn, and not quite as fun.

DOW is not a bad game. It's a good game. It's just not a great game.

RATING: 10
All sleeved in ultra pro sleeves
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A cool co-operative game with some interesting elements.  It's pretty hard to win, but after a few plays you've figured out what some of the bad decisions are and how to avoid them - and suddenly you start getting closer to winning more often.

It has a great traitor mechanic.  It's actually possible to wrongly accuse someone of being the traitor and still have them win the game with everyone else.  You can also have people who aren't the traitor acting selfishly to achieve their own goals and a lot of the time there is no traitor at all, just lots of suspicion.

It helps to reveal how people play games.  You can be left with a decision of not completing your solo objective but still helping everyone else win.  Of course, you could always make sure that if you aren't likely to complete your own objective that you play badly enough for everyone else to lose.  but what sort of person does that...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
Cooperative game, where each player also has a personal, hidden goal (or could even be a traitor working against the others). Each turn, you allocate 3 action dice to your characters to execute actions (fight, search, etc…). 
Luck-dependent, doesn’t offer a lot of meaningful decisions, and compensates its lack of sound and original gaming mechanism with theme and atmosphere - neither particularly original.

RATING: 6
As far as coops and zombie games go (both things I don't like), I would say that this game rises above my bias just a little bit.  There are way too many different moving pieces, if you haven't played it a million times you have a 100% chance of having to look in the rule book every single session. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Zombik, hó, halál, árulás és száműzés
Most kivételesen a véleménynyilvánítással kezdeném. Megjelenésekor nagyon szimpatikus volt a játék. Van benne egy csomó számomra szimpatikus játékmechanizmus, mégis minden eddigi gém végén nem tudtam elégedetten felállni az asztaltól. Talán a túl sok holtidő a játékosok között (megnövelve a keresztút kártyák böngészésének kínjaival), „áruló módban” a küldetés teljesítésének szinte elérhetetlensége, a különböző helyszíneken történő tárgyak utáni folyamatos keresés-kutatás, a megszerzett tárgyak sokszori haszontalansága.
Eddig teljesen koop módban egyszer sikerült nyerni. Tudom élvezni a nehéz játékokat is, de a kilátástalanokat már nem annyira.
Pedig minden adott, hogy megszeressem.
A téma tetszik, zombi apokalipszis után fagyos időben foggal-körömmel küzdünk a kis kolóniánk túléléséért.
Játszható csapatjátékban és korrekt az „áruló módos” verzió is. Mindenkinek a közös cél mellett külön-külön kis küldetései is vannak, tovább formálva a játékosok közötti együttműködést versengéssé.
Nagyon jók a játszható karakterek és megtetszett a keresztút kártyák alkalmazása is. Könnyfakasztó jelenetek játszódhatnak le: például függő kémikusunk zombik hadát robbantja szét tuti keverékével miközben kutya játékosunk mellette szaggatja szét a többit „vállvetve” a gyermekeit védő anyukával és a háttérben figyelő részeges áruházi mikulással.
Kivitelezés is korrekt, maga a szabályrendszer könnyen megérhető már a kis tapasztalattal rendelkező játékosok számára is.
Természetesen angol nyelvfüggősége korlátozza a leendő játékosok körét, de itt hiába várunk magyar megjelenést (bár ki tudja).
Esélyt még kapni fog, hátha megtörik a jég és megérzem azt a hype-ot, ami a játékot körüllengi. Addig „árulós”-nak megmarad a BSG. Talán a megjelenő „stand alone” kieg is segít a számomra hibának tűnő elemek javításában, kiküszöbölésében.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a game about Zombies that is not, after all, About Zombies at all. It's about a bigger monster, a more cruel monsters, the Human themselves.

In this game, Zombies are just a pretext to see human natures at his worst. Each user work together for the survival of the colony but each one has their own objectives and agenda to accomplish. Worst (or best for our gaming experience) some will want the colony to fail as they are traitor. This game, with the right group, can be incredible.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Decided that you need 5 to really enjoy the game, and further all 5 must be either part of a consistent group or very familiar with the game. If a few people have never played the traitor mechanic does not work well. As great as the game is when all the stars align, it is way too difficult to get to the table. 

Another update: How good it is really depends on player count and your group, which in my mind really limits its ability to get to the table. At 2 or 3 there are loads of other co-ops I would rather be playing. At 4 or 5 the game can shine. Then there is the fact that it is hard to bring the traitor element in until everyone in the group is very comfortable with the mechanics, this is especially true at 3. Also you are right, the circumstances and difficulty of the game can vary wildly which is another issue I have noted approaching 20 plays now. I am almost at the point where I may sell it off just because it is good, but not good enough or versatile enough to stay in my limited collection.

Update: After around 15 plays with 2 groups I have found that the whole group really needs to understand the game mechanics for the traitor element to shine. As a pure co-op there are much better choices, but once you implement the traitor my comments below stand. In this regard, however, you need a regular group to play with. If you are only able to whip it out occasionally or not often with the same people I don't think you will be able to take the game to its full potential. I will also say that with 3 it is much harder to be the traitor, and not quite as much fun. At 5 everyone is scratching their heads when you start to the throw the game, but at 3 it can be quite obvious who the person is. 

An instant classic for us. Played several games with 5 players, and at that count the game is great. Play was fast and fluid. The down time in this game is actually exciting as you have players rolling exposure to avoid death, you are constantly watching player behavior to spot the betrayer, and of course the crossroads cards. They are a good mechanic that had an impact in different ways during all of our games. It is hard to complete the main objective depending on die rolls and search results. We had several characters die of exposure in a row one game and that really buried us. Also to complete the objective a good deal of cooperation is required. I am going to try with 3 and 4 player counts and will post my thoughts accordingly. Right now this is one of my favorite games as played with 5. I do think that your group will have an effect on your enjoyment of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This is in some things very good and in other very ugly, which can leads to very fun or boring and frustrating experiences. 
I expect games to be fun 95% of the times I play them, even if I lose... but this is not such a game.
You can win and be very bored during 2-3 hours or also lose and be bored.
Some items of note:
1. If you play with bad players, the game will be boring. This means, new players will probably ruin the game, which leads to another problem which is that you need to play 2-3 games with new people to start having some expecation of fun the next game.
2. People can easily ruin the game for everybody by being a traitor and not knowing how to win.
3. The game is extremely confusing in the secret objective mechanics, since you may be a traitor, get exiled and later on maybe win the game, but the other players who detected you and exiled you may even lose that same game.
4. Traitors are very dependent on which turn they play, for ex. Traitors can win easily if they are the last player of the round, but they have no way to manipulate who will play first or last, so in a 5 players game, you probably get to be last in the round 1 time during the WHOLE game... so that means traitors get a chance to easily complete their objective or not decided by a RANDOM factor. This specific point is to me the WORSE mistake in design.
5. The game has many others game wreckers elements based on RANDOM dice rolls. For ex. you start with 2 survivor. If you move a survivor you roll a dice and you have 1 in 12 chance of dying. In a 5 player game there are 10 survivor, so very probable at least 1 player will being the game with 1 less survivor during the first move (which you need to do otherwise you basically can´t do anything useful). There is also 0.7% that you will lose BOTH your survivor in the first turn just because of a RANDOM roll... again, very very bad design.

[EN]Excellent meta-coop game that does a great job at transmitting a  survival tension that is improved by the secret objectives and the ever-present threat of a traitor. The crossroad cards and the "Death dice" eliminate linearity and keep plays unpredictable. I would've liked for group leaders to have some sort of mechanic attached to them and for the box to include enough zombie standees instead of the less attractive zombie tokens

RATING: 8
I had the pleasure of playing a pre-release demo of this at U*Con in November, 2013.  Very immersive game -- I really enjoyed it! Great tension, nice narrative, good decisions, good challenges. Loved the independent goals + shared goals + possible traitor elements, and the storyline was engaging. Very nice game.

Everyone has a secret objective. Most secret objectives have the requirement that the group completes the main thematic card in order to win. There's a chance someone can be a traitor, whose personal victory requires that the group :lose: this major objective. In addition to the group objective, people also have private victory conditions (hoard as many guns as possible, collect enough science textbooks, etc etc) that don't always mesh nicely with the other players -- even if they're theoretically on the same team. So even when players aren't the traitor, they're not always motivated to act in the group's best interests (why share guns with the group when you need to be hoarding them yourself?). So it creates all of this crazy paranoia that's just delicious.  Definitely removes a lot of the staleness and "quarterbacking" that permeates other cooperative games, which is nice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a solid game but I can't believe its rated as highly as it is here on BGG (#19 as of this comment).  I guess I need to play some more to appreciate everything?  The traitor mechanic is nice but is not as well done as BSG, because of the individual objectives it is very easy to screw the group while making it look like you are pursuing your goal.  It also abstracts some of the things that makes zombies fun.  

The powers, combos, and tension are all top notch though and it isn't too long for a big zombie game.  I liked it a lot.

RATING: 7
Here's where I'm at with Dead of Winter. It's my kind of game. I like the sort of co-op sort of not thing there is going on. Having a group goal and an individual goal seems to work really well. I like that it feels a real challenge to survive, particularly whilst trying to secretly fulfil your own goal as well. It almost feels like you can't quite do all you need to, and good or bad fortune is going to have significant impact. I like all that. However I feel I haven't got the best out of this game as it doesn't seem to suit the people I normally play with. This game seems pretty polarising, and that means it's hard to get stuck in and get the most out of it, sadly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After several plays, it has become clear that there are some serious flaws in this game. Nevertheless, the overall experience is generally an enjoyable one, if a bit overlong at times. 

Dead of Winter has players managing groups of survivors in a zombie apocalypse, struggling against the hordes of undead, the harsh elements, and against one another. Mechanically, this is a competitive game where each player has a secret objective to complete in order to win. However, there is also a public objective which all players must complete, or no one wins. This has certainly been done before, but it works pretty well here as there is often tension between contributing to the main goal and helping your own goal. 

Unfortunately, there is also a “traitor” element that is also incorporated. The difficulty of completing the main objective is often so hard that it will be failed even with all players attempting to complete it. So throwing in someone who seeks to undermine it is very bad for balance. A single failure can mean a game loss for everyone except the traitor, and it can occur without even being obvious WHO the betrayer was. Even IF the other players do identify this player, doing so simply allows them to stop him from doing further damage. It does nothing to repair what has already been done and still allows the player to interfere in some aspects. Yet playing without the possibility of a traitor removes the suspicion of paranoia. If someone is not helping the main objective, you know they are just working on their own objective, not actually undermining the group. So it’s not the traitor element that is bad, it’s simply the implementation and balance of it.

The reason the subtitle of this game is “A Crossroads Game” is due to the system of “crossroads cards” that really add to the narrative feel. On your turn, the player to your right will draw a crossroads card, keeping it hidden from you. If you meet the triggering condition at some point on your turn, the card will be revealed and you will be forced to make a difficult choice, usually between doing nothing or gaining a benefit and penalty of some kind. These really add to the narrative of the story and help keep players involved during other people’s turns. Unfortunately, even their implementation often leaves something to be desired. Twice in three games we have had cards that required us to get a certain character to a certain location, risking the exposure along the journey. In both cases, the character was already at the target destination, but the rules made no allowance for this, requiring an exposure role for a journey to the place the character already was. Simply anticipating these common scenarios would have gone a long way towards making the game feel more immersive. 

All in all, I am excited to see what else can be done with the crossroads system, but I am hoping it is used in a game with otherwise significantly different mechanics. Despite the excellent presentation of the game, it still comes off feeling unpolished. More mediocrity from Plaid Hat leaves me to wonder if Summoner Wars and Mice & Mystics were just flukes.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.5
Overall enjoyable but I feel like it was overhyped. Need to give a few more plays to decide for sure. I like the overall gameplay structure and the crossroads cards. Not a fan of how getting more followers in your group are just cards or how vulnerable many characters can be to a hostile player.

It seems like most scenarios encourage you to send a single person to a remote location and camp there and search repeatedly for several turns. Not many interesting decisions early on, but some later in the game.

The game tries to play the grim-and-somber theme straight but the dog totally ruins it. Virtually everything you can do with the dog - especially if you activate a crossroads card - is comedic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The crossroad cards is probably the worst mechanism I've had to endure in a game. You draw a card and there is a slim chance that something might happen? But I guess it pairs well with the d12 roll,which is whenever you move there is a 3 in 12 chance of anything happening. Also the co-op part of the game is basic and boring as hell. So you have a boring co-op game with a couple of mechanisms that may (but usually don't) add anything exciting to the game. The only good mechanism in the game was stolen from Battlestar Galactica.

But this isn't a euro so the game doesn't have to be solid. It's about theme. The thing that bothers me most about the theme is why is there a group that trying to sabotage the whole colony? It...just doesn't make sense. And it's not like there is one bad apple who gathers followers to his ideology. The characters are always dying off and being exchanged for new characters but somehow this religious like fervor to destroy everyone else stays alive. 

And for a zombie game I would like zombies shambling about. In DoW they just kind of spawn, and stay, and never move. They seem more like a hurdle you have to jump over instead of a zombie you have to run from.

The only saving grace this game has is the artwork and the board layout is nice to look at. 

Do yourself a favor and spend the extra hour to play Battlestar Galactica instead.

RATING: 10
Tense, atmospheric, engrossing - these are words I would use to summarize Dead of Winter. The game is dripping with theme and story, and really lends itself to players involving themselves in the narrative. The unique characters are awesome (Sparky & Forrest for life) and really act as excellent platform for players to role play the story out. The components are well made and the art is nice and dark! And the game design is somehow just as superb! The secret objectives always makes players suspect others of being the traitor (and you just know they are, damn it). I only play with the traitor variant, which is how I highly recommend everyone else play it. It only ratchets up the paranoia! *mwah* Bon appétit!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I had hoped this would replace BSG, it did not.
This game simply does not work. But with all the hype, very cool artwork & droves of die-hard kickstarter fan-boys the game will remain in the top BGG ranks. 

The whole die-role mechanic is just incredible lucky.
The crossroad cards are okay at best, but feel poorly implemented:
Very often players forget to draw them, and then mid-turn the card is drawn & if activated complicates timing issues.
If it's drawn most of the time everyone has to wait until the card has been read, just to hear, nah nothing happens.. or the player keeps looking around the board to see if character x,y,z is present.
But since you don't have any influence on what card you get, it simply feels like a poorly implemented event deck.

Where BSG is all about finding the traitor/s, in DoW it's about haggling.. for one you can't be even sure you have a traitor & second there is no proper game mechanic to find out.
So since everyone is doing pretty wonky stuff to fulfill his secret objective (in our last game, one player shot his own character because he needed a wounded character to win) you never know what people are up to anyway.

So everyone is working at his own goals, and most often won't contribute to the team even though they're not a traitor.. and that doesn't generate a feeling of "us vs. them" but rather a feeling "of no idea, no way to find out, me vs. all.." so Player 1 won't do a task that needs to be done in order for the game not to be over, so Player 2 has the choice to either do the task, save the group but loose his chance of winning, or get closer to fulfill his objective and push the decision further down the line.
So because no one wants to loose deliberately usually no one sacrifices his win.. and then the haggling starts.. "okay so you wanna search there instead of killing that zombie.. how about i kill the zombie and you do that other thing..? That's not possible either.. hm.. okay.. so what could you do? Are we allowed to tell about our secret objectives so we can plan properly..?" No you're not. "Okay so we all stay secretive and let the game drag itself on.."

In a way the game probably depicts zombie shows pretty well, with characters constantly doing stupid things for no apparent reason.

I'd rather go to the toilet than play this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Sleeved

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
£30

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Brilliant and challenging co-op game, in which refreshingly the actual center threat are not the zombies (although there are zombies in the game) but more like all the threats, also common-day problems that could be threatening the survivors of the post-apocalyptic world, like starving, freezing (hypothermia), possible in-morale among the colony leading to possible conflicts, deceases of all sorts etc. There's a lot of problems to take care of, and at the same time you have keep on eye on the all of the zombies that might also threaten your colony. I like how the game emphasizes exploration, risk evaluation and true co-op decision-making instead of battles. Because of that it's also refreshing that the actual battles in the game are relatively simple. Game looks good, it has good quality components. It also plays fairly quickly, for the game of its size, it is really fast playing. 
And then there's the possibility of a  traitor among your survivors, a player who has a hidden negative agenda, who usually have to sabotage other players in order to achieve his own goal he needs in order to win the game. And it's never certain whether traitor is in play or not. Every other player also has own goal card which to follow in order to win. So yeah, game starts as a co-op, but in the end only those players who have been able to meet all the requirements of their personal goals win the game.
Game is not without its flaws. Sometimes it feels the game is too short in order to even have a realistic chance of getting all the things done that are required. Perhaps that has been intentional in order to elevate the difficulty level of the game. Still I personally found that a little frustrating. Also the fact that many things, even some crucial things, are heavily dependent on roll of the dice, is frustrating too, especially when there's a chance (1/12 chance) of outright dying when moving or fighting, because you have to roll a die  which have basically only bad things as results, and one of those 12 results can actually kill your character right away, no matter how fit or prepared the character is. That's really the biggest single thing I would have liked to be different in this game or even removed. 
But as overall experience perhaps one of the best horror-survivor experiences in a boardgame format you can have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Probably the best hidden traitor game. Maybe not the best zombie type game, although its definitely oozing with theme. The scariest thing in the game is not knowing who to trust. Instead of one player having a hidden role or objective, ALL the players have objectives to meet, but only one person is an actual traitor. So throughout the course of the game, players make shady moves or decisions - but it may not be that they are the traitor, its just that they HAVE to make those decisions because their objective calls for it. This game makes for an exciting, finger pointing game. Always a hit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Tight theme very fun to play. If you like the zombie/survival theme then this game will hardly let you down. Much replayability with traitor or coop modes and enough missions to choose from.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
BNIS

You might not have a 10/10 game each time, but overall the game delivers a 10/10 experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
AKA [i]Paper Dolls in Peril[/i]

[COLOR=#66CCFF][size=12]⁂[/size][/COLOR]

[i]"After we shoot the squatters in the McDonald's we'll drink the fryer grease.  Well, me 'n you will anyway—screw those other guys."[/i]

[COLOR=#66CCFF][size=18]*[/size][/COLOR]
First play was rough, as I was the betrayer (dammit!) and had no idea how to nudge things in the desired direction without looking fishy.  Providence lent me a hand with a disastrous "hospital adventure" in which two survivors perished (a vivid and memorable narrative moment), but after I dumped the first real turd in the punch bowl my poker face slipped and I was caught in a lie, summarily exiled, my objective rendered impossible.  Next time will be different... right?

[imageid=2266458 original]
Some crossroads cards are marked with a li'l swearing word-balloon to indicate "mature content", facilitating their removal for those who'd rather not endure potentially disturbing material.*  This is a neat idea in general ("Hey!  I can play this with the kids, and Gramma!") but the application seems haphazard.  The cards with the symbol aren't [i]that[/i] rugged,

[o]Why can't we have a debate about [i]smothering[/i] the baby?[/o]
and at least one card that wasn't marked has a truly horrific encounter with 

[o][i]your dead parents[/i]—one by apparent suicide, the other zombified and coming straight at you.[/o]
If I were lily-livered and that one popped up in front of kids I'd probably faint.  A note to the designers:  If you're gonna go for the jugular, get to it.  Hesitation marks evoke the wrong kind of disquiet.

[b]After 4 plays:[/b]  This gets a 7.  While the narrative moments are grand (last night we decided that exiles get their arms duct-taped to their sides, with a police whistle affixed to their mouths**—they get a boot in the back to send them staggering into the icy night, all a-whistlin' to beat the band) there just doesn't seem to be much tension.  Betrayers haven't been at all difficult to spot, and we've taken to exiling good people just to get the numbers down to beat a crisis or meet food requirements toward the end.  Hopefully this picks up with experience, but so far the few bright spots have been awash in a sea of ennui.

[size=7]*Seems ludicrous in a seriously-toned game about rooting around in the putrefying corpse of civilization while screwing each other over, but whatever.

**Because we were fresh out of air horns.[/size]

[size=5]NOTE:  Next time don't forget your goddamn reading glasses.[/size]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
You have no agency.  This a great 'game' for unintelligent people.  If you understand how the system works you can exploit it for a draw or a loss and you would realize most outcomes can only be achieved by rolling better.  If you are too intelligent to believe rolling better is an intelligence based skill then this is nothing but a terrible slog through a boring game.  Terrible game.  No redeeming quality.  Not really a game.  As bad as all those Arkham 'games.'  The completely contrived special objectives are obvious - you have the thinnest patina of a reason to ask for guns once you have some, or more food or more gas.  Take a step back and watch what the other players keep asking for and you see these asks are a revelation of the 'secret' objective.

RATING: 8

I won't ever play it with 2 players. I also recommend playing with high probability of a traitor. We didn't have a traitor in my first two games and, for a moment, I thought this game was not that good. In my oppinion there are much better coop games out there if you "take the traitor mechanic out" of this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A game I picked up on a whim, and boy was it a good choice. I would say I'm drawn to co-op games, but this adds a traitor mechanic akin to Shadows Over Camelot. What sets this apart from Shadows, is that not only are we all trying to survive the scenario,but each player has a secret objective that they're trying to achieve. So you have to decide, "should I help out the colony, or hold back and keep things I need to finish my personal goals?" But what truly sets this game apart from many other co-ops with a traitor mechanic, are the Crossroads cards. The fact that they can make each game a unique experience and will only be triggered when certain characters are in play, the player does a certain action etc. The crossroads can truly hamper or help someone in a pinch, while others require a majority vote on the outcome. These usually have people losing trust in one another when one person votes in favor for something truly horrible to happen...or where they really considering what's best for the colony?

The game can have a bit of complexity, but nothing that goes over even the greenest of gamers. I've been able to teach this game to fairly new gamers or people that barely play games and it has gone over well. 

When you see it, you'll immediately think "ah, another zombie game." But it's far from that. Zombies in this game is more of a looming threat on top of everything else the game will throw at you. Zombies aren't center stage, but if they get out of control then you're boned. There is so many different mechanics and things happening in the game, that makes the zombies just the icing on the cake. Great game, one of my favorites
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The individal player objectives add a layer of deception and tension in the game because you never know if a person if "evil" or just a fellow good survivor who wants to keep some meds with him cause he's a pusher - which is how I imagine post-apocalyptic world would be.

This is a thematically strong game complete with zombies, crises (e.g. blizzards which demand you collect fuel for fire, food spoilage which require food contributions, etc.), locations for resource-gathering (don't make too much noise or more zombies will come), and death - lots and lots of death. 

If semi-coop with a dash of competitive play and zombies are your thing, this game is for you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Three honest tries now, really wanted to like it because it's two of my friends favorite game. However the story element doesn't grasp me, the gameplay seems like there is not many options on a turn, and oh so long between turns where if I'm at the table or in the bathroom doesn't seem to make a difference. If I want a fun storytelling game I'll play Tales of the Arabian nights, if I want a long engaging euro game I'll play Terra Mystica, if I want an awesome zombie game I'll play City of Horror, and if I want a great betrayer hidden-roles game, Avalon still works great. Mashing all four of these elements together in a sub-par way just doesn't seem to work for me.

Update: Played again, this time with 4 (the other times were all with 5) and there was a little improvement due to less downtime, but not enough to change my rating. Will probably only play again if there are three players. Had more fun with a half-hour conversation after the game ended on how it could be improved.

RATING: 2
One of the very worst mistakes of my board gaming experience was falling for the hype and stupid reviews praising this game. Nothing you do in this game matters. Everything is just boiled down to anti-climatic dice rolls which completely determine the outcome of what's happening at any point in time. The thematic immersion that many seem to be praising the game for is rendered completely mute by the sheer amount of randomness and luck that drives the game. What's the point of playing a boardgame if nothing you do matters? If you like zombies just watch a zombie movie or read a book or play a videogame about zombies. Gameplay wise, this game gets a zero, the rating of 2 is for the good artwork and components value.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very unique game with difficulty based on luck and strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Delightfully duplicitous, this semi-cooperative game forces you to not just fear the zombies or freezing to death, but also the other players. Chose a survivor, complete with a well-characterized standee and individual powers, to pit against the elements from outside and within that conspire against you. My only gripe is the individual goals which must be completed by survivors - in addition to surviving itself, which is no small task - can create some intra-group conflict ASIDE FROM the betrayer.

RATING: 7
It's a fun co-op game with some flaws. I find that most people forget to pull a crossroads card during the other players turn, the personal victory conditions are silly, the frostbite side of the die is an auto death for the most part and I felt like there should be ways to upgrade the colony. I think rather than having conditions for individual players to win, it should have just been, traitor or not a traitor. I still enjoy playing but it has dropped down a bit on my list.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Storage

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is the only game I've played that truly lives up to its zombie apocalypse theme. A co-op game with hidden objectives and possibility of a traitor, DoW establishes that every player is out for themselves feeding into the inherent suspicion and human flaw of selfishness that is characteristic of the genre.

5/4/16 update: Game becomes tiring. My opinion would improve if you could share with other players. This feels like an unnecessary limit in a game about survival. Yes, it's also about selfishness, but it makes the difficult to balance competitive co-op more lopsided on the competitive side and any screw up causes the board to collapse.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
One of my design partners and I may have to abandon a project we've been working on for 3 or 4 years (sporadically) due to how incredibly similar this game is to ours, same theme, core mechanics, metagame, semi-coop, just unreal (talk about a bummer, but we did take too long) 

Needless to say I'll be picking this up...

Edit - May 4, 2014 - Holy Shit, read the rulebook, its like these guys sat in on one of our design sessions, its the same core game with some minor differences, just unreal. We started our development in 2009, my partner blogged about it a few times in 2011 but no where were major details revealed.... I mean an Apoc semi co-op game with a face up team objective, every one having a secret objective, a chance (here its about 45%, we were shooting for like 38%, unreal!) there is a Traitor, a Morale track, roll for exposures (working almost the same!), Crisis cards (ours were events but amounting to same thing), some of the same locations and item cards, and a few other minor things just incredible. 

There are a few significant differences too, but I'm not sure where that leaves us. Anyway its a must have game for us obviously and would recommend it to others looking for a meaty semi-coop potential Traitor game with good paranoia in it.

RATING: 4
Seems like an ok game but it doesn't really work for our group dynamic. Granted this was one play on what seemed like a fairly easy scenario without a traitor, but the game fell pretty flat for us. Crossroad system was interesting and fun but it was a pretty small part of the game the rest of which was a pretty straightforward affair. It was interesting how since we needed to kill a lot of zombies there were times when we'd purposely fail something if the only punishment was getting more zombies on the board. Maybe part of the problem was that we happened to get characters/items that made it so collectively the table could kill something like 10-11 zombies a round without rolling the exposure die, and if that were riskier there would have been more room for a traitor to sow discord, but it seemed like a traitor would have had a really hard time in that group. By the end we had all told each other our secret win conditions and worked together to make sure they were all satisfied before we won, which I feel like isn't supposed to happen.

RATING: 7
A very interesting twist on the zombie game where the zombies are actually somewhat incidental to the entire game play.  It is a little dice-luck at times, but good players can mitigate that effect with good planning.

After more plays, the dice is not as bad as there are other means that I didn't realize to mitigate your rolls and the exposure dice isn't as bad as it first seems.  This is almost a 10 for me and it may well be as we play with other players.

After a play with 4 and then 5 players, this game is certainly a 10.  We keep wanting to play it and the story that the game tells has been completely different every time.  The secret objectives are not so difficult that you are pulling against the team all the time.  We haven't had anyone be a betrayer yet, so we may make it a bit easier to have that happen.  All in all, this is a great game!

RATING: 6
The ease with which one player's character can die, combined with the ease another player can pick up extra characters can lead to a game which is hugely asymmetric in the involvement levels of players - One player having a lot of options and actions to do each turn, while another player can be done in 30 seconds and then having little to do for the next 20+ minutes. 

But there's a lot of fun in here - some on the blocks of text over hundreds of cards, and some on the traitor mechanic and the need to co-ordinate differing players' agendas.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is the first game I've played that I feel truly transcends the labels of "Eurogame" or "Ameritrash". It's incredibly thematic and uses some brilliantly streamlined mechanics (like the Exposure die!).

I absolutely love this game and would recommend it to anybody who asked, but I'll just lay out the couple issues that kept it from being a 10 for me:

1) Why bother including the "long" objectives? Nobody wants to play a 6 hour game. We played one accidentally and had to give up after 2 hours when it was clear we had at least another 4 hours remaining. 

2) The board(s) make it look pretty soul-less. It looks ugly and intimidating on the table.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Y5+
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This may just be the people I play with, but it also tends to be very static. I've noticed the game usually starts with several people leaving for places to loot and then sitting on that location all game. Some mechanic to force more movement might have been a good addition.

Having played Robinson Crusoe, I think the system used in Robinson Crusoe, as far as I know it doesn't have a special name,  of having events, some with decisions to be made, with delayed effects is much better than the Crossroads cards. I prefer it because: 1) the events or decisions just trigger when drawn, instead of requiring arbitrary prerequisites that usually don't trigger; 2) the effects appear more meaningful to the game most of the time; 3) and the use of a token to mark an upcoming effect from an event gives it a nice sense of tension, knowing that you're going to be hurt but not how or exactly when. That isn't to say that the crossroads system is bad, but I'm hoping future games that try to implement this kind of thing will lean more on Robinson Crusoe than Dead of Winter.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Super fun game! Ameritrash at its best. So many decisions to make each turn that will help or hinder the whole colony. Even without the (pretty awesome) Crossroads card mechanic, all kinds of interesting stories emerge through the gameplay. 

I do think it MIGHT be a little too easy for the betrayer to win right at the end, and I'm still not sure how I feel about the player order passing to the right.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great survival horror semi-coop game. Player elimination when you're outted as the traitor is great, meaning you don't lose the game on the spot and watch the survivors try to stay alive.

The hardcore versions of scenarios when playing without the traitor are really good as well and gives a nice way to play the game for people that don't enjoy the traitor mechanics as much. Depending on your group this might be the way to go as some people are just bad at playing the traitor and others just don't like the mechanic.

I won't rate games I designed. But, FWIW, I am still playing this game a bunch with my friends, even now that playtesting is done and the game is published. Read that how you want...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
2014-10-17

Initial Rating: 7.0 (October 2014)

Dead of Winter is certainly a good game but as many people named it “Game of the Year” I was expecting something a bit better. Still I have only scratched the surface of what the game can offer so I still have high hopes for the game. I feel it is a mix of Battlestar Galactica, with Mall of Horror and Robinson Crusoe.

The game rules aren’t complex and they are easy to teach, however the game has a lot of English text and due to the secretive nature of the crossroad system and the secret objectives all the players need to understand the language very well. That’s bad news for many of my friends. The art is GREAT and the components are adequate. I would have loved if the game came with zombie minis but the cardboard pieces are ok and they serve well their purpose. I think I will use zombie miniatures from other games.

I’m a big fan of apocalyptic and/or zombie themes so that’s another plus for me. However Dead of Winter, although in a Zombie setting, feels something more so I feel the game will appeal to people, even if they hate the zombie theme.

The secret objectives are great (although unbalanced), and along with the traitor mechanic and the crossroad system, are the best the game has to offer for me. They allow for very interesting group dynamics, even if there is no traitor some players will make weird moves that throw suspicion in their direction, or (mean) players could exile other players just because :devil:. Due to this, I feel this is the one of the greatest Semi-Coop games out there. Many games fail at this but there is real tension in Dead of Winter.

There is some luck with the dice each player throws each turn, but you can mitigate it a bit using food, and that also throws suspicion your way. 

Bottom line, a good game I want to explore further. It could go up in my personal ratings, but it also could go down as easily. I still prefer to play BSG over Dead of Winter.
 
Current Rating: 7.0
[hr]
2014-10-30

I thought the game was going to improve after more plays, but for us, it has become a bit boring each time. Now I feel the game to be exceedingly long for what it offers, it has A LOT of uncontrollable randomness (exposure die, cards, unbalanced secret goals). I’m downgrading its rating. As of right now, I’m trying to sell my copy but I will probably play it again in the future. My desire to play DoW took a hard plunge.

Still feel the crossroad system is great. BSG is miles above DoW.

Current Rating: 5.5
[hr]
2015-01-01

After even more plays I continue to downgrade Dead of Winter's rating.

The game is really hard to win so when there is a traitor he doesn't need to do anything exceptional to tank the game. This makes for a boring experience as there is no evidence if there is a traitor and he can attack at a critical junture when everyone trust him. This sounds great but here it isn't because the traitor is hidden not because he plays very well but because the game allowed him to hide without any effort at all. In all my games I haven't yet seen bad cards in the current crisis and this doesn't hurt the traitor in any way. 

All things considered, I only like the game's theme, artwork and the innovative crossroad system, however I would like the choices on the crossroad cards to be blind, that makes a lot more thematic sense. 

Current Rating: 5.0
[hr]
2016-01-12

Dead of Winter was a painful disappointment, I expected so much from the game. It broke my heart. I hope to never play it again.
 
Current Rating: 4.0

RATING: 8
my favorite zombie game. I love the hidden agenda, the way the game beats you down, and the crossroad cards make this game shine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It is a very fiddly game.

First, the objectives does an adequate job of hiding the betrayer, however it gives a false sense of ending game conclusion. If the colony gets overrun and you complete your objective, you lose. However if the colony survives at the end of the rounds and you don't complete your objective you lose too. It feels like you can't the objectives and ending game conclusion are very different.

Second, the encounter die shouldn't be here. I hate that this part of the game is completely random. Granted you can get items that can ignore it, but you seldom get these items because the range of items you can receive is huge! Also even IF you get the item, you probably need to spend it for the crisis.

Other than that, I love the encounter cards and how they can be randomly triggered. I love searching for supplies and trying to fix this puzzle of a survival game.

But it has a lot of blemishes, that prevents me from enjoying it fully.

RATING: 9
I hsve my brother to thank for this game... i picked it up just for his visit.
I have played this game twice now and have yet to win a game. I didn't expect much from this game and when I was setting this game up with my brother it looked incredibly complicated.  
Supriszingly though it is not that complicated at all and in no time at all we were having fun. This is a long game and you need to plan that time if you want to see the end. Although you can have some long down time between your turns, there is enough of a story unfolding to keep you engaged the entire time.
We would make up little stories about our characters when something happened to them.
After my first game I didn't know if if liked it or not...kinda the same way I felt after playing twilight struggle. ... But just like twilight struggle I couldn't help think about this game all the next day and found myself wanting to play it again
This is my brothers no.1 game!!! And definitely in my top 10!!!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
2014-10-01 - I needn't have worried about whether or not this game would live up to the hype. It really is very good. I've only played the first scenario (2 times), and it is a little on the basic side, but it's good for getting to know the game. It takes a little while to teach, but is actually fairly simple. The theme really comes across well. This felt a lot like Battlestar Galactica to me, but shorter and with more to do. I really like this one.

2015-10-04 - The shine has worn off a bit. I'm dropping my rating from an 8 to a 7, because the dynamic this game builds just doesn't seem to work for me. I think my group has had some trouble figuring out the betrayer goals. The good guys have lost way more often than they've won, but the betrayer has never actually won (despite frequently being the reason the good guys lost). So, more often than not, no one has won, which would be fine if we were playing Pandemic, but is just frustrating for me in this kind of game. I do have hopes we'll figure it out, and this game will go back up in my estimation. For now, though, it's dropping to a 7.

2017-07-03 - So, in the end, I don't like the betrayal mechanism in this game. It's too fragile, and just not very interesting to me. It feels like a hack to make people feel a certain way. Lowering my rating to a 6.

RATING: 8
Dead of Winter is an action-packed game that constantly provides you tense decisions, both as a group and for your own interests. The mechanics work well together, and the suspense mounts as the session progresses. As someone who isn't a fan of straight co-ops, I wish there was a way for there to be a clear winner; but the game is fun enough that this ends up being a minor caveat. I'm not often in the mood for a zombie game, but when I am, Dead of Winter is my drug of choice.

RATING: 9
The next evolution of zombie games: not only must you complete the scenario to succeed (a la Last Night On Earth) but you must also complete an individual one as well -- though there may be someone in your group who wants to betray you and make sure you don't win. Zombie arrivals are pre-set, chances of failure are quite decent... all around, this isn't an easy game to win but it's certainly fun if you happen to lose.

BIG PLUS: integration of different mechanics
PLUS: strong use of theme, piece quality, variety of options
MINUS: not a simple "right out of the box" game... though picks up when you get the hang of it

RATING: 6
Interesting game with a great, immersive theme. . . that gets old as the game wears on. Once the "wow this is cool" factor wears off, the same-e-ness of your choices - despite the cool Crossroads cards that add great texture and twists - becomes apparent. 

"Here's our next crisis card - it's a fuel one again. . ." Every round becomes an exercise in collecting a certain number of cards to avoid some crisis. The only difference in the events that occur is what kinds of cards you need to collect. Blah.

Wishing that something more happened as the game ramped up, besides just more zombies and more mouths to feed. This game just grows tiresome for how long it takes to play. Enjoyed it, loved the theme and the descriptive texts, but won't be purchasing it for the high price tag due to scarcity at this point.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The epitome of ameritrash games, as far as I am concerned. Tons of atmosphere that sucks you right into the world - you feel the cold and desperation as you play. Often a little too random, but that randomness is there to give the traitor a place to hide. I love how subtle the betrayal is in DoW - it's never failing missions or outright sabotage, at-least not until the Right Moment; it's not cleaning up after yourself, eating the food, not sharing, making just a little too much noise. This fosters the sense of paranoia that makes the game what it is.

Great game, always fun, never won it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
MG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very solid experience game. Feels quite similar to Battlestar Galactica in a number of ways, but most notably in the betrayal and crisis mechanics. The advantage this game has over BSG is that it does not have the infamous FFG rules bloat that makes BSG a huge chore to teach and a really long evening to play. Now that I have this, I doubt I will ever go back to BSG again. Dead of Winter improves upon it in almost every way, except for the tired theme. Fortunately, it does not play like a typical zombie game (which nobody ever needs more than one of, if that).

The rules are almost too efficient. In your first play, you are likely to come across a lot of situations that the rules do not adequately address. Be prepared to reference the FAQ (which is also pretty thin) and/or make judgement calls during play. After a couple of plays, you'll either find an answer online or a satisfactory house rule that stays within the spirit of the rule set.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good mix of theme and semi-cooperative gameplay. The first zombie game that isn't as stupid as its theme. While no revelation, most of the time players have real choices. The trade-off between individual goals and the common goal is interesting. Risking movement at the danger of being bitten, save items for future crises or use them now - the right risk management is decisive. Once a traitor is in the group, winning becomes much more challenging.

Many characters, ten scenarios and the crossroads cards provide replayability. Repeated plays in short time will lay bare the limited mechanisms but as a thematic diversion only every now and then Dead of Winter gains a place in my collection as first zombie game.

RATING: 5
This is one of the weaker co-ops, though I suppose if you like a zombie theme, this might do it for you. Its Battlestar, but BSG does traitor paranoia better. Its Robinson Crusoe, but RC does survival better. Its Shadows over Camelot, but SoCam does simple co-op better.

The mish-mash of mechanics is okay, if it wasn't so slow and boring on someone else's turn. The Crossroads mechanic wasn't as groundbreaking as I imagined it to be.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Requires the right group. Only good if the players are decent role players/storytellers. If simply played mechanically and robotically rather than for its story experience and social interaction, for which I'm sure it excels, then don't expect too many satisfied players.

Needs a traitor player who can play their role in an interesting fashion too. That player needs to enjoy stimulating some kind of fun-chaos in the game. It's absolutely no fun at all if the traitor behaves themselves through the entire game. The point of that role is to create an air of distrust, fun discussion, finger pointing and tension. Without that, our night ended with an awkward, bitter taste in the mouths of many when the traitor finally made himself known and annihilated our hard fought chance for victory at the last possible second. The game is certainly no cakewalk! On a side note, I just can't enjoy how fiddly things get as the game goes on. When more characters, equipment and items start coming out, things start getting chaotic and tedious quite quickly upon the tabletop.

But still, I can certainly appreciate the idea and its design. If played with the right mindset and game group I'm sure it'd be an absolute blast. But several games later I've lost the patience trying to discover that sweet spot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's okay... But given the choice to play a different game with a (possible) traitor, I would always opt for something else. The crossroad cards are a just a blown up random trigger and the choices they present simply boil down to making the mechanically right choice. Having the app only tell you the thematic choices (and not the consequences) is a huge improvement which shouldn't have been necessary. It should have been in the game right from the start. The individual goals hurt make the game susceptible to tanking, since there's no incentive for players who can no longer reach their secret goal to cooperate with the others if they can't reach their goal they will lose no matter what. The thing that one of your characters could just randomly die by moving is (imho) a horrible design choice. And ultimately everything else which happens in the game is rather tedious and bland... search items, fight, bring out the trash (really?!) Just not my game...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
I don't understand the love for this game.

First thing first: the theme is puerile. You know what? Dead is dead. Dead things stay dead. A game based on dead things moving about has a tall mountain to climb. Even if you are prepared to suspend disbelief in the second law of thermodynamics, zombies aren’t scary. They shamble about and fall over. Bits fall off. They are tedious and stupid. But in Dead of Winter it's relatively easy to get past the theme since the zombies don't really feature anyway apart from the mechanical whack-a-zombie routine at the start of each round. But when it comes down to it, zombies are at best not fun and at worst they're a reason to throw a game on a fire. 

It's confusing to teach, because there seems to be such a lot of irrelevant and random stuff going on, and it's hard to avoid pointing out the obvious: don't leave too many people in the colony, but if possible leave someone there who kills zombies without rolling for exposure, move as little as possible from location to location, and ensure that you barricade whenever possible. And if you draw new colony members, always make noise and draw again. Apart from this there's limited space for tactics and absolutely none for strategy. So the game manages to be formulaic while at the same time being chaotic and depending too much on chance.

Setup takes too long and is too fiddly for what the game is, there’s too much downtime between turns, and the game invariably overstays its welcome - which in my case never lasts more than about 10 minutes.

Why am I so impatient with this game? Apart from the stupid theme? Because it is overly dependent on luck. For a start, the powers of the characters in play make a huge difference to the outcome of the game. If you get characters with complementary powers, you will have a very different game from the one you get if you have characters with powers that don’t complement each other. Next, everything you do is subject to the roll of dice. The outcome of the roll can go from nothing to dead, and you have no way apart from re-rolling to react to what you roll and mitigate the outcome. Bad rolls have no upside, high rolls are have no downside. That’s not good. And if the player had some agency, the randomness might be fun. In this game, what you can do is largely determined by things outside your control. Games that depend on luck but give the player no agency are not going to stay on my shelves. 

I don’t like the atmosphere of the game. The traitor mechanic and personal agendas leads to suspicion between players. It also emphasises their isolation from one another, which is not lessened by any sense of common purpose. The game has never felt to me like anything more than a strange solitaire where the only common bond is mutual distrust. The game is designed to cause each player to mistrust the others. I don't enjoy mistrusting people, and mistrust isn't the place I'd start if I'm looking for a good time. Feeling betrayed is bad enough in real life not to want to look for it in a game.

The traitor mechanic actually breaks the game when the player knows what they are doing. Behave totally in keeping with the other players until very close to the end, and then drive the morale down to zero in a surprise move. 

In this game, collecting resources is a forced, mechanical rote, a dull chore. There are no interesting decisions. You just dig through a heap, collect resources, make noise, whack a zombie, roll a die, die. I find I can "meet with Triumph and Disaster / And treat those two impostors just the same" rather easily in this game. 

The crossroad cards are intended to give the game a much-needed shot in the arm every now and then. Unfortunately there is no coherence in the crossroad cards, with a startlingly wide qualitative range of possible outcomes. But that wide range is often immaterial since the cards are rarely triggered and when they are they usually have little or no impact on the game.

There's minimal story arc or sense of progress (or the lack of it) and so very little tension. The game is what it is from the start. I feel myself plodding stolidly through my turn, then waiting rather dully while everyone else plods through theirs. And hoping that it'll all stop soon.

Gave my Totterdown copy away.
Gave my Åkeshov copy away.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game takes some of the things that BSG does well and breaks them. By having players wait until their turn to do anything consequential, it loses the constant engagement and decisionmaking. Characters are disposable and too many rely on the "take an extra card" mechanic, so you aren't even really invested in outcomes because there isn't enough differentiation. 

I appreciate that it's shorter, but I wouldn't play a short version of BSG, either. The whole game is about doing the one thing your characters can do well until they get overwhelmed, so once it's your turn again, you're STILL not making meaningful choices. Totally unsatisfying to me.

RATING: 7.5
One of best coops I have played as of late. 

Concept of hidden goals is great and ads so much tension to game. Based on this and my love to BSG I no longer enjoy pure coops (without either traitor/hidden goals or one vs many or something with realtime aspects) so much. These more traditional coops feel too dry, are prone to analysis-paralysis and aplha player syndrome (and I must confess I am guilty of being aplha player too). 

Story is nice too, although I would probably enjoyed it more if it was not zombie themed.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A fantastic atmospheric game, this comes back often on the table when we have 4-5 players. Can be lengthy, and long to setup/manage components/play through turns with so many things to think about, but more often than not it is worth it.

A bit more bland without a traitor, so I highly recommend increasing the odds of having one (but keeping it possible to not have one). Lots of lore, good game play, meaningful choices - you'll never be able to have a perfect plan.

While the hard objectives looks like quite a steep bump in difficulty, after a few games I recommend using it - it is possible, especially without a traitor, to not be challenged enough as you get better.

Overall, a very thematic game I would recommend if you like managing a lot of components, like to plan out your turns in groups and optimize survival - but beware of those pesky traitors.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Even when there is no betrayer the game is hard and when the suspicions rise it becomes much more chaotic. The game definitely feels thematic and the atmosphere is there. My only complaint is the downtime and I use the variant with the one action per player until dice run out to solve that (each player takes little turns until they run out of dice). I recommend the game but I don't get why people recommend it to newcomers. If one of the player doesn't know the game well teaching and playing just takes so long a shorter better gateway game would be much more enjoyable. After this not hitting the table for a while it became previously owned. It is just too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
2016-10-09 - 6.5 - I played once the first easy scenario and there was no traitor drawn. Even with all that in mind I have some doubts if this game will live up the hype. It was fine, sometimes funny, sometimes creepy but it was not the experience which can be compared to the one I had with Battlestar Galactica. DoW has advantages over BSG, like playing time and lower number of players required to have a good time. But the gameplay seemed mechanical and was basically digging in one of the 6 piles of trash most of the time. The Crossroad mechanism is interesting, but not as good as I would expect and happened rather rarely. 
The game is not the easiest to explain as well, but maybe I just had a worse day.
Anyway I will try to play at least another scenario, which may add some spark to the game.
It's not bad. But I expected much more.
One more thing - I worry about replayability. If you know what the items can do and what Crossroads cards there are (or at least what kind of cards you can encounter) the game will be less surprising and might become even more mechanical, which is not a good thing in a such story driven game.

2016-11-15 - 6,5->6 - It's only ok game, but a big disappointment due to mechanical play. There are better games and I think this one is rather not worth my limited time. I won't propose it, but I can play it from time to time if someone suggests it.

2016-11-23 - 6->5 - I got rid of it. 5 is more accurate rating of my desire to play this game.

RATING: 4
Ugh.  Glad I didn't buy this one.

Semi co-op means everyone is grinding away for their own secret agenda and maybe someone is a traitor, but in practice it just makes for inefficient fumbling through a dice riddled card hunt.  Sometimes you win easily; sometimes you have no chance.

Thematically it's uneven at best.  I'm not entirely sure how walking to the gas station gave me such horrible frostbite that I died.  Doesn't anyone wear gloves?  The dog just blasted that zombie with a shotgun?  Weirdness.

Not sure about a random luck of the draw causing some players to have a whole army of characters while some may get whittled down to one.  Combine that with the occasional impossible secret goal and you have one fragile game experience.

RATING: 8.5
- 3-5
- Weight: Medium
- Genre: Cooperative + traitor
- Length: Long

Great co-op game with some cool elements that separate it from other co-op + traitor games. Everyone has their own secret objective in addition to the group main objective and if you don't complete both, you lose. With a large variety of main and secret objectives, as well as characters and random events, this game has a lot of replayability.

RATING: 6
Elég monumentális játék, sok komponens, nagyon történet- és hangulatközpontú, ötletes mechanikákkal van tele, minden tematikus, logikus benne, de azért elsőre elég sok dolgot kell megjegyezni, nem azonnal fogjuk átlátni a lehetőségeket. És gyakorlatilag ez a lényeg, aki szereti a nagy sztorikat, bele tudja élni magát egy-egy kalandba, és bejön neki a zombi tematika, az jó eséllyel imádni fogja... Számomra viszont egyszerűen túl sok a szerencse benne. Nem, nem azt akarom mondani, hogy minden a szerencsén múlik, és biztosan sokkal okosabb döntéseket is lehet hozni, de egy ilyen összetettségű és játékidejű társasnál én ennél nagyobb kontrollra vágyom.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Loved this game upon original purchase, and still love it. However, after more playthroughs, some elements of the game I have cooled on. The betrayer mechanic is great, but how the betrayer can sabotage is really uninspired. Instead of subtly tanking the game throughout to raise suspicion, all the betrayer has to do is wait until the last round and attract zombies, eat food, move, etc. Downtime can be long with more players, and personal objectives can also be very unbalanced. My first real thematic game though, which will always stay in my collection. Have great memories playing it with friends. If your group doesn't get into the theme, the game will definitely suffer.

RATING: 7
Another co-operative game with the potential for a betrayer. Players get all kinds of extra equipment and potential other followers in this zombie apocalypse game. Leveling up is always fun, and rolling the die to see if you get bit is also tense. I still have not played this game with a betrayer yet, so I may bump this up depending on how those games play out. As is, the cooperative aspect of the game has been fairly easy when there has been no betrayer, even if players seem to do fairly odd things to meet their largely arbitrary, and sometimes impossible goals (which I do have a problem with). As a strictly cooperative game it has some fun and enjoyment, but other games do it better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I usually don't get into overly complex and long games. But this one is just one you MUST  play for anyone into End of the World scenario playing. It's psuedo-coop, meaning everyone works together, unless you're the betrayer (randomly and secretly handed character goal cards), everyone wins if you beat the main crisis objective. Each round brings on a new crisis, each round you must feed the colony, and morale is of utmost importance. I've never played a game that weaves story telling, plot and scene setting like this one. If you have a group of board gamers, someone MUST own this game to bring out from time to time...

RATING: 3
[size=12][b]Top 300 or higher board games list[/b][/size]

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game:[/b][/size]
- I dislike the story-telling aspect of this game. I just want to play the game. 
- I dislike the amount of randomness in this game between the dice rolls, crisis cards, mission objective, cards you get, survivors you get, etc.
- I dislike the traitor aspect to this game. In my first game, the traitor failed to do anything threatening.
- I dislike how the difficulty of the secret objective cards varies greatly. I'd rather have decks of easy, medium, and hard secret objectives.  

[size=12][b]VERDICT:[/b] Not willing to play this game[/size]

RATING: 9.6

If you're into this kind of thing. This game may not appeal to the abstract euro crowd - it's more Walking Dead meets Werewolf. :)

RATING: 7.5
08-27-2014 - This is a good game.  But it doesn't live up to the hype IMHO.  For one, i think it's too hard.  Perhaps more plays will give me a hope that it's possible to win, but now it's just so many cards you need, the cards aren't incredibly easy to get (burns action dice, cards are buried in numerous decks, etc.).  The designers put in things to help you accomplish certain tasks (characters who can draw extra cards, other stuff), but it's just not enough.  It is just a slow death march so far that isn't as enjoyable as other death marches, like Arkham Horror for instance.  Perhaps playing with the sweet spot of players will help (3 or 4?)?  Perhaps finally playing with a betrayer will help?  I don't know.  For now, 7 seems too low but 8 seems too high.  7.5.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
As always- great expectations. It was said to be a psychological game. It is but in a way I hate- that is- if too little players work for the team instead of themselves, the whole team is going to lose. But if no one is doing anything and you're trying to fix it- you're going to lose. So let's even say players work together for shared victory and can play a nice cooperative game.

There are these crossroad cards (which can simply even eliminate one of the player's characters before he even gets to play one turn)- and they are supposed to be tones of fun. They are cool. Once. But when in three games in a raw you read the same three paragraphs about a crashing helicopter, it feels like watching the same movie over and over again. The cards are one use only, really. They would be much better if they were more generic, leaving more to imagine and less to read, also giving a player just an option with flavor. 

It also seems like every player has a team competing with other players' teams and every team has a leader character. Except the leader does nothing... It's only a name. Or our copy of rules is missing some pages. Also killing other player's characters will not work for you, so why the option? Just for the traitor? 

Some things and ideas are really cool here but we found the game to not work as it should. Everything semi-cooperative here just breaks the game. So if you simply play a classic cooperative game with a traitor, everything works fine- even personal goals.
