=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Only played it once, but I think this is just about the perfect zombie game, and the option for pure co-op vs. "I [i]think[/i] we're cooperating" means you can satisfy two different kinds of gamers.  Lots of neat little touches like indicators on the cards which should be removed when you're playing pure co-op, or Crossroads cards which might be objectionable for kids (uhh... you know, kids who are playing a game about flesh-eating undead).  Also, I like the basic mechanism of rolling your dice at the start of the turn and [i]then[/i] figuring out which ones to use for combat etc.; it's a little like Mage Knight, only without turns that take 20 goddamn minutes.

Update: the first time we played, it seemed like the Crossroads cards didn't really make much of a difference--but the second time, we got cards which changed our victory conditions, affected our food supply, and had some other neat effects, so it really depends on which ones come out.

Update: after a couple more plays, I'm sticking with the "just about the perfect zombie game" claim.  Our last game, everyone lost; we had it [i]in the bag[/i] until the last turn's crisis card came out.  The game before that, I was worried that I wasn't going to make my private goal before someone ended the game... then I [i]did[/i] make it (in what was going to be the last turn); then, as I was clearly happy (and the common goal had been met), someone called for a vote to exile me (just so that I wouldn't win), but it didn't pass... then that same person inadvertently hosed my goal... then through a stroke of luck I got [i]un-[/i]hosed, so it was a good emotional rollercoaster.  Tentatively calling this an 8, after adjusting for new-game-infatuation, but it could go up or down.

Update: two more plays tonight, both wins for me; also, we had our first Exile tonight (in the very last turn of the game), and it turned out to be the betrayer, which was [i]necessary[/i] for me, because exiling the betrayer (if there is one) was my secret goal (which I think is a really tough one).  [b]I thought it was great,[/b] tense right up until the last moment, but the betrayer said he didn't enjoy that game at all, because from turn 1 he felt he couldn't achieve his goal (having 4 guns equipped).  I didn't agree--I had [i]given[/i] him a gun early on, and if he'd played differently, I might have given him others, because I had more than I needed--so I felt like he would have had more fun if he'd seen his goal as [i]difficult[/i] rather than [i]impossible.[/i]

2016-09-12: yeah, sticking with "just about the perfect zombie game."  However, non-betrayers really need to understand that if they let the game end before they meet their secret conditions, [b]they lose,[/b] so they need to not let that happen.

Although this is a good game, I need to downsize, so gave to bjlillo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Not sure why everyone is so fond of this one. Seems overrated to me. The crossroad cards are nice, but that's about it. The ethical dilemmas that you get with them are stupid. The game starts of with a lot of tension but the tension definately decreases after a few turns. After finding a few good weapons, you can simply stay where you are and shoot zombies or search, without ever having to roll the exposure die again. Also, that die can be terrible when starting the game. Losing your two characters in the first round is no fun at all. Wouldn't play this one again unless there isn't anything else to do. 

Whatever Dead of Winter does, other games do it better. A lot better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
 Dead of Winter is a meta-cooperative psychological survival game. This means players are working together toward one common victory condition — but for each individual player to achieve victory, he must also complete his personal secret objective. This secret objective could relate to a psychological tick that's fairly harmless to most others in the colony, a dangerous obsession that could put the main objective at risk, a desire for sabotage of the main mission, or (worst of all) vengeance against the colony! Certain games could end with all players winning, some winning and some losing, or all players losing. Work toward the group's goal, but don't get walked all over by a loudmouth who's looking out only for his own interests!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Semi-cooperative, story-telling game. The goal of the game is to survive the cruel post-apocalyptic world, while achieving your own individual goal. The entrance barrier is high due to the amount of rules that need to be explained. A very interesting mechanics of this game is that a player may trigger a random event at any time of the game which will results in hard decisions to be made. These require some reading, so some English proficiency is recommended.

Replay Value: 4
Difficulty: 5, due to the amount of rules
Time: 60-120 minutes

RATING: 5
Some sort of euro resource management zombie game. There are a few interesting things in this game, but I think the game is pretty long, or we were playing too slow.

We hopefully could not finish the game. The first turn took an around 1h, the 2nd turn took 30 min. There were 4 turns left. I don't see how the game could end in 2 hours.

This is also the cross road cards that are pretty new idea, but for me it does not work. When somebody narate me some text in english, I don't see to understand anything. It also add much more down time because we need to wait for those narration. Finally, most decision on those cards consist in "do you want to take a risk or not" instead of "you have a choice between 2 important decisions".

One thing they could have done is to separate the flavor text from the rule text by placing the rule text in bold. So if you want to skip to the rule text  you just read the bold text.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
FIRST IMPRESSION:

While it is a zombie game, I didn't really feel the theme as strongly. It could easily be just an enemy out there causing issues. The cooperation while trying to achieve individual goals to win the game does add a bit of angst and intrigue to the game and can make anyone look guilty of being a traitor even if one is not present. I also really enjoyed the Crossroad cards and their effect and some of them are quite creative in nature (if a player yawns, they are sleepy and something might occur...).  Dice determine actions that are of any value and the 1 in 12 chance each time you roll the encounter die of dying is quite nerve-wracking...as well as when the disease can spread through multiple people at the same site unless one chooses to sacrifice their dude.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Con ayuda de los jugadores, Dead of Winter puede ser una excelente experiencia narrativa. Caso contrario, es un semi cooperativo imbalanceado con un alto nivel de azar.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
[u]Comments:[/u]
Dead of Winter owes a lot of it's design elements to it's predecessor [gameid=37111]. But, just because you are the illegitimate offspring of a genre defining game doesn't mean you have to be a retread of that game. Dead of Winter may be one of those rare situations where a great game is replaced on many people shelves by an even greater bastard child of a game. I have only had a few plays in so far but you immediately see the parentage in the design as you present with a dire situation for human kind that must face bad situation after bad situation with little to no signs of hope. After a few minutes those those similarities to its predecessor quickly fades and you find a wholly different game that branches off and is able to do just about the same thing as BSG in about half the time, and one that will not feel like it is the same game over and over again (which isn't necessarily a bad thing in the case of BSG). DoW packs a huge punch in short package. The components are top notch, although miniatures would have been nice (but in no way practical). The crossroads cards are pure dead brilliant and I look forward to their inclusion in other games by PHG. I do wish that the Crossroads cards didn't give what happens when a choice is made and then let the player decide. I prefer to read the opening paragraph and then give the player the choice, and then after they choose tell them what happens to them because of that choice. Makes for a better game in my opinion and adds a level of realism to the game that is great. Some of the objectives that requires multiples of tools can be incredibly difficult and I would like to have seen a whee bit more balance in that regard. But overall I think this game is a home run, and if you enjoy hidden traitors, adult themes, and lots of dramatic moments do yourself a favor and play Dead of Winter.    

[u]Comments Update:[/u]
After a number of plays with Dead of Winter I came to realize that every time I was playing there were moments where I would think to myself "I wish they had done this thing like they did in BSG." Or just flat out saying I wish we had played BSG. Sure DoW is really streamlined, and has the start of a GREAT mechanic in the crossroads cards, but it isn't nearly as refined of a game as BSG, not nearly at all. BSG really does do the hidden traitor mechanic by far the best that has ever been done. Every game of BSG would come down to almost the very end, and the reveal of the cylons were always a surprise. This just isn't the case in DoW, often the traitor doesn't reveal themselves at all. The Crossroad cards should have been designed differently, so that players didn't get to hear the outcomes of their actions before they made the choice of what to do. That is a HUGE design flaw to me, and I hope they revise that mechanic in their next Crossroads game series. Overall DoW is a decent game, I probably wouldn't turn down a game of it, and I don't regret preordering the game at all, but I it really can't come close to replacing BSG for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This was a hopeful purchase that worked out better then I could have expected. I had just played my first game of BSG and wanted it but I went with this because I heard they had a similar feel and thought the theme would work better with my group. I was right. This has been so much fun. Every time we play a story is created that we still talk about. I love this game and am always looking forward to playing it again.

RATING: 3
The Terra Mystica of Ameritrash: it's an overhyped jumble of the genre's worst excesses.

The game boasts "innovative" mechanics like Crossroads (just a random event card that someone else reads and watches your turn to see if your actions trigger it or not). 

DoW "solves" the inherent broken-ness of semi-coops by... uh... It simply doesn't. It's kingmaking in a box and expects you to just play along and read the flavor text instead.

Dig past those 2 issues and the gameplay is utterly derivative Ameritrash of the FFG/Flying Frog kind.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Disclaimer: I've only played this game once and so am not sure how accurate my first impressions are.

This game is very much a game of post-apocalyptic survival of lacking resources and braving the weather rather than a zombie one due to the zombies not actually doing anything unless they overrun a location, which I feel is much more realistic. Most of my actions were spent searching for items to avert the current round's crisis, and building barricades preemptively to stop the zombies is much more efficient than actually fighting them.

There were about 5 Crossroads cards that were activated in the game I played. They made the game much more interesting since you never knew what to expect (besides adding story with some nice flavor text). However, if a group got unlucky and didn't get many Crossroads cards to activate I could see them thinking this game is mediocre (especially if it turned out there was no traitor), as it does seem to hinge a lot on these cards to spice up the relatively long turns.


The action point allowance with the dice adds some variability of your available options to the game, while possibly allowing the traitor to sabotage the food supply without being obvious of his/her nefarious plans. I'm not sure how much I like them being tied with the number of survivors you have though, as going down to one survivor in your group is really debilitating both winning-wise and fun-wise. Also, if you get a few survivors early in the game you can just power through the game leaving the other players to twiddle their thumbs. With their much less effective aid.

The traitor in this game I felt had to be much sneakier than say a Cylon in BSG, as the items are labelled with the location they came from, so it is much harder to add negative cards to cause the crisis without being called out on it. The traitor seemed to have to take a more passive role because of that which might turn off some people, but the traitor in my play still had fun, and still had something to do when not sabotaging because of the secondary task the traitor has to complete to win.

Rolling the bitten symbol on the exposure is horrible but I don't know how else they could have made it both unexpected and unlikely (maybe they could have done something like the way Betrayal did the triggering of Omen cards, in that the first time you move, your chance of being bitten is really low, but each additional move has a higher and higher chance?). 

I don't like how they did the probability distribution of whether there is a traitor or not, since it is more likely there is a traitor with fewer players, yet I feel like a traitor is more manageable with more players. However if my prediction is true this is an easy fix.

EDIT: Hmm not sure what to think of this game anymore. My first two games were very memorable, but since the shine of the crossroads cards have started to wear off, and each game just feels like a slog of searching + some management of food/zombies, making the game feel like more upkeep than story. Also the game can drag, and a lot of the scenarios while having very different objectives have similar feeling paths to get there. I considered rating this game an 8 after my second play, and now consider rating it a 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Semi-Coopératif dans un univers hivernale Zombiesque. (The Walking Dead).
Jeu à identité secrète avec possibilité d'un traitre dans la colonie.
Les mécaniques sont généralement thématiques, les crossroads cartes apportent un aspect narratif au jeu qui amène parfois des situations tendu et terriblement excitantes.
Le jeu n'est pas facile d'un point de vue coopératif.

C'est un jeu relativement conséquent en temps de jeu, mais apporte une vrai ambiance post-apo-zombie autour de la table.

RATING: 8

RATING: 10
This and Zombicide, are the only 2 decent zombie games I've ever found, after decades of searching. Finally!

The way the mechanics work is simple and elegant, and it plays well co-operatively.  It has a good challenge level, so that you and your shelter-mates have to work hard to win.  

The only thing I find less satisfactory is the personal objectives, which seem a distraction and somewhat pointless, but that could be me: I focus on the survival of the colony.

I have yet to try the "Exiled" part of the game, though I came pretty close last time.  I look forward to that!

Excellent game!

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
New in shrink
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Dead of Winter is hands-down the most absorbing thematic game I've ever played. While there is a ton of information to take in at first, it's not very challenging mechanically once you've played a few rounds. The Crossroads mechanic adds a fantastic level of randomness, humor, chance, and replayability. The broad cast of characters are great, and I love the semi-cooperative nature in which everyone has a common goal as well as their individual goals. The action dice pool (a great mechanic!) lends the perfect amount of chance to everything. My main complaint is that it can be difficult to bring to the table because of its length and initial complexity, but with the right crowd it is always a top choice. A lot of people feel that the game gets stale because often searching is your main focus, so you're just doing that every turn and maybe managing zombies when they start showing up. I still love it, but I can see why the hype has died down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
high theme rank

100 minutes!!

One reviewer (https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1216628/dead-winter-review-or-zombies-are-soup-players-are): However, if you love games with a narrative element, add this to your collection. Even if you don't like zombies, don't worry about it. This game handles them the right way. They are set dressing. A threat that drives our motivations and nothing more. You aren't afraid of what the zombies will do--they are easy and predictable. You are afraid of what the other players will do. But more than that, you're afraid of what you might do.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
11/2014 Co-operative game with a possible traitor/saboteur.  I just don't like the combination.  In a co-operative game one should play together with the aim to accomplish something - then either win together, or loose together.  This game doesn't accomplish anything and just leaves the players with a feeling of having wasted a few hours.  It's way too easy for the traitor to ruin everything in his/hers final move.

RATING: 5

I have seen it crash several times with different groups. The artwork is really nice, the setting is convincing and the stories are decent, but as a competitive game the thing falls short for my taste. I understand that I am in the minority here, but what are ratings worth if you are not being honest?

RATING: 5
Not a bad game, but not particularly fun for me.

IMO, the biggest problem is the lack of random card inclusions when contributing cards to overcome crises. I really think the math of BSG works better in a hidden traitor scheme.    

I don't care for the luck-heavy rolls. 

Crossroad cards aren't my thing: I am personally not interested in reading the story cards, and it most of the time they are a hassle you can easily forget to draw; I found they break immersion in the gameplay to inject a random story, which isn't worth the tradeoff. As for creating a decision point, it does so, but not in routinely compelling way, as the decisions are usually pretty obvious choices of "what can we afford at this time?" 

In the end, I haven't walked away from the table feeling like something cool happened. Unlike BSG, I haven't gotten any stories to tell from our plays.

RATING: 6.5
([url=http://www.espacejeux.tv/]Espace Jeux[/url], 2014-10-11)

Dead of Winter is a survivor game and an alternative to Battlestar Galactica in the semi-coop with traitor genre. Zombie theme, lots of survivors, personal goals, and variability. It doesn't quite distinguish itself to rival BSG for playing time, so this is for real big fans of the genre. The game is ideal with Medium length main objectives, drags a lot in Long main objectives and is a bit too repetitive.

(Traded with [thing=150482][/thing], [thing=174152][/thing], and [thing=183785][/thing] for a gift certificate in the [geeklist=220998][/geeklist], 2017-02-23)

RATING: 7
The game is very well done thematically. The problem I have with it is that firstly the down time in this game is extreme and secondly(and most importantly) there is a huge bug in the game(although it can be fixed easily, and from now on we'll be playing it this way). The bug is that if you search a location A with a character X and find items I1 and I2 you can use/equip them on characters Y and Z on locations B and C immediately... what's up with that? We'll be playing it like this - all of your cards will be split among your characters. To use a card on other character they ARE GOING TO be handed off normally AND to contribute to the colony(food and/or cards to the crisis) THE CHARACTER holding those cards MUST be at the colony. That's the only way we'll be playing that game again. Then it could actually be fun.

RATING: 6.5

RATING: 8
While I thoroughly enjoy the game, it tends to drag on, especially with 4+ players. It doesn't always matter, but when you get familiar with the game, it gets boring when people have AP with the simplest of things, like where to build barricades or which locations to search. The crossroad cards are also a hit or miss, most often a miss. People tend to choose the path of least resistance, even if thematically and ethically it's wrong. Not everyone is a psychopath, but playing this they are. That takes away some of the decision making in this game, but it's more a fault of the group and not the game. Still, a worthy experience and even this version has loads of replayability, might be even better with the expansion, or the expansion as a standalone.

RATING: N/A
5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Short summary: A very swingy, luck based game attempting to randomly generate a story through tortured mechanics.  For the record, I wanted to like this game, sadly I could not.


What do I mean by the above?  Lets start with the luck factor.  Luck comes in multiple die rolls, the main one being the action roll and the exposure roll.  The exposure die is rolled when traveling is an instant 1 in 12 chance of death, additionally there is the possibility of frostbite which is a wound adds an additional wound every round if not treated. There are also straight wounds (3 wounds result in death - wounds are treated by medicine cards randomly drawl or by characters like the doctor which are also randomly drawl).  The exposure roll is also rolled when combat with zombies occurs (pretty much every turn) - unless certain randomly drawl cards are in effect.

The players Action dice, one per character plus one, are a pool is rolled every round together, and a single die needs to be allocated to preform a single action, that die needs to be hire than what is listed on the card of the character (e.g. search is 4 or higher while fight might be 2 or higher).  This can be mitigated by spending food, etc. to offset the luck at the cost of resources.  Typically 1 pip for 1 resource.

Depending on the scenario, there may be addition rolls required as well - our was to collect samples which happened on a 4,5,6 of a 6 sided die every time we killed a zombie.

The next layer of luck comes in the allocated characters you can choose from, and their abilities.  Some are very useful - like the solider who can kill 2 zombies instead of one per die.  Others are less useful like the lawyer who can look at one players randomly drawn card.

Then there is also the luck of the draw piles in the locations.

Then there is the luck of the crossroads card drawn each time a player starts their turn - these typically are targeted at named characters and come into effect if that character is currently in play rather than in the deck - though they can also be trigger events that occur only if something happens, like a character is moved from on location to another during that players turn.  They also usually involve a choose your own adventure type option choice of a or b - the group we played with used a rule which said the reader had to generalize the options and give as little information as possible about the choices and most importantly the outcomes of the choices to preserve the story feel. Clunky but understandable.

The last 2 bits of luck, at least that I recall, are secret agenda card assigned at the start of the game randomly, and the crisis card drawn on every player turn.  One of the cards in the agenda deck is a traitor card, in the game we played with 5 people, I think the agenda deck had 12 cards including the traitor, and 2 were dealt to each player.  This is where the crisis card comes in.  Each round it too is randomly drawl and states a certain number of cards of a type from the players hands must be donated to addressing it or some bad thing happens.  Cards are contributed secretly - and in theory this adds some level of dramatic tension as to if the traitor, if there is a traitor, is actually contributing what they say they are contributing.  In practice, we were crushing the game (thanks to luck) for the first 5 rounds, and then the luck in the 6th round swung against us causing a number of character deaths that dropped our moral to zero and lost the game. No traitor was needed at all to loose, and I suspect this may be the case pretty often. (I would have been disappointed with such an easy win, but I was even more disappointed with the reversal of fortune that lost a game where the colony was so far ahead.)  

One more tortured mechanic I need to add, players are allowed to ask each other for things like books or weapons, but players are not allowed to say which resources they have or who they would really like to give them to - I assume this is to help shield the secret agendas, and the traitor in particular, but in practice it is just clunky.  Once the card is asked for and received (a character can receive it no matter the characters location),   it must be played immediately.   However once the card is face up, it can be traded via handoff to other characters in the same location.

I think the game is an imaginative attempt at a random story based game that falls short on execution.  I also think there are better executions on it out there, and certainly for those looking for an involved story based game, perhaps I can suggest an actual RPG.

My 2 cents.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 1
This game has one of the best (if not THE best) components/art I have ever seen in a game! It is very thematic with the exception of(a major one that kills the theme for me) that not every character has cards, but they are shared... So you can get item (I) from location (L1) with character (C1) and give that same item (I) to a character (C2) in another location (L2). The major problem I have with the game is another though. The downtime is INSANE!!!! I mean 3 hours of play to do 5 moves that take you like 3-4 minutes? NO. Just no! I guess that is why they killed the theme with the exception I just talked about... the downtime would make me throw this game away! Another problem is that the token passes to the left instead of to the right (what's up with that?) and as if the game is not hard enough -> the bad guy should always win? I will be keeping It but I hope they fix all the issues with the expansion, otherwise It will be traded (I hope someone wants it) away!

RATING: N/A
Very good semi-cooperative game. Mechanics reinforce the theme very well. While it is a zombie theme, the zombie part is light and doesn't feel like every other zombie game. Possibly a traitor at the table. On top of that, there is a team win condition as well as individual win conditions, and both must be met for victory. Every choice is important, and acceptable losses must be taken in order to achieve final victory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really like this game. The artwork, theme, rich narrative, quality components, fluid mechanic, mix of co-operative play and the traitor element. The negatives are the lengthy downtime between turns, especially with 3 or more players; the lengthy rules expositions; and the random element which may alienate some tactical or strategy-based players. But there are ways to keep the game fresh and invigorating. Focus on the experience for your players. Expand on the narrative between turns with the players and raise the emotional stakes with regards to resolving a crisis. I guarantee they will be talking about the game long after the components are packed away.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The concept of a main goal with each their own subgoal and possibly having traitors is very cool. There are also some cool options for trickery as a traitor with the crisis card, attracting zombies etc. The survival game is slightly dull though with what seems just a game to minimize having to roll the red die. It's also a bit messy with the separate location boards and player stands.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3

Mediocre game that is only popular because "zombies"

RATING: 8
Beautiful. Such high production values, and entertaining writing. Reasonably long down time is balanced out by the tension of watching people screw up (or not) especially in the late game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I thought that this might be overlong, and that it had little chance of living up to its hype, and I was wrong on both counts. It's splendid.

While there's quite a bit going on, it's not fiddly. The theme is strong -- and a personal favorite -- and closely tied to what happens mechanically during play. The components are marvelous.

My first two plays were in the same session, one with no betrayer in the deck -- a learning game -- and one with a betrayer. The first was good, a 7 or an 8, but as a pure co-op DoW competes with more games I already enjoy, and it felt like it was lacking a certain spark. With the betrayer -- both before and after finding out we had one in our midst -- it jumped to a 9.

I'm iffy on semi co-ops in general; I almost always prefer full co-ups. But with DoW, there's a layer of menace and unease and tension that's both sublime and perfect for its theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
In my opinion one of best Zombie games

RATING: 9
DoW borrows lots of mechanics and ideas from other games but manages to bring its own twist and feeling into the play. It has many similarities to BSG but still manages to stand out as its own (especially with a bit shorter playtime which is a plus with most of the players).
The game offers lots of intense moments and multiple ways to play the game which helps getting the game on the table with different gaming groups.
Some people have complained about the downtime but it isn't nearly as bad as in most of coop games.
I really hope they will release expansions to the game and add more complex crisis cards and new challenging elements to the game (not that I have any complaints regarding the offering with the base game). Also the traitor mechanic seems somehow forced and doesn't add much to the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
Lot to say about this game, but not much is good.

Actually I should say "lot to say about this story creating box" as it is not much of a game and much more a randomized story being laid out in front of you.

Scenario 3 player

Shuffle 6 non villain + 1 villain secret objective

1:7 chance to have a villain which cant do anything until the very last turn or will get exiled and... Do nothing.

Then shuffle the character deck. Pass 4 to each player.

12 characters being drawn.. We keed 6 of those. 
Low chance you get the power 6 double searchers (one for each location) 

but still, if you can get the library double search in the begining, then get the blue prints ... You already won.

Maybe its the police double search... You won. (Little "tougher" but you still won.

You got the cook... You'll never run out of food.

Anything else is fluff with some of it really bad fluff.

Ok you got your characters... Lets shuffle item decks... So randomly shuffled that no matter what, all the same items are always in the same place... Just in a different order. So be sure to be real lucky to have shuffled it in the optimal setup because theres nothing really you can do about it later (except making noise... But that mechanic is as dumb as it gets)

*Side note - noise mechanic*
If you decide to make noise by looking at one more card and still picking just one but having to deal with two zombies instead of one, well... You like rolling danger dices for nothing.

Instead of making noise... Double search. Spending two dices in a search and getting 2 item at no risk (and spending another dice to deal sith the automatic zombie for your presence in that location feomthe previous turn) is better than speanding 1 dice for 1 item and having to fight 2 zombies.

The only time it comes in handy is if tou get the hell out of there by the end of you turn.

Crossroads... Only good for killing useless survivors.
Seriously ... Lose 1 moral save 1 can of food a round (most of the time) . Its a no brainer.

Accumulated cards in your hand stay there until you need them. Never pay a food if your reserve is made for this round.


This game plays its self out. You have no choice to make. None at all. 

So why a rating of 4?  Visuals. I guess it can be fun if youre drunk or not a really hardcore gamer.

Sad i bougnt it to say the truth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Tense game where things can go pear-shaped in the blink of an eye. Very engaging. Grade: A
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dead of Winter is a really cool cooperative game. We played with 2 different groups at BGG con. It feels a little bit like Robinson Crusoe, but take out some of the complexity/difficulty and add a traitor element. The removal of these things makes me like Dead of Winter MUCH more than RC. I don't think it's a gateway game, probably 1 step up. However, if you have a group of non-gamers that like a challenge, this could work. It's dripping with theme, is not too difficult, has excellent components, plays in about 90 minutes, and is a lot of fun. One of my favorites from BGG con 2014. 

Update 8/16/15:

Played this 2 more times with family this weekend. My rating is going to stay the same. I really enjoy this game. BUT, it's got a lot of problems. There's simply too many fiddly rules. Every time I've played this (4 times now), we are spending half the game flipping through the rule book. Plus, and even more damaging, turns take forever!! You only get a limited number of turns in a game (3-4 usually in a 4-player game), and you have to wait a very long time between them. Between my first and second turn (I was start player in the game), I had to wait a full hour. That's craziness. This game would be dead to me on that basis alone, but the theme is just so good. It's incredibly atmospheric, has great components, and offers a great cooperative experience. Mechanically, I rate it a 6. Theme is a 9.5. Taking the average, I'll round up to a 8. Just plan on spending 2-3 hours between setup, game time and clean up. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Very cool game, that made me wanna play again immediately.
Unfortunately I think the group I played the first game with didn't really connect with the game, but I liked it.

It's quite simple, in fact it seems like a mash of mechanics from other games, put together in a streamlined way. With the novelty being the addition of the Crossroads.

Being a simpler game is in no way a bad thing, just different and the Crossroads are quite interesting but definitely this won't be my final score for the game. I need more plays with different and the same group.

RATING: 6
Sold for $23 on Geekbay.
---------

Bought at Miniature Market Black Friday Sale.

The tension in this game is great, and the crossroads cards give a good amount of theme.  The traitor mechanic can be tricky, but I've seen some great implementations of it.  I actually enjoyed this more than I initially thought I would.

Multiple different scenarios, different survivors, crossroads cards, and multiple search decks really help replayability.

----

Update 1/10/16 from 9 to 6.5.  While the first play with Michelle and Daniel was amazing, it's fallen flat the few times with other groups since.  Mechanics are fairly simple, and there really isn't as deep of a strategy as I've become used to in heavier euros.  Lot of good replayability in scenarios and crossroad cards though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favorite coop games.
Very positive surprise... It's the best 'Walking Dead' game there is. Downtime vs. actual decisions made (most of your turn is just different dice rolls) is the biggest issue, but the game is worth some boring waiting and you can discuss strategy or share cards even if it's not your turn. I hate the red dice, but it's thematic and exciting.. I love the personal objectives (REALLY awesome in portraying the selfishness),betrayer,Crossroads deck and simple euro mechanics (dice placement and free actions). Artwork is ok, setup is very quick. Variability seems good too. It's just all around very smooth and solid game. 

2-Player Comment:
*Check out the Prisoners Dilemma variant by designer of the game. (Follow 2p setup, then give each player two Secret Objectives, one of which is betrayer - but if both betray then it's a loss). It's really awesome and makes 2p one of my favored player counts (best with two or three in my opinion, since there's quite a bit of downtime).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
A friend of my owns this game now and I really enjoyed playing it 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
This game is awesome, and has quickly made its way to my top 5 I could play at any time. The theme is really well represented, and the game has some incredible mechanics built around it. 

I mean, where do I start? 

I think the encounter die is brilliant (even if it may earn you an insta-death on your very first move... of your very first game... EVER!). 

The characters are very fleshed out, and the detail that Plaid Hat put into the diversity of them really shows.

Then there's the Crossroads cards... wow! Every time I've played this game I've discovered a previously un-triggered card. It's always presented my group with a significant, but rewarding, challenge. They add this ever-present sense of dread throughout the game that really heightens the tension. You may think, "Oh man, we've got all the food we need, the crisis is as good as solved, we're gonna knock this round out of the park!" then suddenly someone draws a Crossroad card that pulls the rug out from under you. This game really encompasses that old saying: "Life is what happens to you while you are busy making other plans..."

I didn't even talk about the betrayer mechanic!

If you like thematic, co-operative, games with a fair amount of tension, Dead of Winter is for you.

RATING: 7

RATING: 9
An amazing social experience. The zombies really only offer a background to everything else that's going on. Players must survive, but one of them [i]might[/i] be a traitor who wants to see the world burn. There's hand, resources and crises management. Players who are not a traitor have both a common objective and an individual secret objective that they must accomplish in order to win. Games without a traitor can sometimes seem too easy. The crossroads system is nice and adds some nice story-telling to the game, though some crossroad cards will inevitably end up being resolved a lot more often than others.

RATING: N/A
Four max
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Good
Great zombie themed game. The mechanics and art blend well together to make it feel like you are a part of a struggling colony trying to survive harsh conditions as well as a zombie horde. 

Potential betrayer and individual objectives is brilliant because you are never sure who you can trust. 

There is a large pool of characters that can be played and each plays uniquely further increasing the replay value of the game. 

The cross roads cards add tension as well as entertaining story elements that further help tie the theme into the game. 

Solid core mechanics, you pre-roll dice at the beginning of the turn and then can execute actions based off of those dice. The higher the roll the better the actions. So before it's even your turn you can pre-plan what you will do on your turn without random chances of failures. 

Bad
You need to be careful who you play this with. AP prone players will make this game drag out to the point where it isn't entertaining.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Cooperative masterpiece. Fired BSG, perhaps Eldritch Horror (except for those nights we really need tentacles). Mechanics are not too hard to grasp, one person who knows them can guide the others through a few turns and they will pick it up quickly enough. The meat is in the choices, the emotional tension, and the story elements, which can be fantastic. Don't let the zombies turn you off the game, there is so much more than that. It can fall flat if not everyone gets invested in the story or struggle, so the right group is important. I wish there was a mechanic to get more survivors other than random card choices. Have had several games where one or two people had all the survivors past the initial two; bad if its the traitor.

RATING: 7.1
Pros: 
+Fun overall. Comes together into a solid game
+Thematic decision making in the crossroads event cards is definitely the strong point of the game

Cons: 
-Not enough variability leads to low replayability. This game relies a lot on the hidden roles to make things interesting. The gameplay itself is pretty predictable
-Coop variant badly oversimplifies the game for the reason noted above. This is not a good two player game, which is mainly how I play. Coop game is very straightforward.
-The game would have benefited from miniatures--the cardboard zombies are rather lame and easily damaged when putting them into stands repeatedly. The components are generally uninspired and not of great quality. Not enough zombies are provided to fill the board.
-Board design choices are questionable--huge amounts of wasted space on the board (not even filled with good theme or art) while most of the game happens on small cards that are not on the board

RATING: 10
A fantastic game. Great quality, amazing replay value. Scaleable difficulty. Betrayer aspect is optional but is flawlessly folded into the gameplay. Crossroad card add infinite possible situations on every players turn. Tons of flavor texts and amazing art lend to this perfect co-op board game. It will have you panicking and blaming one another before the rounds run out or the zombies break in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Game in a Nutshell: Objective based zombie game of completing a cooperative goal but also a secret selfish desire.

Played as: 4 player

Pros: There are some very nice thematically integrated mechanics- how helpless survivors cause you both want to save them (to sustain moral) but also drag you down (consuming food with no benefit); how a bite can spread panic, and possibly the infection, among a group; cross-road cards that trigger when you might not be expecting it, inject story into the game.  

Cons: A lot of the character abilities are a deadly combination of being unexciting (even the zombie killing ones) and necessary (using what can be very limited 'action points'). The secret objectives were a bust. We all know we're each going to be doing something a little funky on the side, so who cares. The most disappointing part of the game is the zombies are largely passive. Without a strong spacial element, they never feel like much of a threat beyond being another resource that needs to be inversely managed. Perhaps that sums it up, there just wasn't enough to keep it from being another bland resource management game where the challenge comes from stacking those resources heavily against the players favor. I just never felt 'stressed' like I have in other horror (Last Night on Earth, where the zombies chase you down), Co-op (Pandemic, "someone needs to get to Asia stat!"), or hidden role games (The Resistance, where who is what REALLY matters).

Other: So the cross-road cards (what was supposed to drive the originality of the game)... At the worst they felt disruptive and tacked on. At their best, they were well written pieces of narrative that drove a story. That said, this is where I think the game will either succeed or fail. If your group can embrace the narrative, role-play a little even (not just the cross-roads cards, but the game as a whole), I think this game can succeed as an experience. On the flip side, as a break-down of mechanics, it's just not that interesting.

Best Use: A structured role-playing-esque game for people who want to play up the story.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Semi-Kooperatives Spiel mit einem sehr stimmig umgesetzten Thema. Das Material ist ansprechend und grösstenteils selbsterklärend und verfügt über das passende Design. Die Kartentexte sind teilweise nicht optimal übersetzt, was aber den Spielfluss nicht ernsthaft hemmt. Die Schicksalskarten sind mit sehr kleiner Schrift beschrieben und entsprechend schwierig zu lesen. Hier sind gutes Licht und Augen gefragt.  

Jeder Mitspieler "steuert" eine kleine Gruppe Überlebender. Das Spiel kann je nach belieben in einer kurzen (ca. 75 Min) einer mittleren (ca. 150Min) oder in einer langen Version (ca. 300Min) gespielt werden. Die unterschiedlichen Szenarien sowie die über 30 verschiedenen Überlebenden bringen Abwechslung ins Spiel.

Die Regeln sind eingängig und schnell gelernt. Die Spielsteuerung erfolgt über zum einen über Aktionswürfel und zum andern über Karten. Die Mechanismen sind ausreichend ausbalanciert, um ein gewisse Kontrolle und Planung zu erlauben, dabei aber auch durch die Würfel nie ganz berechenbar und zugleich auch nicht zu kompliziert, so dass der Spielfluss nicht negativ beeinträchtigt wird. So entsteht eine schöne dichte Spielatmosphäre ohne wirkliche Längen.  

Dadurch das jeder Spieler neben dem gemeinsamen Ziel auch noch eigene, geheime Ziele verfolgt, wird verhindert, dass einer der erfahreneren Spieler die Planung aller übernimmt. Zudem könnten auch Verräter unter den Mitspielern sein. 

Fazit: Bin eigentlich nicht so der Kooperativ-Spiele Spieler, aber dieses hat mir sehr gut gefallen und ich spiele gerne wieder mit.

RATING: N/A
8/8/14
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is exceptional. So exceptional that, when we finished playing it, my friends and I held an hour-long discussion about strategy. We then recalled our favourite moments from the game, and we acted them out as our survivors. Then, we excitedly looked through the survivor cards, noting how the jobs of each survivor directly relates to their special ability.

This game is thematic. It's tense, it's consistently fascinating, and it's thoughtful. The mechanics are strong, there are always exciting decisions to make. The game is cooperative, but it's also competitive, in that everyone is working for the group goal, and their secret personal goals. Everything about this game works.

Most importantly, and this is the point that I feel best sells the game, is that the game accurately recreates what it would be like to live during a zombie apocalypse. And it's a complete thrill.

In summary, Dead of Winter provides one of the best experiences that the hobby can offer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I enjoyed my initial plays of Dead of Winter despite it not really being my favorite style of game. The Crossroads cards were (and still are) the best part of the game, but I enjoyed the dice assignment mechanism as well.

Unfortunately, my impression of the game significantly cooled after subsequent plays. While the Crossroad cards are still amusing, every game (for me, anyway) has devolved into a somewhat dull exercise in set collection lacking much in the way of player agency or interesting decision points. I end up feeling like spectator, a problem I have with many of the games in this genre.

Finally, while in theory this game should be more about narrative than anything else, none of my games have produced much of a remarkable story. The Crossroad cards inject some narrative flavor, but by their very nature are disjointed from the stories of the individual scenarios and the other Crossroads cards themselves. Usually the events in the game are either fairly generic or simply get played for laughs.

I'd love to see Plaid Hat develop the Crossroads concept further and perhaps make a game in this style that's a little more interesting to actually play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
won first as junkie
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game. I would rate higher if it wasn't for the its bad packing. I will go over this later.

The lore is pretty well written, character design, item design, situations, and crossroads. I love that it has variants like 2 player co-op (it is pretty difficult) and it has an excellent replay-ability adding social deduction to the mix, missions and crossroads.

As for the packing it has no way to divide item cards for each location, crossroads, situations, characters, missions, betrayal, etc (there are a shitton of different cards). When packing you need to find a way to divide them otherwise the set up will take a lot of time. Once everything is set you will have a game that you will definitely enjoy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

On the basis of one play through with the family, a fun atmospheric game which I am looking forward to playing again. There was a certain degree of rules checking, certain slightly non intuitive rules interpretations, and a slightly dull mechanic of rooting through decks for the goodies, but on the whole worth a shot.

RATING: 9.5
I love Dead of Winter from start to finish. I've always been a fan of the zombie genre but my favorite zombie stories are ones that focus on the plight of the survivors. This game focuses heavily on that aspect - surviving in spite of yourself against the undead horde and your asshole comrades. The competitive cooperation makes it hard to trust players in a game where you'll fail without it. The art is amazing as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is easily the most over rated game I have ever played. The gameplay itself is flawed/broken but the theme and experience is okay...

RATING: 8
What a rich narrative experience! It's everything I have wanted from a zombie game - hard moral choices, where I must choose between personal self-interest or that of the larger group, risk management, characters I actually care about that aren't merely cartoons.

There is just enough BSG built into the system to demand cooperation and feel threatened by betrayal, but it is not the dominant focus. The story is the focus, and those crossroad cards are just fantastic at making things feel three dimensional. 

I think that if we don't over play it, this will become a regular staple of our gaming evenings.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game received rave reviews from everyone who played it at Cancon and as I like games with traitor mechanics and am very receptive to the zombie theme I thought this would be right up my alley. It wasn’t hard to find some other interested players in the games library so we borrowed a copy, set it up and got down to playing.

Initial reactions were that the game was a little fiddly with a heap of different decks to set up. The game played okay as we struggled to fulfil our mission. Morale went down when some-one didn’t take out the garbage and then the traitor revealed to make us fail a mission de jour task. Our guys through judicious searching (one seems to spend a lot of time rummaging through grocery stores which is realistic but less than enthralling) to get all we needed to set ourselves up for a win, but the crossroads card before the end of the game was not in our favour and a zombie broke into our HQ and ate someone making us all sad. Sad enough for us to lose.

Overall it was, I am sorry to say, a pretty ‘meh’ playing experience, lacking in tension and interesting decision making. For this type of game I would much rather play Battlestar Galactica or Shadows over Camelot, for real zombie fun I’d play Zombicide. Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game is not one I’ll seek out again and probably won’t purchase. In all honesty, once the ‘hotness’ wear off this game it is one I just can’t see being anywhere near as popular in two or three years time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
Friend has this. It's ok the theme is cool but the game play seems lacking

RATING: 10
Great Story telling game with great mechanics. First game I ever preordered. I got sucked in by 'Board With Life' play through and watched every video about it. Swept me into the hype. It helps that the game is amazing. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The traitor mechanisms (goal, vote-out, new goal) in this game are excellent, which makes this fun for groups of 4 and more.  I like the gathering of objects, the Crossroads events, the location item diversity, the personal goals, the fear of the tooth roll, and uncovering the hidden donations.  Yet most of the Crossroads cards rarely apply (thinking of limiting character-based cards so that they're added as the characters come into the group), and the crisis cards are terrible.  There needs to be more crisis cards since they change every turn.  And they need more variety in story and in impact.  A few of them stand out, but most lack imagination.  Perhaps this was needed to provide a stable threat mechanism, but the lack of variety really impacts play for me.  The cardboard stand-ups are fine, because there are a lot of possible characters to play.  Many of them have personality touches that are great.  Set up is really not bad for a game with tons of chits.  Great mechanisms here, but the Long Night expansion is really a must for me, and I still want more variety!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Battlestar Galactica: the light version

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A simple narrative survival semi-coop in a zombie apocalypse, with a traitor (or not).

Very simple mechanics, highly luck-based (dice roll). It's a game about the players, not the zombies (they can easily be anything else, including "The Thing" monster in the Carpenter's movie).

The game is fun, albeit not that tense imho, and the crossroads cards, being so random, add very little to the overall narrative - if the event is random, it can be anything; if it's linked to a specific character and he's not in play, it's a bit frustrating.
For us it becomes a bit more interesting if you must choose blindly the crossroad fork, without knowing the consequences.

Rate: :star::star::nostar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Schon wieder ein Brettspiel mit Zombiethematik?! *gääähn* 
Nein, aufwachen Leute, denn Dead of Winter (dt Winter der Toten) ist quasi The Walking Dead in Brettspiel-Form und mit Abstand das beste Brettspiel mit Zombies. Die Spieler übernehmen die Rolle von einer Gruppe Überlebender, während der Zombie Apokalypse. Doch die Untoten sind nicht die größte Gefahr, denn der Winter steht vor der Tür und Nahrungsmittel und Ressourcen sind knapp. Außerdem geht das Gerücht um, dass es einen Verräter in den eigenen Reihen gibt. Winter der Toten ist ein semi-kooperatives Brettspiel mit Verräter-Mechanik. Die Spieler müssen zusammenarbeiten, um unterschiedliche Ziele zu erreichen. Der Verräter 8sofern es einen gibt), darf aber nicht zu früh sabotieren, da auch er ein geheimes Ziel besitzt und sich vor den Zombies retten muss. So ist das Misstrauen nie so omnipräsent wie z.B. bei Battlestar Galactica, aber man hat die Möglichkeit immer im Hinterkopf. Wirklich toll ist die Crossroads-Mechanik, die bei uns am Tisch schon zu manch verrückten Situationen geführt hat (ich sag nur Kaufhaus-Weihnachtsmann und Show-Hund)! Wer auf kooperatives Spiele und Zombies steht, kommt um Winter der Toten nicht vorbei!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good game, dripping with theme (and a theme I like too), but didn't love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Incredibly atmospheric co-op/traitor game. The secret objectives are cool. The crossroads cards are a brilliant addition and add another wonderful layer of storytelling.

Plaid Hat
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Ok, I just played this game yesterday for the first time. 5 player game and to be honest, I really loved it. However, I will not give a 10 because of only one thing. When comparing it with City of Horrors, Dead of Winter really lacks the voting system and items card. 

Apart of this, it is a much superior game. However, I really like the voting on CoH. That is why I give DoW 9.5 and it doesn't replace CoH. It dos replace certainly Battlestar Galactica, but the lack of a voting system is the only obstacle for a perfect 10.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Puntos fuertes: Muy bien ambientado. Buenas ilustraciones. Las cartas de encrucijada y los roles ocultos le aportan algo extra a las misiones. Las historias/misiones están bien montadas. Es fácil de aprender, aunque tiene su complicación. Para el precio los componentes están bien. El juego está bien equilibrado respecto a la dificultad en relación al número de jugadores (no es ni más ni menos difícil). Tiene muchas misiones, así que tiene cuerda para rato.

Puntos débiles: A dos no aporta la misma experiencia. No puedes jugar con roles ocultos y las encrucijadas tampoco afectan tanto. Tiene bastante despliegue y, aunque no es tan relevante, solo tiene una orientación el tablero.

Conclusión: Juego cooperativo complejo pero fácil de jugar y de aprender. Sin duda mucho mejor para grupos a partir de 3, a dos se queda muy corto. Consigue meterte en el papel por la ambientación y la narrativa. El no ir con un solo personaje es un punto que le da variedad y posibilidades. Nuestra valoración de 6.5 es para dos, pero a 4 le daríamos un 7.5. Buen juego.

RATING: 5.5
My friends really like this game, however I'm not a huge fan.  The game is a coop game which each player has their own objective.

In playing it, if you are going to win or not usually coming down to the last turn when everyone is trying to do everything they can to complete their own objective causing everyone else to lose if they are unable to succeed.  Because of this, the end of the game becomes frustrating.

The game does have some fun with the various cards with humorous events and interesting characters you can play as.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Much to my chagrin, this game is better than BSG. The rules are clearer and cleaner and the play time is much more manageable. As a result I know this will get played a lot more. The traitor mechanic isn't as pronounced as BSG, in that it's entirely possible that there is never a betrayal, and even if there is that person might still need the main victory conditions to still be met. 

The Crossroads cards take this game to the next level, the narrative they present and the decisions they provide are very rewarding and give the game a real story feel. Can't wait to get this to the table again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I do love cooperative games and this game definitely scratches the itch.  The Evil player mechanic is cool as well.  I think it's been done here as good as in any game.

RATING: 9
I bought this game because I love the surviving part of a  zombie apocalypse game. There is more scavenging and managing resourses than fighting. Zombies are coming but it's dangerous to fight them. Dead of Winter is like State of Decay but during Winter :-) There are many elements what change at every game: objective, the presence or not of a traitor and the numerous events cards. It's a difficult game but there is a lot of fun at every game, even when all your survivors die starving, or are eaten alive by a zombie or (the list is long)

RATING: 5
I know I'm in the minority, but Dead of Winter is much more mechanical than story-driven. Stockpiling resources just so bad stuff doesn't happen isn't all that interesting, and you know exactly who put what in there, unlike BSG, where the game is designed to throw you curve balls. I think this game is false advertising also, because the rules as written don't make this game cooperative. It's everyone for themselves, but if you don't collaborate then no one is going to win. So many good ideas, but it just doesn't come together as well as it should.

Vastly prefer Battlestar Galactica in comparison.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The combination of cooperation game and hidden agendas creates a good level of friction between the players. Many cards are drawn and dice cast but since they are played afterwards, there is balance between luck and skills. 

That said, the mechanisms are not very inventive: roll a die, move and draw a card. The challenge is not to follow a deep strategy or find surprising tactical actions but to optimize the odds and there are better and simpler games for that.

Those who appreciate roleplaying games are sure to appreciate the colony's struggle against weather and zombies while tacticians and strategists may lack control.

Reviewed at https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1383185/why-i-love-you-and-why-i-still-divorce-you (which also tells why I sold it).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I don't get to play it very often and wish I had the Tabletop Day exclusives, but I love it for the mostly-cooperative nature of gameplay and replaybility. If you like zombie games, you should think strongly about this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Boring. Boring. Takes forever. More or less obvious choices.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This game needs the right group to play and be enjoyable. If your group doesn't like long pauses between each turn for example to read crossroads cards or the descriptions on the survivors cards to read their abilities, or texts on item cards, then don't waste your time with this game. All of these take time, and then add many other things you just have to remember, like adding a die for new survivor or counting the zombies before your move and then you say "stop, I just forgot to read the crossroad". Yes, each player spend a long time finishing their turn so if you play with 3 (which is the recommendation on BGG, there will be more than around 10-15 minutes before the first player get a chance to play again. As others stated before, this is more of an experience, like a movie, not a game you would like to play every day. You have to be patient to able to enjoy the game by  watching other players play their turn, talk about it, talk about the crossroads and plan a head. But if you find the right group, I am sure that you will enjoy every second of it,

RATING: 9.58
Almost every mechanism in this game makes sense thematically.  It's a thinky co-op with a brilliant secret objective based traitor mechanic mixed in.  The crisis system in BSG might make the game seem like it has less downtime, but I find myself very interested in every other person's turn in DoW, and the cards contributed to the crises themselves make more sense thematically.  I'm not into zombie games, but this game completely overcomes that aspect of the theme to me.  It's the best zombie game ever made.  It's the best traitor game I've played.  It has a harsh dice roll that just flat out can kill a character, but somehow it just adds to the suspense and fun for me.  That's a rare feat.  Well done, Plaid Hat Games.

RATING: 2
An ok game that needs a fix for preventing tanking the game as the betrayer.

I'm keeping both BSG and SoC since this does not replace these games for me.

A good supplement to the cooperative+traitor genre, but still not the perfect game in the genre that I was looking for.

Changed to a 1 because of this:
http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1256602/variant-prevent-betrayer-tanking/page/1

My experience of the game will now be associated with this thread, which kills the game for me. I didn't get the tanking problem fixed and my mistake was to assume that people reading my thread would help me out. Instead I was attacked by people loving the game and the designer for: "lying" about the problem. 
When the only people reading threads are people liking the game, this is what you get. Silly me :)

The designer was nice enough to write me back:
"I do care about your thoughts and criticism. If something I said implied otherwise I apologize, as that was not my intention.

I stated in a previous comment I did not think you were lying, I'm only trying to understand and help solve this problem. And to see what the problem is.

Again, I'm sorry. I generally stay out of these types of threads, and will revert to doing so in the future. I did not mean to make you feel bad, I only wanted to help. "

Which is very kind of him.

RATING: 6
This game has a lot going for it: crossroads, secret agendas, group agendas, relatively high replayability, different scenarios, a traitor mechanic that works sometimes, different feeling characters, and generally decent gameplay.

But I do have some issues with it: downtime especially at 4/5P counts, high swinginess due to the ease of tanking morale, widely different personal objectives that range from trivial to very hard, and some other nitpicks.

Together, the pros and cons become a wash, and its a decent game that I'd play but am not crazy about.

Plays: 6+

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
My impressions after one play is that this game evokes a real sense of feeling for your characters and the colony as a whole.  The mood is tense and the game very quickly puts you in a position that every decision is important and there is a very real chance that you can fail in your endeavors.  I had multiple survivors get killed and failed a crisis at one point.  The feeling of impending starvation loomed.  Morale in the colony was whittled down to next to nothing.  The storytelling elements of the crossroad cards added to the immersive nature of the game.  Teegan loved it.  Even though there were many complex strategic decisions to be made, he was caught up in he story and really enjoyed the ride.  This game surprised me by the amount going on.  Reviews and video run-throughs fail to properly capture the feeling that is created by playing this game.  It truly is a unique experience.  Because of the adult theme and the desperate nature of the game, this is not a play everyday type of experience and keeps me from rating it a bit higher.

RATING: 10
An elegant, flavourful survival game with true semi-cooperative objectives: each player receives a secret goal to complete in addition to the main objective (or, rarely, a betrayal objective, which is incompatible with the main one). The difficulty and randomization balance seems just about perfect, as well – each game is feels unique and perpetually on the verge of failure, but a well-coordinated group can handle just about anything. 

Exceptional!

RATING: 5
Make no mistakes about it, DoW is a eurogame. Yes, despite all that thematic flavour text and the great art, it is a very mechanical eurogame.

Contrary to what some people say, I think the zombie theme fits this game quite well. What I didn't like, though, were the "Request" action and the Waste Pile - those just feel clumsy. I mean, in a post-apocalyptic, zombie infested world are people seriously worried about taking out the rubbish?! Some people aren't even in the real world... Anyway, the actual thing that spoils the game for me a bit is the dice pooling mechanic instead of having individual dice allocated to characters. I think this pushes the game much further into eurogame territory than I enjoy as this mechanic really makes for bland, generic characters and considerably detracts from thematic values. This paired with the far too quick cycling of characters give the game a much more euro feel than it should have. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

PROMOS: [Characters] Kodiak Colby; Roberta Plum; Felicia Day; Rich Sommerer; Rodney Smith; KD James; Meryl Wolfe [Crossroad Cards] Lucky Luke Smith; Andrea Smith [Crossroad Sets] Dice Tower

COMPONENT STORAGE: Plano Medium Pro-Latch Organizer 3650

EXPANSIONS: The Long Night
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a personal favorite of mine. You and the other players control a group of characters in the aftermath of a zombie outbreak. These survivors are part of a colony, and various game objectives require travel outside of the colony for resources. A card draw at the beginning of the game determines one of ten possible objectives for winning. Each player also draws a card to determine their own secret objective for an individual win condition, and one of these may be a traitor card that pits that player against the others, unbeknownst to them. While the zombie theme has certainly been overdone, this takes nothing away from the fun of this game, and because of the aforementioned combination of objectives, replay value is quite high.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
[WrenniePennie's Copy]
This is an evolution in co-operative gaming. Plenty of diverse roles with some interesting strategic options; immersive atmosphere (even if some of the flavor text is a bit cliched); the traitor mechanic fits the theme very well; and the crossroads deck is something that I can see other games imitating. This is a diamond in an over-saturated zombie genre.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Dead Of Winter gives a very thematic feel to each play. The zombie apocalypse is well conveyed through game mechanics. Unfortunately, the game has several clunky factors that eliminate it from being one that I would consider owning.

Set-up and tear-down is an ordeal. Game length can exceed 2 hours. Some elements, specifically the Crossroads cards, never seem to fire off, making them a mostly pointless task. And then there is the possibility of a traitor in your midst. While this does create an atmosphere of suspicion, limiting outright cooperation, I would rather do without it. Personally, whenever I wind up the traitor in a game with such a mechanic it instantly ruins the game for me. Usually I am playing such a game for the cooperative aspect and now having to work against the group makes it a completely different kind of play experience, one that I'm not interested in having.

I'm glad Sean owns Dead Of Winter, as it is worth playing every now and then. It's his kind of a game anyway.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
A fun hidden traitor/resource management game. The is so much going on that an alpha player is less frustrating than in other games, especially for gamers who prefer lighter games. The hidden objectives also help to balance the alpha gamer. This bodes well for future Crossroad games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A co-op for players who enjoy Robinson Crusoe, and who (somewhat) appreciate the gameplay of BSG but not its extra-ness. It's also for those players who wouldn't mind a light dusting of Ameritrash -- one or two character-specific abilities and dice-based combat (but not so much that the experience descends into dice-rolling RPG-land or general drudgery [Eldritch Horror]). Importantly, in Dead of Winter, you roll the dice [i]first[/i] (this is now my thesis statement in explaining euro vs. Ameritrash). The plethora of scenarios and starting characters promise continued novelty value in complement to a streamlined character-based co-op experience (simple stats, straightforward game-losing conditions, few # of phases each round, customizable game length)-- with some engaging add-ons in the form of hidden loyalty, hidden secret goals, the possibility of banishing suspect fellow players, and a couple layers of booby trap every single turn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very inconsistent game - sometimes it's short, sometimes it's long, sometimes it's fun, sometimes it's not.

There are a ton of fiddly rules, and many of them, particularly item handoff or requesting rules and PvP combat, never come up.

Exiling is quite broken. If your group is cooperatively minded, you can break the game by giving all the survivors you find to the traitor, then exiling the traitor. The exile objective is usually orthogonal to the colony's success, and you now have a very powerful player, who you don't have to feed, who can trade with you to make sure everyone can accomplish their goals. Even if there's no traitor, exiling someone usually improves everyone's chances of success, which feels wrong.

That said, it's good for the same reasons Betrayal at House on the Hill is good. I just  want a game like it that's more robust to good strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.2
It has some mechanics from Galactica, but I would not say they are very similar. It is nowhere close Robinson Crusoe, but I see some similarities with Shadows over Camelot. The designers made a great work at creating a set of simple and coherent rules that work very well. Easy to teach, easy to understand, easy to play.

Most of the decisions are quite straight forward and lack depth. Still, it is deeper than the average ameritrash game. 

I guess most of the fun most be in the social aspect of the game. We didn't see that in our game, because we had no traitor; even if the social aspect in our game was limited, we enjoyed it.

It is certainly a thematic game, but  I don't see it as thematic as many people insist. I see it more as players trying to beat the game mechanic: you already know how many zombies will appear and where they will appear, you know the things you need for your turn mission and the numeric consequences of failing it, your morale level and how many morale points you can afford to lose, etc. For example, of you stay put at your location, you do it because you have 1 morale point and you don't want to risk this character to die and lose the game, and not because the character is afraid, or some other thematic reason.

Some people say it's very easy for the traitor to make all players lose. I can easily think some situations where he can do a lot of damage by exploting tight situations. I guess veteran players will be able to minimize this by taking less risks. 


Things I like:
-> Game mechanics: Simple, strong and fun.
-> Fluidity: Being able to roll in advance allows you to plan your moves in advance; you will only need minor adaptations depending on what the other players will do.
-> Duration: The designers succeeded at keeping it short enough.

Things I dislike:
-> Lack of replayability. Survivors have skills that define their strategies, they will always be played the same. You always get the same locations, with the same cards. I foresee games being very similar and plenty of expansions being published.
-> Lack of balance. There are shitty characters and great characters. One player can suffer a bad roll and stick to one character (and 2 action die) for the rest of the game. The next one can have one of these "draw 2/keep 2 cards" every time you search, and get up to 7 characters (and 8 action die) mid game. It's does not kill the fun,
-> I don't like having to read the effects of the Crossroads cards; it substracts to the theme. It would be much more thematic and intense to read the effects only after the player made the choice.

First impression [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/184429/item/3753236#item3753236]here[/url].
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Cooperativo con possibile traditore, molto dadoso. Questi i principali motivi che rendono questo gioco non apprezzatissimo da me. A mio avviso in 5, specie le prime partite potrebbe farsi sentire un down time un po' fastidioso. Il gioco offre diversi scenari per rendere le partite sempre varie. Inoltre ogni giocatore potrà controllare un paio di personaggi ognuno con capacità specifiche. Gioco da provare.

RATING: 6
Verdict:

What I Like: The atmosphere of mutual suspicion this game creates. The crossroads cards are the distinguishing feature, and they are fun. The artwork is fantastic. Everyone I've played it with loves it...

What I Don't Like: ...a lot more than I do. The actual cooperative gameplay lacks the brutal intensity and teamwork I crave. And if the difficulty is bumped up, the game becomes too easy for any traitor. If the traitor possibility is removed for balance however, the game loses all intrigue and becomes uninteresting. I wish the location decks were a bit more varied with the items they give as well.

RATING: 8.1
Robinson Crusoe should take note. Complexity is not always better. Story can be had without it.

After 4 plays I am a little disappointed no one has been the traitor yet. Because of this I have gotten to experience the Social Gaming side of this so much.
Also we played an easier campaign collecting samples twice, the first time the dice were being totally mean and we almost didn't win, which was exciting because i think it literally came down to the last round. the second time we rolled dice like a boss and crush it with time to spare, not as fun. Also the hidden objectives sound cool in theory, but in the end I just kind of tell people I am going to do something stupid to get my objective fulfilled, i guess with an actual traitor this would become more interesting. I am def. compelled to play this again, i feel like there is more story to give, more crossroads to read, more betrayals to occur.

RATING: N/A
