=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A very intense and deadly game! After my wife read the rules for the game, but before we played for the first time my wife stayed up late for a week putting together a soundtrack/playlist for Dead of Winter. One that was entirely zombie themed. When asked why she did this, she said this game is so scary with it's winter season theme and the constant loss of life and tough confrontational situations with other characters in the colony...this game deserved the right music for ambiance. 

The components are excellent and I really appreciate the bitter cold artwork. This is an intense semi-cooperative game. Each player has their own personal goals for winning. The game also has a goal for you to achieve or no one can win. It is super difficult living conditions in a zombie apocalypse. Food is scarce, morale is always low, moral questions will always come up. Do you take more survivors into your already struggling colony or send them away? Every game is unique and even if the same moral questions come up they may not be voted on the same way depending on the current climate of the colony.

Each player controls two characters at the start of the game. But those characters could succumb to frostbite or become infected and not survive. You will also probably be faced with taking on more characters during the game too. The simple task of traveling to any outside building in the town is so incredibly dangerous. But someone has to get some supplies...right? This game reminds me a lot of Shadows of Camelot, the difficulty of just traveling to a destination is a huge part of the game...and of course the Betrayer. Yes...someone in the group could be the Betrayer!

Before purchasing this game there was a lot of hype over the Crossroads cards. To be honest, they are an exciting element to the game, but only because they offer surprise choices and good back story to the game. I don't think they are incredibly innovative as some would have you believe. I feel like they are similar to the Encounter cards or Other World cards you might find in Arkham Horror or Eldrich Horror. Some crossroads cards you vote on as a colony, others must be decided by the active player. 

A difficult game to win. An excellent and intense winter survival zombie game, where surviving as a colony becomes everyone's goal, but individual goals are still needed to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
bagged
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
sb4/15,
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I think this is one for more serious gamers. I played it with muggles; I had fun, they had fun but we all had more fun with Pandemic and The Resistance. I think if you were more familiar with those games you would probably appreciated the nuances of this game more but for beginners that subtlety is lost. 

I would say too that while the art on the box and the standees are gorgeous, the actual play board is really bland and ugly; an undifferentiated grey expanse. 1 point off for that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
規則:
*圖板跟六個地點放置好(藍色圓片紀錄士氣，紅色紀錄回合)，選一主要任務卡並做起始布置，秘密任務抽玩家數*2加一個背叛任務，洗勻每人發一張，剩下的不開棄掉，危機牌庫洗勻放圖板，生存者/放逐目標/十字路卡分別洗勻放一旁，所有道具卡根據地點分開洗勻放置
*每人拿一張參考卡，起始道具卡洗勻每人發5張，剩下棄掉，每人拿4張生存者並選2張，剩下的生存者跟原本的洗勻，每人選一個當領導放參考卡左邊，拿對應腳色立牌放到主圖板右方圓格處，領導影響力最高的拿起始玩家標記
*遊戲進行數輪，每輪有兩個階段
A.玩家行動階段有三個步驟
1. 打開第一張危機卡
2. 移除所有骰並獲得1+玩家生存者數目的骰子，擲骰放參考卡左下
3. 順時鐘每人執行行動，動作玩家右手邊玩家抽一張十字路口牌，如果有動作玩家符合條件，念給動作玩家聽並結算效果，把骰子用完
>攻擊 選一個腳色配合一顆骰(擲要大於等於腳色攻擊力)攻擊同地點喪屍或生存者，喪屍直接移除並丟暴露骰結算，打生存者則擲該骰，骰值小於等於該生存者攻擊力，就放一個傷害標記並隨機抽該玩家一張手牌，不能攻擊無助的生存者
>找尋 在基地以外地點花一顆骰大於等於該生存者的找尋值，抽蓋地點物品卡一張，選擇保留或製造聲響(每個地點上限四個)來抽額外一張，最後選一張保留，剩下的放回牌庫底
>圍牆 一個生存者花一顆骰來放一個障礙標記到該生存者所在地點的空入口處
>清理 一個生存者在基地花一顆骰移除棄牌堆最上面3張
>吸引 一個生存者花一顆骰來移動兩個喪屍(任意地點)到該生存者所在地點
>生存者能力 需要骰的，需要比大於等於該能力值才能使用
>出一張牌 自己回合使用能力後丟到棄牌堆，裝備牌則裝到生存者身上，如果裝備者死在基地則牌回手，死在外面地點則裝備洗進該地點物品牌
>解決危機 蓋著放牌到(可拿生存者的身上裝備)到對應區來幫助解決危機
>移動 每個生存者可移動一次到有空位的地點，每次移動丟暴露骰
>花食物 每個花掉的可增加骰值一點
>要求 可要求隊友給物品牌，該牌不能加到解決危機裡
>裝備轉移 同地點可轉移裝備給另外一個生存者(僅能使用一次的轉移後不能再使用)
>投票 每個人可一次指定某人為叛徒並發起驅逐投票，平手看起始玩家決定
*暴露骰 : 受傷:放一個受傷標記，凍傷:放一個凍傷標記，每回合開始行動錢再放一個受傷標記給該腳色，咬:直接死亡，且同地點影響力最低的選擇死亡或是擲暴露骰，空白骰沒事其他骰面則死亡繼續由影響力最低的腳色選擇死亡或丟骰，有腳色死亡則士氣降1
*十字路口卡抽完秘密蓋著，當有玩家行動符合該卡觸發條件時打開念出，下方行動唸完後由該玩家選擇執行
B基地階段有七個步驟
1. 每兩個在基地的生存者(無助的也算)付一個食物，不夠付就都不付，放一個餓標記到食物區，根據食物區有幾個該標記士氣下降幾格
2. 棄牌堆每10張士氣降1
3. 洗勻解決危機牌庫的蓋牌，一張一張開，每張有符合符號的加一點，沒有的扣一點，總點數大於等於危機牌則沒事，如果超過玩家數2點以上，士氣加1
4. 每兩個基地的生存者(包括無助)加一個喪屍到基地，每個地點則一個生存者就加一個，地點的聲響標記每一個擲一顆骰，值小於等於3就再加一個喪屍
5. 確認是否達成主要目標，達成遊戲結束
6. 移動回合標記，到0也結束
7. 起始玩家標記右傳
*增加殭屍時一個一個加，基地照入口數字1放到6再循環，如果滿了但有障礙物，則移除障礙物根要加的喪屍，沒障礙物則基地影響力最低的死亡(僅有無助才能死無助)，外面地點放置規則相同，入口只有一個
*基地殺喪屍可任選一個入口位置的殺
*獲得生存者放到基地，如果沒位置就不能做
*生存者身上有3個以上受傷標記就死亡，只要任意生存者(包括無助)死亡士氣就降1，如果領導死亡就換人，最後一個死亡就牌全部棄掉抽一個新的生存者，移除生存者不算是死亡，不降士氣
*如果投票驅逐一個玩家，該玩家馬上抽驅逐目標來取代原本的秘密目標，且該玩家生存者全部要移出基地，該玩家不提供危機處理卡，不增加無助生存者到基地，不能花食物存貨區食物增加骰點(可出食物牌增加點數而不使用能力)，不投票，死亡不降士氣，出的牌移出遊戲，當有第二個人被驅逐，士氣降到0
*遊戲在主要目標完成，士氣降到0，回合掉0都結束，完成秘密任務的人獲勝
*投票時可先討論，倒數後一起出大拇指，向上贊成向下反對
*效果同時發生時，順序由起始玩家決定
***變體***
*純合作 不發秘密任務，主任務使用高難度面，不能驅逐玩家，移除有非合作標記的牌
*2人變體 使用純合作模式，起始7張手牌，生存者留3個
*背叛者變體 起始秘密任務數每個玩家1張而不用兩張
*高難度 使用主目標卡高難度面
*玩家減少變體 玩家死亡就移出遊戲
*窮徒模式2人變體 每人起始一張秘密任務一張背叛任務
>主要任務完成且兩個玩家都達成秘密任務則都贏
>士氣到0且有一個玩家完成叛徒任務則他獨贏
>士氣到0兩個都完成叛徒任務則兩個都輸
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Cull
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Feels almost like a roleplaying game, except that you have less emotional connection to your characters, of which you typically have several. They can die and be replaced by others. So in this sense it's less RPG, more board game.
I especially like the action system, whereby you roll a set of dice and then decide how to spend those dice, according to your characters' abilities. A mechanism borrowed from the euro genre, it lends a puzzly feel to the gameplay and is a divergence from old-fashioned RPG mechanisms (which typically revolve around you deciding to do something, then rolling to see if you're successful), and a welcome one at that.
The bite die adds an injection of true randomness and chaos to keep things from feeling too deterministic.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
STEPHEN.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The decisions are pretty basic - move to a location at your peril (roll a die), draw cards at the location (each location has a different mix so go where it's more likely you'll draw what you want), and push back the zombies at your location so there's not enough to kill you. The cool thing is that each game is different. Not only does the group have a new mission (collect this card or that, or do this or that), but each player needs to fulfil their own secret condition to be part of that win as well. So the priorities of what you're searching for and what you care about are different each game. Additionally, you'll be playing different characters with different specialties each game. So the attraction is not so much about the game-play, it's the theme and the flavour. The possibility of having to cope with the potential traitor (executed in Shadows Over Camelot style) adds some angst as well. I'm a fan of scenario driven variety, so put me down for more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A tight game and gaming experience. This may be my favorite semi-coop board game, yet. So much going on, but it all works beautifully. You don't have to like zombies at all to appreciate this game. It even plays well 2 players.

I think that what makes this game different is that any time the survivors go out into the cold or attack a zombie, they could die instantly from a bad exposure roll. The inclusion of this particular mechanism, coupled with the crossroads cards, makes the design of the game a breath of fresh air.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What an awesome game ...

Three games this year have really rocked my boat and have been three of my best games of the last decade nameley:

Dead of Winter
Alien: Legendary
Shadows of Brimstone

So many clever mechanics in this game, well,produced well,supported and can be played very well solitaire especially if you choose your actions first then draw your crossroad card then carry out the actions ...that way the crossroad card will not influence your choice of actions. A very simple way of making the game very solitaire friendly using multiple characters.

RATING: 8.2
At the outset this is an incredible looking game. Presentation is excellent - there are loads of parts and the options when you turn comes are great.

After a few plays though, you realise that although this is a lot of fun, there isn't a whole lot of strategy involved. Mostly this is because the mission design is a bit weak. Either you get a simple enough mission that you might be able to complete or else you get a stupid one you have no chance of achieving and instead of working towards a goal you just mess about, sandbox style.

While I think this is a much better game than Battlestar Galactica overall, the whole part of guessing who the traitor is is better in BSG - so BSG is not obsolete.

Downtime can be pretty bad between turns, especially if one player has a lot of followers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Dead of Winter is a semi-cooperative game in which players must achieve a shared scenario goal as well as a secret personal goal in order to win.  Players take control of multiple characters, which can be killed off (usually to the group's detriment) or recruited anew (which has a penalty), and they move those characters around the board collecting gear and fighting zombies.  Resolutions of movement, fighting, etc., was determined by die roll, which seemed pretty random to me.  The gameplay itself didn't really seem compelling.  The secret goals were a pretty good idea, but they definitely weren't balanced--some were much, much easier than others.

(4 plays)

RATING: 2
I'll definitely give it another shot, but so far I wasn't that impressed with it. The story telling was different and immersive, but the actual things you're doing aren't really that interesting. I also didn't understand with some of the crossroads cards why we lost morale. It seemed pretty damned beneficial to me to kick someone out that was infected. 

I also felt like there was a lot of downtime between turns. Not to mention the rolling of a d12 to see if you survive. I need to actually read the rules to this because I've heard it's not as brutal as that, but I'm really not that interested in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The issue with this game is that I never feel like I have any interesting decisions to make. The choices that you do have always possess a very obvious optimal ranking, and it ends up feeling like you're doing chores and never getting anywhere. 

Also, a competent betrayer can safely tank morale on their last turn and there's nothing you can ever do about it, destroying any progress you think you could have made. It's difficult to slowly sabotage things throughout the game, since each struggle or crisis is explicitly a win/fail affair—this means betraying is a binary action with no nuance and no real room for depth in gameplay. A lot of the time the betrayer's objective is so difficult that they may not even achieve it, leaving a game where everyone loses.

Even if the gameplay were more compelling, there are some really, really strong thematic-gameplay contradictions. It's optimal to exile the last player on the last turn before they can take it, even if it's less fun. It's optimal to take boring cards like the Mother and the Cook who just stay in the colony because they're extremely useful. The game's intro scenes and crossroads events are a mixed bag; some read as though they were written by fourteen year-olds, others are incredibly serious, some are frustratingly facile, some nonsensical, and others just outright comical. It's like the game didn't want to settle on a cohesive theme besides its zombie skin.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is my favorite game.  I was very hesitant to purchase this game as most of the zombie games are cheesy and overall not fun.  After one play, I have been absolutely hooked on this game.  The crossroad cards keep everyone involved and everyone loves to play a game that feels like a walking dead episode.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
The secret traitor mechanic fails in this game because the traitor can accomplish far too much in back-to-back turns. Many scenarios can be sabotaged with a single action, such as the "empty two decks" objective which can be sabotaged by a traitor killing off one of their own characters on the last turn of the game.

Successful coop-with-a-traitor such as Battlestar Galactica, Dark Moon and Saboteur work by limiting the amount a saboteur can do in one turn.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
(01/18) It was like my 5th board game, I've played it more times than it says here.

I love how people get engaged with it from the 2nd round, even on player's first play. Love the game without a traitor, so, imagine how much better it gets when someone is trying yo screw everything up. I haven't played Battlestar Galactica and I consider this one one of the essential games with a traitor dynamic and a narrative storytellling.

The Crossroad cards are incredible, add so much to the experience (PlaidHat said they were going to do more games with that dynamic, still waiting)

I will update my rating today from 8 in may 2015 to 8.8

RATING: 8
I finally got this game played at my most recent meetup for my local board game meeting. 

This is one awesome game with the right crowd. It was funny that the hardcore Euro players turned down the offer to play but fortunately we have enough players who are interested in more thematic games to play a 5-player game.

We played a short game and I think it was the right choice for a beginner's game (we have 3 newbies). 

This game has many good mechanisms mixed into it and the crossroad card really makes it feel like we are playing THE WALKING DEAD video game. Each choice you make affects the game differently.

We won at the end which was a plus in my book. I would like to play again if possible.

RATING: 7.5
The game mechanic 'co-oprative play', I came in touch through 'Pandmic' (like many others I pressume); I liked it and played lots of games in the same genre from the tons of co-operative games that came out in the slipstream of Pandemic. 
But after a while I became bored with this mechanic, as in there core, they were clones of Pandemic with some other some and twists that weren't exciting for me. Even the praised 'Robinson Crusoe: Adventure on The Cursed Island' couldn't excite me.

For the first time since long, I had a positive feeling after playing dead of Winter, a co-operative game. I think what does it for is the simple addition of the secret missions. It makes that while in the core it stays a co-operative game, it's not that sure you/everybody will win when you complete the common objective.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Played with 4 Players. No one in my group liked it. 
The main problem is the lack of meaningful decisions a player can make. The game mechanic is simple but not  elegant like in Pathfinder the Adventure Card Game. On your turn you draw item cards from different location decks, use the items somehow and kill zombies. When you kill a zombie there is a chance that you die instantly or  get wounded. Three wounds and one of your characters is dead. Well, just search for new characters in the location  decks. That´s the game in a nutshell. Lot of downtime for the other players. 
Traitor mechanic and hidden goals do not work well.
Maybe the game is better in the pure cooperative variant with just two players. I´m willing to try it this way.
Better coop games with traitor: Shadows over camelot
Better coop games with storytelling aspect: Pathfinder the adventure card game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
This is a brilliant game that is, at its core, of the Ameritrash genre, but with hints of Euro-elements that make for a very streamlined and fast paced zombie apocalypse survival romp. 

The story revolves around a colony of survivors that are struggling to survive a particularly harsh winter sometime after the zombie uprising and subsequent fall of society. Predictably, a la Walking Dead, the colony has fragmented into a number of cliques, each controlled by one of the players. Each game, the survivors have a different objective that they need to complete, while each individual player has their own secret objective as well that may, or may not, be compatible with the colony objective. And all the while, the zombie hordes advance - constantly pressuring the colonists and forcing them to fight and forage to survive. 

And if that weren't enough, there may also be someone lurking in the colony who's working to bring about the colony's collapse. 

The game's components are extremely high quality and the shear variety of characters, objectives, secret objectives, make the game infinitely replayable. In addition, the inclusion of the Crossroads cards keeps everyone engaged during other players turns and continues to keep the gave fresh and lively. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The traitor/betrayer mechanic saves this game from being a rebranded Zombicide-style game.  I like playing it and I find that the individual objectives keep the game fresh and interesting. Semi-coop is a cool thing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
15/06/17: enjoyable introduction to this - 4 player with DE, DE & DE:
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a game with a lot going for it:
- It has awesome multiple mechanics (a bit like Battlestar Galactica)
- It is very well themed
- It is immersive
- ...

Personally I feel the best part is how the co-operation mechanism has been implemented though.

DoW is a co-operative game in which co-operation is not the mindless "decide-together" typical of some other games like Zombicide or Pandemic, but in which individuals make the deliberate choice to co-operate (in full or in part) and personal and collective objectives (often at odds) makes choices meaningful for the player performing it, and ambiguous for the other players (even more so when the game is played in "betrayal mode".

My only [minor] gripe is that all games look alike, because the main mission/objective only plays on a couple of variables (stocked goods, number of barricades, locations...).

A thoroughly enjoyable game though, highly recommend it! :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Solid coop, heavy on the theme. Traitor aspect has not yet really clicked, as the role seems to be too hard to achieve winning condition. Has seemed a bit easy without the traitor, though.

RATING: 9.5
I *LOVE* this game. Complicated to learn, but the mechanics are so logical that once you have it, you have it. The complexity ensures that each game is different. I'm not even a fan of zombies, but the theme is so well put together I don't even notice I'm supposed to not like it. I can't wait for the next crossroads game, it'll be an instabuy for me. I really hope it's space, but I think I'll like it no matter what the theme.

RATING: 9
I first played this on Aug 27, 2016 with Kenny, Aldi, and Zach.  It is a game of cooperation against the zombie horde that seems to overrun and eat you.  It has a difficult learning curve, but it was worth it and we won our first 2 games played on hardcore mode.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a very well written hidden role game, where you are living in a town plagued by zombies. Each player gets a personal goal to complete, and all players have one common survival goal to reach as defined by the scenario. As you play, events happen that force you to make interesting story choices. One minor problem is that it's more fun if you don't know the result of your choice until you make it, but the game sort of forces you to read the resolutions on either side of your choice and make an informed decision based on repercussions. Death happens often in this game, and often it happens randomly because there is a die that has an autodeath face on it. You get new characters, but often this can be frustrating as you lose progress on your secret quest. There is also a traitor mechanic which can make things tense. overall I like this game a lot, but it might be a little too random for my preference.

:star: Art and components
:nostar: Innovative mechanics
:star: Handles 5 or more players
:nostar: Good with min or max players
:star: Low time between turns
:star: Comfortable complexity
:star: Re-playability
:star::nostar::nostar: Enjoyment
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
My son's favorite game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
This is a really cool game that looks great with the standees and doesn't outstay its welcome.

The crossroads cards are really thematic and add drama to the game.

Good communication is definitely needed to maximise player turns as the turn counter is quite unforgiving, meaning you have to get started on your missions from the get go.

Players are challenged to balance the mission, crisis, food supply, secret missions and morale which can create some difficult situations.

Can foresee the replay-ability factor being an issue though as each game I've played has generally followed the same pattern.

Would recommend, especially to lovers of the zombie genre.

Excitement 7
Strategy 7.5
Interaction 7.5
Balance 7
Replay-ability 7.5
Theme 9
Components 8.5
Value 7.5
Time investment 7.5
Player Downtime 7


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game has been a stable in my gaming nights and I love it. It's a semi co-op game with a possible traitor. The theme is based on a zombie apacolypse but unlike other zombie themed games, the zombies don't play a major role in this game. It's about the interaction of the players and the difficult decisions they have to make. What I love is the crossroad mechanic. It adds a lot of flavor and story to an already immense game. My favorite game of 2014. Highly highly recommended. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great theme and lot's of interesting decisions. Most comparable to Battlestar Galactica, but a bit shorter and with better theme integration.

My biggest complaints are the lack of balance in objectives* and the radical variation in difficulty depending on whether there is a traitor.

* There are two objectives which are by definition not balanced: one requires 2 medicine cards at the end of the game and the other requires 3 medicine cards. The other objectives are also generally not balanced, but the two medicine objectives are glaringly imbalanced.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
One of my most played games. I still enjoy it but I have gotten a little fatigued of teaching others to play. This is a  Coop push your luck type of game with a possible traitor.  If you can bring this to the table and everyone has played it about 3 times I find it starts to really shine. Stick to small player counts until everyone understands the nuances of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An interesting collection of ideas that doesn't really work as a satisfying game. I like the crossroads mechanic, which adds opportunities for story and characterization in an otherwise pretty mechanical game. I like the possible traitor, though other games do it as well. I like the way the crisis cards work, where you have the option of filling the need or suffering the listed consequences.
However, even if there is no traitor the game is punishingly difficult and there is often no way to mitigate the disasters that come up. In particular, I dislike the red exposure die, which has a chance of instantly killing a character any time they attempt a meaningful action. This is very swingy and frustrating, and bad rolls can easily make you lose the game regardless of what you do. The way you find extra characters in the search decks is also problematic, since you don't get to make a choice about it. You just automatically have to take the new character. It would have been much more interesting and gamelike if there was a choice to make about whether to recruit them when you find them. As is, these two mechanics can lead to vast differences in power and ability between players over the course of the game, and sometimes getting stuck with extra characters can make you lose when you would otherwise win.
Overall, it just feels like more of a story generator than a game, because of limited decisions and very swingy dice and card draws. And most of the stories are "You die horribly and there was nothing you could have done about it."
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Holy sweet Moses this was fun. Tense, exciting, stressful. We used the app for atmosphere and to read crossroads cards.

RATING: 9
One of my go-to cooperative games!
This game is fascinating because the zombies and theme are a backdrop to how well you can function as a group and the social paranoia that ensues when you start thinking there might be a traitor amongst you.
It's a mind game of human nature as much as it is a survival experience. 
Fun scenarios, awesome Crossroads mechanic that brings character to each game you play.
A top shelf game and rightly so!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I was expecting something along the lines of Battlestar Galactica but instead got Betrayal House on the Hill. Not much there strategically. However, the game manages to get the spirit and the theme of a zombie move into a game through those Crossroad cards, which are merely event cards with narrative text on them.

One thing I didn't particularly liked: players can gain more people in their faction/entourage to control. Unfortunately, this is all luck-based. So if you have only one or two characters to control while others have five or more, then bad die rolls hurt you more, and there is much less interesting things you can do on your turn.

UPDATE: We made a serious rules error: You are not obligated to play event cards (in particular, those that give you new characters) immediately. This enables you to give these cards to other players, or save them up for later. However, I don't think my rating will change despite this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After much research,  I recognize this as more a story telling game and not just a traitor one. Like many of my favorites with the meta game,  this game is focused more on the experience than a clear victory.   You won't enjoy the game looking for the win.   After I realized that,  I liked it a good bit more.   However, there is not enough time in the game to realize a vision like that.  The personal goals are too clunky.  There is never a time that I would want this over Shadows Over Camelot for either new people or gamers

RATING: 4
A clever game with cool ideas, but one that hails from the Arkham Horror school of design where the game mostly plays itself and player input is just incidental. 
 
The game is heavily reliant on random chance for both play and narrative. Characters can and will die at the roll of the die if you attempt to use them in any respect, and the story telling frequently makes no sense.

Still, if Zombie games are your thing and you don't mind a 30+ minute rules explanation, you could do a lot worse.

RATING: 8

There are some pretty wild swings of luck, so sometimes the scenario will be a cakewalk or totally destroy us, but players always have a choice in how things play out. Overall, I love the way this game inspires suspense. A rare occurrence where a games quirks/"flaws" can actually enhance the gaming experience. Possibly brilliant.

RATING: 9.5
Played two times so far, and both left us exhausted in the best possible way. The theme really comes through. I'm not even a big fan of zombie-centric pop culture, but the tension and story kept me engaged. I like the Crossroads mechanism quite a bit, though my group kept forgetting to draw the cards.

My only complaint so far is that even the short scenarios are pretty long--although I'm sure play time will shorten a bit as we grow more familiar with the game.

**Edited to add: I've played it a few more times now, and wow, this game is amazing. A day or two after you play it you find yourself telling each other the story of what happened--who tragically died too soon, who took a foolish risk and got someone killed, who turned into a ninja badass with a sniper rifle. Takes a bit of time to teach, but totally worth it. Leaves people itching to play again.** 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm not a huge "Zombie" guy, and I don't watch "The walking dead", but I like this game quite a lot.

What I like about this game :

- the crossroads cards add tremendous amounts of theme and there are a ton of them.  They can be highly specific so some don't often get used, but when they do its so immersive.  I love it when someone is taking there turn and the player to their right says, "hold up one moment".

- Great component quality.  The art is good, the thick cardboard stand ups are fun and make the game look appealing.

- the ability to customize it so there is a "no traitor" version of the game.  Personally, I think the traitor mechanic is fun - and typically we play it that way.  However, my wife is not a fan of traitor mechanics in games.  The ability to flip the objective card to the "hard" side and not use the traitor was genius.  It will totally allow me to play this game with her that otherwise I liekly wouldn't be able to.

- in the same vein, it's nice the creators made a symbol on the crossroads cards that indicate some of the more "adult themed" cards.  If you are playing with a 12 year old, it lets you as a parent easily find the cards that you might feel uncomfortable playing with and remove them.  Since there are so many crossroads cards, you won't miss them much.  That being said, I *do* often play with a 12 year old and I haven't come across any cards I find problematic so we use them all.  Still, nice to have options for other folks.

As far as negatives go, I don't have any stand out issues with this game so far.  I will update if I find any as I continue to play the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Snooze. This game virtually plays itself and has a lot of bookkeeping, downtime and randomness.

Move somewhere and do something obvious *then wait for your next turn*. Stay stationary and do something obvious *then wait for your next turn*. Discover a medikit, so share it with a player who has injury tokens *then wait for your next turn*. Etc etc.

After four plays, I'm dropping its score from 6 to 5.

Table conversation seems to be 95% dull checking (i.e. "Between us, do we now have all items we need in our hands?") and only 5% interesting deduction etc. One player may dominate.

Its two main innovations do add 'spice' to the game but detract from it in other ways:
- The crossroad cards and other cards add flavour but also add many interruptions while text is being read.
- Hidden player objectives for all players, in addition to a possible traitor, should be cool. But they add too much fog/noise, almost reducing the hunt for a traitor to guesswork. The way turn order changes means a traitor usually just waits until they get two turns in a row and saboutages things at that point.

The similar, older Battlestar Galactica game has a more satisfying/deductive 'find the traitor' mechanism (provided you have a good memory for who's played what cards). I'm surprised Dead of Winter seems more popular.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic game that offers a variety of scenarios to suit play time, anywhere from 45 minutes to hours of gaming.

The game is easy to teach in a short time, and with a few organizers, is quick to set up and put away.

Even better if you pick up a pack of Zombicide's extra zombie minis for it.

The only downside to the game is that the default setup always has the chance for a traitor, but the chance can be rather slim, especially in a 5 player game, with 10 standard objectives mixed in with the single chance for a traitor. We've started playing with the standard setup - 3 or 4 non-traitor cards for a game with more paranoia and excitement.

RATING: 4
I should like this game.

It does have solid mechanics and the materials quality is pretty good - both big pluses.

It's co-op, which I'm fine with playing. It has resource management, which I love. It has figures (card, but still) which I like. It has a possible traitor element, which I normally revel in.

Yet, there's something I really just don't like with this game. I can normally give a much better justification as to why I mark down a game, but I can't with this one - I just don't like it.

RATING: 7
02-12-2014. Sold after 7 plays. Dead of Winter remained mixed. Some games I loved, some games fell a little flat. Ultimately, I noticed that I got a bit bummed out by the game. I still like it and would play it, but I am not running around in circles thinking the game is fantastic. I think I like the Cylon hunting in BSG or Resistance better.

06-09-2014. Rated after 3 plays. Dead of Winter is the little brother of Battlestar Galactica and Tales of Arabian Nights. Situated in a zombie-environment you play a bunch of characters trying to survive a zombie-holocaust, while coming out on top yourself. DoW is a semi-cooperative game, with hidden goals and a potential traitor. 

So far, my experiences with DoW are a little mixed. When the game works, it's a great experience. But if the cooperative scenario is too easy and there is no traitor, the game feels a little meek. There is no BSG like tension of knowing there is a cylon, and if the cooperative game doesn't push you to your limits basically everyone wins a relatively tension free game.

However, when there is a traitor, it becomes a very fun game. My 8 score reflects the fun during a good game (9), to the more boring cooperative scenario with too easy characters (7). I think I'll play with X+1 cards from now on, to increase traitor chances.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Overhyped, repetitive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Disappointing.  I played this once at BGG.CON 14, and did not care for it.  The downtime between turns was extremely long.  It just didn't click for me and wife at all.  I'd give it one more try just to make sure that I am not off base, but I am super glad I didn't buy this before I played.  Hype avoided!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This game has way too obvious of decisions to be made, especially if you get a hidden goal card that is pretty much not what anybody else is doing so the entire game you pretty much have to do the same action over and over and over again (I played twice, one of them was have a bunch of barricades built in the community. No one else wanted to bother, especially since I already built enough to stop zombies, so I had no choice but to build walls for my entire turn, every turn, for the entire game, in a futile manner, because I had no hope to get as many walls as were required to win).

If that weren't bad enough, the game has nothing for you to do in between turns, so if other people have more interesting things to do or a lot more survivors to control, it can take FOREVER to get back to your totally boring turn.

Then there's the Crossroads cards, which are a cool gimmicky idea, but I didn't enjoy them much in practice. When it's your turn you basically have to avoid doing any nervous tics or saying anything or scratching yourself or exclaiming out loud or...basically have any fun whatsoever... just so you can avoid triggering the card and having something bad happen to you. I get that some people might get a kick out of trying to get those to trigger, but the game is punishing enough that you don't need anyone blaming you for making it even harder because you had the nerve to cough on your turn. If they were only based on what you do in the game and not outside of it as a player, I would probably enjoy them more.

Basically it seems like the designers looked at Battlestar Galactica, thought the hidden traitor thing was cool and tried to do it with the zombie theme instead, but missed 1) the fact that even though a game of Battlestar Galactica is long, it doesn't feel like it, because you have a decision to make on every single player's turns when the crisis cards come up, so that keeps you engaged the entire time, and 2) Battlestar Galactica offers a myriad of ways that you can sabotage things as a bad guy while pretending it was the best thing you can do, between the jump choices, not helping the crisis cards, not playing the best cards in your hand, not going to the most optimal location, sending people to the brig because you 'suspect them', etc. Dead of Winter does have some of these things, but the hidden goals dictate what you're doing too much and doesn't let you be subtle in how you slowly doom the table to oblivion.

Basically, just skip this game and play the game it was inspired by instead: Battlestar Galactica. It offers a much, much better experience than this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game. I'm impressed that in a tired old genre, DoW focuses on the "survival" aspect of survival horror. Zombies are less of a threat than something to be managed. It's not a perfect ten for a few not-so-important reasons.

Breaking theme: The cards are so immersive that when you roll the event (?) die, the icon on the die roll has a much more abstract feeling than, say, drawing a card from the deck to determine a result. The rules for trading equipment cards allow a survivor in one location to trade with a survivor in a different location. The dog is able to be equipped, and is not immune to negative food effects.

Secret information: Since information is hidden, new players may trip up on various rules they need to know to achieve their objective. The DoW mechanics *can* support full coop, and perhaps rules for a full coop mode would be more helpful for new players.

Strategy: The objective we played was to search through two location decks. We didn't realize how many cards we had to search through each turn, resulting in us setting ourselves to lose the game early. Some strategy tips for the objectives would be useful to keep players from setting themselves up for failure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In love with this game. Will never turn down an opportunity to play it!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It's not exactly "Heavy", but there is a bit of a learning curve, and certain mechanics are easy to overlook (i.e. Drawing/triggering crossroads cards at the appropriate time) or forget (dealing with uncommon events like exiling players, death of all a players characters, etc.). 

That being said, it's an absolute blast and has given me some of the most epic board game experiences EVER (i.e. My heart was actually racing during the last turn as we negotiated for our lives with an exiled betrayer).

Everything this game does, I think Battlestar Galactica does better, I would always play BSG over this.

RATING: 7
Entertaining. For me, the balance of co-op to hidden objectives is about right. Seem to be a lot of flaky cards, which can be forgiven, but might lead to problems depending on how a group play. Some objectives far easier to achieve than others, though that's somewhat of a minor quibble - I like that exact balance wasn't considered necessary in the design, it should be possible to enjoy this without it. 

Overall, play experience can be much greater than the sum of the parts. The atmosphere generated in the game really fits the setting.

RATING: 6

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Ugh. I like this game. But it really does have some serious problems. 

 Roll high. Sure, you can spend food to increase it, but that's not very viable. So it's right back to "You better roll high!"

 Getting the traitor is a cakewalk (at least in my limited experience). The game is already very, very tough. In our first game the traitor didn't have to do anything and we just offed ourselves. In our game last night there was no traitor, but if there were, he wouldn't have had to do anything, either. Even if the good guys are winning, it's so easy to tank things--and holy crap, when you have two turns in a row you can wreck the joint. 

 On a related note, the secret objectives are just insanely unbalanced. Some are tough. Some are easy. Some are almost guaranteed to happen just through normal gameplay. Congrats if you happened to draw that one. You don't have to work as hard as other players. Well done. 

 The gameplay is kind of monotonous. Move-->roll-->hope. Kill-->roll-->hope. If you roll low, get ready to build some barricades and take out the garbage a lot. Adventure!

I still have fun when I play it, and I like the Crossroads cards a lot. It's fun and flawed. 

I'm excited to see the system in space. I hope they fix the problems and don't just do Dead of Space. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
These days, zombies are the it thing for thematic games. It's either zombies or Lovecraft lore. 

This game is different, zombies are there and scary as hell but not the driving factor. The protagonists are the other players at your table. One could be a traitor and want the game to tank. Always look at what everyone is doing closely , that's a pro tip.

Can I even classify this as a game? I think it's a social experiment/experience. It's beautifully crafted with the crossroads cards, every game is a different story. 

Go play it now, before the zombies get you.

RATING: 9
Debo reconocer que no soy fan de los juegos con mecánica de traidor, pero sí me encantan los juegos cooperativos.

Este Dead of Winter me ha encantado, me ha gustado mucho la mecánica de objetivos personales aparte del común, me han gustado los personajes, y sus geniales habilidades, los objetos, la interacción, las cartas de encrucijada. Quizá la duración se excede un punto más de lo que yo esperaba, pero para nada la partida se hace larga. Un gran juego.

RATING: N/A
Amazon 3 for 2 Black Friday 2015 special with TTR Europe and Nations. Arrived 11/27/15
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I've played this game about two times and both times created a sincere sense of dread amongst those who were involved.

Thematically, this game strikes all points true. Crisis cards add flavor to an already tense and harsh environment. Little bits of story-telling that give good or bad outcomes.

Mechanically this game could use some work, but I still love it. I like the action die concept, and rolling for exposure after most combat, however just simply removing a die and a zombie and then just rolling to see if you get hit is a little lackluster, likewise instant death on overrun? Hmm. The game makes up for it with everything else.

Amazing Production, Great Deception based game, solid variants, LOVE IT. Don't listen to the bad reviews, if you're on the fence, watch some gameplay (THERES A LOT) videos to see if it's for you and your gaming group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Admirable developmental work with the cards and theme but not impressed with the design -- like Vega's other games, simply a mash-up of other games (Shadows Over Camelot, Arkham Horror, Mall of Horror) without much of its own soul. So-called mind-blowing Crossroads mechanic is simply another player reading your random encounter card beforehand and watching for the trigger... eh? What am I missing?

Its central idea, making everybody 'Cylon Leaders' with a selfish objective in addition to a secret one, sounds good in theory but is flawed in implementation. If I'm loyal but not achieving my secret objective, what stops me from becoming a kingsmaker? What stops us from Exiling somebody near the end of the game (heck, after he's taken his last action in the game) and giving him no time to complete his new objective?

Exposure die is tedious (and derivative of Shadows Over Camelot: Merlin's Company), and as in City of Remnants and Bioshock, I don't like the same random events determined by a die roll ad nauseum.

For its dedication to theme, I find the instant teleportation of items found and received between members of my group awkwardly dissonant.

2+2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With zombie games getting done left, right, and center, this one takes a lot of the focus away from the zombies and places it on the mechanics.  I like how some, all, or none of the players can win and the crisis cards really make the possibility of a traitor come to life.  The crossroads mechanic is one of my favorite mechanics.  I think that the personal goals can be a bit easy to accomplish and I would really like a higher potential for a traitor.  The traitor mechanic is definitely one that walks a thin line - it either can work splendidly or fail miserably.  Really good stuff and one that I'd be happy to play again any time!

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I really want to like this game, but it total ruined by a few factors. The fact that you can go from several super healthy dudes to none so quickly  a poor design decision in my opinion. It's like the difference between the original zombicide and zombicide black plague. The original zombicide you are too fragile just like in this game. You can go from winning to losing too dramatically without any poor choices being made. You can still make a tough game without the silly dramatic swing that are out of your control. This is a prime example of a game that sacrificed mechanics at certain points for the purpose of theme. I don't appreciate the compromise. The are several things I still really like about the game, so my rating would probably be lower otherwise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ok, so here are my first impression thoughts after 2 initial plays (both 4 players).

Good:
1.  Unique cooperate experience.  Feel a bit like Eldritch Horror, but tighter and not as drawn out.  More interesting that the typical "put out fires" coop game.
2.  Thematic, with a nice dose of role-playing.  I love the characters and all their unique powers.
3.  Lots of variety in scenarios, difficulty, and length of game.
4.  Traitor mechanic does provide a fun layer of constant tension and suspicion.
5.  The exposure die is hilarious.  
6.  This is a fun game.  Period.  People around the table are consistently smiling.

Bad:
1.  I really only see this being excellent with 4 players.  3 wouldn't be enough to provide a real feeling of a "group" (esp. with 1 traitor), and 5 would be too much down-time.
2.  When there's no traitor, the basic scenarios feel pretty easy.  However, if there's a traitor in your game, then a "hardcore" scenario is going to be near impossible.  So, I suspect my favorite way to play will be to"
   - boost the chances of there being a traitor
   - use a "moderate" difficulty level, in between easy and hardcore

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Appearance: 9/10
Mechanics: 7/10
Clarity: 7/10
Pieces: A lot

Dead of Winter is what I like to call a "Nothing Else" game. When that board hits the table, the TV is cut off, cell phones are put on vibrate and all the lights except the one illuminating the table are turned off. In my experience, this is NOT a game you break out during a rowdy party because it takes all your mental capacity just to survive, let alone actually win.

The art and pieces are gorgeous, the only thing i didn't like is the plastic pieces that hold up the standees. If you're too rough combining them, you can damage your standee.

The only thing about the mechanics I don't like is that you'll have a hard time completing the objective with consistently bad dice rolls, but the bright side is that there is no such thing as a completely worthless roll and the slack can be picked up by your fellow survivors

The rulebook is pretty clear, but every now and then some confusion arises about how the order of events should trigger and how some items found work.

I do highly suggest that you buy or make foam board trays to hold and separate you cards and pieces. Using baggies and rubber bands is very time consuming when setting up/breaking down.

Overall, I would call this game a must have.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I held off on this one for a long time. Read every critical review I could and convinced myself several times that, even though I like co-ops and hidden role games and am fine with zombies, this one wasn't going to work. Bought it on a whim and am really glad I did. While I understand some of the naysayer's issues - and I have a couple of my own - no game is perfect. But, for my money, this one is pretty close and it gets the important things right. Strengths and weaknesses have been debated and listed by smarter and more eloquent people than I, but the biggest reason I have this as my highest rated game is this: to date I've played 7 games and I can distinctly, vividly and fondly remember key tense moments or conversations from every game - win or lose. That's what the hobby is all about for me and my friends and family, and I expect that this game will continue to make that kind of indelible impact for a long time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
[i]BSG Killer? Don't Make Me Laugh[/i]

Reduced rating because I'm pretty convinced the game is broken by the traitor mechanic. Basically when the game winds to a close things get tenser, as most games like this do. There are different ways you can lose. So when there is a traitor he can really wreck house with a decisive reveal move at the very end of the game when you are inevitably close to death but don't have enough time to reverse his maneuvers.

So you really NEED to find the traitor and exile him. Games like BSG make this no problemo because if the traitor plays too "sneaky" (pro human) then he will put humans too far ahead and have trouble winning... so signals start getting thrown out and alert humans will finger the traitor.

Problem with Dead of Winter? The traitor doesn't need to do anything fishy at all. He can just play like a human until he sees an opportunity to kill you at the end of the game.

Also near end of game you might have incentive to exile a random player, to hopefully catch traitor and to reduce requirements for Crisis. That player is screwed because he won';t have enough time to complete his objective.

Finally, for all the talk of supposed immersive theme, there sure are a lot of weird things in this game. Why does my character want to have 3 food? Maybe I can justify that with my imagination, but why does he "lose the game" if he doesn't have it when he completes his other objective? How do I teleport items across the map to give them to other players? Why are some humans so willing to sacrifice themselves to stop the spread of the plague? Why do I not care when my less useful characters die, even wanting them to die sometimes? Etc.

To pile on the complaints: Lack of artwork is a shame, this game is a co-op with fairly obvious decisions, none of the mechanics really feel tight or well developed, has some of BSG's problems with secrecy rules but isn't as good to make you want to ignore them, downtime is problematic with higher player counts, and more.

To the game's credit, it does do story-telling fairly well, with the most card-based flavor text I've seen since Android. Design rating would be lower otherwise.

[b]I'd Rather Play:[/b] Battlestar Galactica

(2 Design + 1 Enjoyment)

RATING: 9
Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game, the first game in this series, puts 2-5 players in a small, weakened colony of survivors in a world where most of humanity is either dead or diseased, flesh-craving monsters. Each player leads a faction of survivors with dozens of different characters in the game.

Semi-Coop, with (but not always) a traitor mechanic. Good feedback so far. Out in Sept/Oct in UK
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a game that I fell in love with the minute I heard the premise, but the actual gameplay has left me feeling a little cold (pun intended).

As others have pointed out, there's an optimal strategy to the game, which is to move pretty much everybody out of the colony to reduce food needs (using fuel cards to reduce exposure), keep them in a single location the entire game if possible, put up barricades every turn to prevent zombies from showing up, and don't add extra survivors to the colony.  Prioritize your personal objective over the colony objective and crisis.  When you boil it down to this strategy, your turns basically boil down to "draw a card", maybe two.  Repeat 4-5 times and see if you won or not.

The betrayer aspect is interesting in theory, but the game provides little room for a betrayer to actually do anything.  Betrayers typically will just wait until the very end to actively sabotage the game.  So the game really just boils down to: "Do you have a traitor, and if so, did you play well enough that he wasn't able to drop morale to 0?"

That all said, in reality it's unlikely that is going to play with optimal strategy in mind, so things won't go as planned.  People will act selfishly beyond their own personal goals, which will ultimately further the betrayer's agenda.

It can be a fun game if you have people really into The Walking Dead, zombies, etc, but I think the game itself falls flat theme/story aside.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A good game to play with friends, but I don't think the traitor/secret agenda mechanic is well implemented. I'd personally suggest this game as a pure co-op experience. 

If your survivors are better off in the colony, then your experience of the game is going to be less interesting than those who have to move around and scavenge. There is risk in moving around, yes, but there is fun to be had searching through the various resource piles in an effort to help the colony/yourself. On top of this, recruiting new survivors expands your personal ability to DO more during the game, and thus is usually exclusive to said scavenger players (as they're not prone to share their option of increasing their player agency in the game). 

There is a fun narrative at play here, and it can often feel like a desperate situation when things get worse and worse - but this is often dependent on the current crisis in play. If the same resource is needed after each card, it's possible to be exhausted by the situation. If differing resources come around, it's a lot easier to deal with. 

I have enjoyed my playthroughs of this game, and it is actually very simple to play and teach, but it's not a game I feel the need to own.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
1 play

It's a co-op! I'd thought, after reading the rules, that there was one winner -- the person who achieved their secret objective. Everyone else, though, seemed to view that as some kind of "super" win! Playing that way, we would have won. Playing for the individual win, though, we all lost.

Here's yet another game with too much randomness. The crossroads thing is kind of fun, I suppose, but also kind of annoying! And those damn dice rolls again! We weren't taught an important rule -- the one about spending food to add to action dice -- but even so, I doubt this would ever be my kind of game. I might play it again, though, but NOT as a full coop!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
-General Impressions
Dead of Winter is a co-operative boardgame with secret objectives. It is a zombie-themed game, but it's all about the players; zombies are just one of multiple challenges the players juggle and prioritize. Because of this, it's appealing to a wide variety of my friends--people who typically aren't interested in zombies enjoy the game because 1) they're given a wide variety of choices, 2) their choices matter, and 3) there are a lot of individual and group decisions and choices that happen. The interaction with people is what makes Dead of Winter fun, engaging, and re-playable--and once you throw in the betrayer card, it adds a nice trust dynamic into the game.

-What it does
Dead of Winter gives players a lot of meaningful choices and options. This is especially valuable when there are a lot of problems to solve and goals to prioritize (i.e. main objective, immediate crisis, food supply, zombie presence, and personal objectives).

This is a co-operative game, but there is a possibility of a betrayer. Players may choose whether or not to add a betrayer to the secret objectives, but doing so will add a trust dynamic to the game and can make things more challenging. There is an ability to exile a suspected betrayer, and after exile, they can still participate in the game with a different objective--very good system so all players are still active.

The crossroad cards are extremely fun in that it adds thematically to the game and gives players more unique options--which in-turn can benefit the player/team or add to the challenge. It's not a core mechanic, but is a very excellent addition to the game that makes it stand out and adds to the replayability. It also shows how much time, effort, and care Plaid Hat Games put into the production of Dead of Winter.

-Why I like it
Although it looks like a complex game with a lot of  moving parts, it was easy for me to learn and teach. I was also able to get away to teaching as we played.

I also feel like Dead of Winter takes the best parts of games i like. It's a unique addition to my game collection that I can always bring to the table.

I also like the balance of luck vs. decision making. Being able to roll action dice and plan what you can do is an excellent way to balance this and make players work together optimally as a team (or help people plan how best to take advantage of the situation for personal gain).

For the crossroad cards, my friends and I play a slight variant: We present choices like Tales of Arabian Nights where only the immediate choice is revealed and the effect is revealed subsequently to the decision. This adds an interesting moral dynamic and makes choices harder to measure and make.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played it a couple of times, was fun being able to have a traitor in the game, took longer than it should have to though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like Zombies, I like co-op with traitor, i am a little dissapointed in crossroads right now sadly :(
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a story-driven MOSTLY cooperative game of surviving a zombie apocalypse.  The zombie theme is a little out of control in board games right now.  This is a well-designed and enjoyable game but there are other conflicts to center a survival board game around than zombies and I wish they had.

The game is played by trying to accomplish the goals of a particular scenario.  A story tidbit is read from a book to introduce you to the world and provide a little bit of atmosphere and then players take turns mitigating disasters and all the while trying to accomplish the scenario's goals.  The reason I say MOSTLY cooperative is that each player has their own secret goal as well.  In order to win you have to accomplish the goals of the scenario as well as your own secret goal.  This is a very neat concept because multiple people can win.  I like the idea of working together as a team while also having your own personal agenda that doesn't interfere with that.

There is one secret goal I'm not a fan of and that's the traitor.  Traitors in games like this don't typically work very well, often the game is already very difficult and so winning by losing is a lot easier and it puts a bit of a sour taste in some people's mouths when one person wins while everyone else loses and they're helped along by the game while everyone else is fighting against it.  This is alleviated some by the ability to exile players, like finding the traitor in Castles Over Camelot.  But again, mostly the game is going to push the players towards losing anyway so the traitor doesn't have to really advertise his evil intentions.  This is still a much better option than something like Archipelago.  The first suggestion by anyone who reads that is going to be "just don't play with that card" but I have a well-documented aversion to making house rules or removing content from games to "fix" them for the designer.  The traitor isn't a bad mechanic in theory, it works really well in Battlestar Galactica but it is an integral always-present part of that game's mechanics.  This is a possible, in my opinion tacked on addition to this game but that's enough about that.

Players progress through the game by rolling dice.  The numbers on these dice dictate what actions are possible by the one or more survivors you control.  You move around a board of locations killing zombies, finding items and weapons, and mitigating disaster to accomplish your goals.  One neat mechanic that adds to the story-driven nature of the game is on each player's turn another player draws a card from a deck that lists a trigger and one or more possible outcomes to that trigger.  If the acting player sets off that trigger then there is a story blurb to read and consequences in the game to what happened.  I like this a lot, it makes the game seem alive and really adds to the atmosphere.

I think the one thing that keeps the game from shining too brightly (other than my opinions on the traitor role) is the length.  I don't mind a long game but this definitely seems longer than it needs to be.  The game is reasonably light in terms of mechanics but there is so much to do on a turn.  Aside from the 6 or so options you have to spend your dice on there are also 8 or so things you can do for free on your turn from moving to trading cards to playing them.  Considering all your options and stepping through them each turn causes the game to drag and there is nothing for the other players to do when their turn is over but watch.

It also fills the same space as Eldritch Horror I think and while Eldritch Horror can easily take as long in total, each player takes 5 times as many turns as they do in this game so you're always doing something.  It is also a tighter game so I don't really see a need for this one but I will play it if suggested and mostly enjoy the experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Dead of Winter is a truly great feat of cooperative game design. While I still like Battlestar Galactica, this game distills the essence of BSG while adding in a few elements to better support the theme and removing some of the chaff. The Crossroads deck is an absolutely amazing idea and I am eagerly awaiting the next game in this line. Sure, you might see the same cards every game, but when one of the rare cards triggers it will be a real treat, and it could be dozens of games before you see them all. Every mechanism in the game is well-balanced and the game takes a while before you will get it and start winning. Even then, it always feels like it's due to you learning how to better strategize and not because the game is out to get you. The players are more dangerous to themselves than the game itself at times, and this is perhaps the shining example of why I love this game so much. I thoroughly enjoy my purchase and look forward to expanding it well into the future.

RATING: 5
A little too much chance in this game and not much you can do to hedge your risk. To give you an idea, on my first couple of play throughs, my 2 characters were killed off completely. The game encourages you to LEAVE the safety of your base to gather supplies/weapons. Well... leaving the base requires you to roll for exposure, and I'm great at rolling the tooth apparently (i.e. instant death).

Down time between turns can be excruciatingly long if one or two players begins to horde survivors (i.e. adding actions). Gameplay doesn't give very many options; there's plenty to do, but typically only 1 or 2 good choices (e.g. search/draw a card, kill zombies, build barricades). The traitor mechanic feels a bit forced, sort of like a "meet too!" attempt, but had it been fully cooperative, I would've passed.

RATING: 7

I hate The Resistance, I just HATE it and I'd rather play this instead, even though it is pretty much the exact same game, because Dead of Winter actually tries to envelop you in the world and storyline it creates. RATING: 6

Components are good - nice boards with fair artwork, thick cardboard playing pieces, plastic stands & dice (many!).  No-so durable cards with fair artwork.  Game time is dependent on the mission, ranges from about an hour to 2 hours.  Two hours may be a bit long for this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very well builded semi-cooperative game filled with a zombie thema! But the true enemy is within ;)
The game is more focused on the survival of the colony and personal choices than you would expect from something containing the Z word.

Lots of cards (320+) with beautiful-themed pictures.
Sleeve them at your own risk (so much!)

Be careful, Crossroads cards have tons of text! Buy the game in your native language for best immersion in the story!

A negative point: Zombies standees have the same shape as survivors and it's difficult to distinguish them quickly on the board. I use plastic zombie standees from Zombie 15' instead for best game clarity.

[i]Preordered at Plaidhatgames (Feb. 2014)[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I'm not usually a big fan of zombie-themed games, but this one is really well done. The story element adds some extra tension and excitement to the usual "get buff, kill zombies" routine.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After 1 play with 5 people: 

Really great game. One of the best I've played this year ( the other being Arcadia Quest.) The game is a solid resource gathering adventure game with a few twists.

The first twist is that every player has a secret agenda which impacts your decisions and adds a air of paranoia neccesary in a horror game.

The second twist is the crossroads cards. The cards are narrative choices that pop up only if the active player satisfies the condition. The preceding player draws the card and watches the active player then stops the game when the event occurs. The stories were really well written (thanks to Mr. Bistro!) And the random nature made them more exciting and immersive than a paragraph game (like tales of Arabian nights)

Really well done game. This one is going to  be a smash hit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Fantastic game! My students and I love to play this game. The theme is great and it is largely co-operative, so it is easy to teach. Just a great all around game.

RATING: 8

But then I have a group of guy buddies.  I love lying to my friends! This game is revolutionary.  You sweat the whole game, trying to deduce who the traitor is. Every move your friends make is suspicious, because every turn there is a crisis that you must all work together to solve. It always seems that your friends could do more to help, but you don't really know what they have in their hands.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Underwhelmed. That's the feeling I have about this game. Somehow, the mechanics are all interesting, but the game wasn't really exciting and offered almost nothing new compared to Battlestar Galactica, Panic Station or Defenders of the Realm. OK, the Crossroads events are a smart thing, as it involves an extra player on your turn, but otherwise...

In Panic Station, you feel more anxiety, as every time you move you deal with the traitor mechanic. Here, you simply roll a die and possibly remove a character. What fun.

The way zombies built up was ok, but it is quite predictable. Unless you are going digging for items, something that probably only is done near the end of the game to meet personal conditions and/or by the traitor to get more zombie pressure. Even then, it's always an exact 50% chance so quite predictable. In Defenders of the Realms, you won't know where it is coming. You have to react instead of mathematically predict your best chances to 'be out there'. 

The 'useless' survivor thing in the colony is nice in putting the pressure on, but the first scenario being such a wimpy condition that you cruise to victory certainly doesn't help in feeling any of it.

And finally, the 'hidden traitor' mechanic. I was a traitor, but literally felt nothing of the excitement I feel being a Cylon in BSG. There are only two ways to effectively ruin  the game. One in putting 'wrong' cards in a check (a mechanic copied from BSG), the other being loading yourself up with survivors (putting useless ones in the colony as well) and go attack other characters at the right moment. I did and succesfully brought Morale down from 5 to 0 in one turn. Which left me wondering if a decent Traitor isn't way, way too powerfull in this game.

In BSG you KNOW there is a traitor. That ups the tension from the start, as you know somebody will make things hard for you. Also, the actions you can take are so much more varied as: do I either attack, search or move? 

Yes, in DoW you can 'clean waste' or 'barricade' as well. Big joy. Playing a game to clean out shit or prevent future events. These actions are so lacklustre (and for a traitor completely no option) that there are almost no incentives to take them other than a personal mission. I get that the waste pile shouldn't hit 10, but it just brings back memories of student home quibbles about who didn't clean out the toilet. Fun? No.

Coming to the personal missions, that is a nice touch but also these have been done before.

In the end, I fail to see why this game get so high ratings and so much anticipation. Maybe being a traitor in the first scenario (collect 12 samples) isn't just not a fun thing to be, and I would have to play more to see.
Not having the game myself and hundreds of others screaming for my attention, I doubt I will.

That all being said, it is not a bad game. Copying from great games isn't necessarily a bad thing. Guess my expectations were raised a bit too much by the hype.

Rating is provisional, as I have only played one time. We'll see about next time but I'd rather be playing BSG or Descent.

The theme is great as well, I thought I was burnt out on all the zombie apocalypse stuff nowadays, but this game gives you the feeling of actively working to survive against the horde and other survivors. Also, while there is seemingly a lot that can go on for each individual turn, the rules are very easy to follow and the game becomes very accessible within your first play through.

Overall a good, but not excellent game.

RATING: 5
Online commentary had me thinking I'd dislike this. Ultimately I didn't hate it, but I suspect it's more of a coincidence of the playthrough rather than a change of heart.

If the methodology here is to tell zombie stories, I think there are too many cogs in the machine. I wanted more nuance from the crossroads cards, and less chit-wrangling in the upkeep. Maybe the chit density gives the traitor more things to nudge, mechanically. But really, it seems like a traitor has limited opportunity to obscure his motive anyway: he's either going to blow the airlock, or he's never leaving his bunk.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.3
Dead of Winter's a zombie-themed set collection game with a possible hidden traitor. I think a lot of people look at that description and get hype; I know I did. But after a couple playthroughs my reaction is now "...That's it?". The tension in the game basically comes from randomness sources -- the ordering of the items in each location, rolls of the exposure dice, and the random turn (Crossroads) and round (Crisis) events. Here's how the metagame looks to me:
  *  There's enough information on the labelling of the cards to identify the traitor if he tries to sabotage the Crisis pile with anything other than his starting items. Even if he shares a space with another person, that narrows it down to two people at best, so it becomes obvious to the other person who's lying. The game tries to help by giving everyone an objective that looks kind of strange, so you can normalize out all the collection-specific requirements on the hidden objective cards; the only effective difference is whether the player is trying to tank the group's morale. There's also the behavior of accumulating a large number of outsiders, which flags a person very quickly.
  *  So basically the hidden traitor's job is to set up as best he can for the double-turn he will get by ending a round and starting the next one as first player. He has free reign to do as much damage as possible during this time, since votes to exile will only be triggered on other peoples' turns. (Bonus style points if your first action on during the double-turn is to get someone else exiled.) May the gods help you, though, if this opportunity shows up too early.
  *  Other than hoarding cards, the traitor emits no signals during his setup, excluding the effects of "peek at someone's hand" cards. So you kind of have to ignore the potential for a traitor, except to watch for the red flags above and maybe to add an extra crisis contribution or two preemptively. In particular attacking someone before they're exiled isn't a good idea; if they die, the group still loses morale. So until the traitor reveals himself, everyone's basically just playing a set collection game and hoping not to get killed while collecting a set.

And a game goes for 2 to 3 hours? For this?

It's not a bad game, but it's long for what it is, and if you don't like the theme (admittedly I don't have any strong opinions there, but some people are very sick of zombies), the game will wear out even more quickly. I'd give it a second try before some of my other middling games, but that's as high as I'm willing to rank it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I'm one of those people who used to love zombies, then with all the new zombie movies, The Walking Dead, zombie board games, etc., I zombied myself out. Zombies became annoying to me, until I saw Dead of Winter on Tabletop.

I feel that this game does zombies right. The zombies aren't really a core mechanic, they are a hazard among the many other hazards in the game. The real gameplay is the interaction between the survivors in the colony, aka the PLAYERS. And the fact that you could possibly have a traitor just adds to the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Bought at Boardgame Warehouse

Step One: Destroy all your other zombie games.
Step Two: Double Destroy any game with "Walking Dead" forced into the title.
Step Three: Destroy Pack away all your hidden traitor games.
Step Four: Change the title of Dead of Winter to The True Walking Dead Game. (It already has a sheriff and a character that looks like Carl)

Great Game. I mean a GREAT game. Yes, the Betrayer has a small chance of being used and an even smaller chance of winning. That is the biggest complaint I see. I think that is what drives this game.

Why this game is so good:

#1: The Hidden Agendas that make you look like you are up to something.
#2: The Exposure Die that could ruin all your plans.
#3: 30 Characters with different abilities.
#4: The Crossroad cards!
#5: There is probably not a betrayer, but maybe...

If you have not played this game...well, if you are reading this you probably have. Good luck Betrayers!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The best zombie game I've played.  It really focuses more on the survivors than just killing zombies.  The different survivors and the crossroads cards really make for interesting storytelling.  The traitor mechanism is done really well and adds a lot of tension.  I think I would 100% of the time rather play this than Shadows Over Camelot, BSG, or Zombicide.

RATING: 10
One of my all-time favorite games. It encompasses many aspects of the Zombie Apocalypse that people have come to know and love throughout various forms of media, while adding its own unique twist to many of them. The characters, scenarios, and crossroad cards deserve to be singled out as extraordinary aspects of the game, but honestly I feel as though every part of the game deserves praise (Especially the Betrayal mechanic). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Dead of Winter is yet another RPG clone.  Fight the spawning zombies and make 1-2 mildly interesting decisions; repeat 'til finished.  The Crossroads cards are the only unique element here and, although they inject much-needed flavor text, they are rarely activated.  Dull.

RATING: 8

The artwork is also a bit overhyped, but it also vonveys the theme nicely. Certainly one of the best Zombie games out there.

RATING: 8.5
When done right, I have to admit that this game genre is one of my favorite game types. And Dead of Winter definitely gets it right. It's such an incredibly immersive experience. The artwork, the crossroad cards and the paranoia-driven interaction is drawing the players into a very desperate and desolate place. It's as if you were teleported into an episode of The Walking Dead and played alongside the cast.Better than that: you are the cast! It does not fire BSG for me. They both are great games with such a different setting and very distinct originals they are paying homage or licence fees ;-) to, that I wouldn't want to not have the choice of theme when I get the chance to bring this game type to the table again.

RATING: 6
I actually love this game pretty much every time I play it but for some reason I just don't want to play it when I'm faced with the option of playing so many other games that I just enjoy playing more than it. The gameplay is tense and merciless, which I like in a game. The player interaction/teamwork yet simultaneous freedom to pursue your own private goal is great. The narrative and mechanics are well written and implemented even though zombies are boring to me and highly overrated and oversaturated in our culture. This is overall a great game, which deserves the love it gets, yet simply doesn't appeal to me to want to play it too often.
