=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A nice, intricate game with a lot of depth and replay potential. That said, it has some issues... Actual play tends to be/feel slow, and set up/tear down is brutally time consuming... A single playthrough is likely to take over 3 hours. Even with all the RP elements, play can feel dry and chore like. The biggest issue is difficulty can vary wildly, from so easy rolling it out is formality after awhile, to losing suddenly outside your control... Game ends often felt unsatisfying and anticlimactic. It's hard to explain because it has a lot of virtues, but it just isn't very "fun".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Fascinating concept and execution, and certainly something I'd jump at the chance to play again.  That said, I don't think I'd rate it as highly as the majority of people seem to here.  Especially late in the game when resources get tight, things really start to drag -- people start really min/maxing everything, trying to consider every possibility, and then a bad roll unravels all that careful planning anyway.

I do love the "possible traitor" mechanism, and how well it goes with the individual victory conditions.  I love how the game ensures that even loyal players will have to do things at times that look bafflingly selfish, as it really keeps things lively.  

Edit: the more I'm around this the less into it I am.  Not a big zombie fan and this seems to take twice as long to play as it should.  I still think it's cool but it's not a title I want to own anymore.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
2-5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Overall there's a lot to like here, but the game does have some possible issues. The co-op aspect, but you don't know who to trust, is very well done. The downside is that, as has been discussed on the forums and I've personally seen it at least once, the traitor can easily wreck the game on a single turn, without leaving any clues up to that point. In other hidden traitor games you usually have some information to help try to figure out who the traitor is, but in this game the traitor can just play as a normal colonist up until near the end of the game when he can destroy morale and win on a single turn (or even on a double turn).

It also seems like the game can be too easy if you don't have a traitor in the game, so it's just boring as a pure co-op.

Still, if the traitor doesn't wreck the game it can be a fun experience. The dice mechanic is good because even if you roll poorly you can still usually do quite a bit. The large selection of characters is also nice as each one has different stats and a special ability.

[b]Player Count Verdict: 4-5[/b]
You need at least four players for two reasons. 1. The traitor is more interesting. He can more easily blend in and sabotage the team without being as obvious. 2. You need more players competing to complete their goals.

Update: Found another issue with the game. The player objectives don't seem to be very well-balanced and you can basically lose the game early on if you have a bad objective. I had an objective to have the most characters in my party by the end of the game. Early on one of my characters died through no fault of my own, and I wasn't lucky enough to draw many of the "gain a survivor" cards. Another player had a character (the fireman) who lets him find more survivors, so he used that to gain many more characters so that he could get more dice, even though we suggested that it was bad for the group to take on that many helpless survivors. So I played the whole game knowing it was impossible for me to win. Other objectives can simply be "don't have any wounds by the end of the game" which is much easier to accomplish and is within the control of the player.

A lot to like here, but the bad outweighs the good and I'll probably be getting rid of this one eventually. So why do I give it such a high rating (a 5)? The crossroads cards can make for some memorable experiences. I still remember the time a character got addicted to drugs when they used some medicine to heal, when a maternal survivor turned against the rest of the colony because she wanted to protect the zombie children at the school, or when we found a weakened horse roaming the streets and were able to feed the colony for an extra round.

RATING: 8
Dead Of Winter is a very dark survival game where you're constantly scraping by to fulfill needs without many resources.  I liked that the zombies are more a looming threat than an actual enemy; you never fight zombies. But they build up, and if too many of them fill an area, that area becomes "overrrun", and characters die. I think our only complaint was that player downtime between turns is a bit high.  It just seemed like when it wasn't your turn, it was a long wait. Still, overall an awesome game, and we all really enjoyed it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Rated a 9. Do not roll for exposure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I like the game system. I like the Crossroads cards and the way they implement a story element. I like the art direction. I like the game a lot. I just think it needs some refinement. It took way too long and downtime is a real problem in this game. If the game was more streamlined, and downtime wasn't such an issue, this would be a smash hit.	

[b]LIKES[/b]

:thumbsup: The theme. 
:thumbsup: Zombies [i]aren't[/i] the focus of the game.
:thumbsup: The storytelling element (Crossroads cards).
:thumbsup: The look; i.e. art, boards, components.
:thumbsup: The social-intrigue element.

[b]DISLIKES[/b]

:thumbsdown: Play time is a bit long. Further games will speed up, yes. But I rarely get second chances with my friends and family.
:thumbsdown: Down time is pretty bad. Especially at the end of the game. I think my last turn took us about 20 minutes. And I don't see this being totally abnormal. You wait a very long time between turns. This is where the game needs serious refinement.

Unfortunately, the two thumbs down it gets are two very big thumbs down. The game just slugs along at a pretty painful pace.

RATING: 6
Aug 26 play: 4/6 rounds, all medicine put into the pile for the cure, just have to survive the round and we win.  On the first player's turn, a bite spreads and ultimately leaves 4 dead.  Morale at 1, crisis sure to fail and drop us to zero.  Two player turns later, they have the option to make barricades and prevent the morale drop.  Instead, they dump out half of the camp's food, and as the rest of us are processing this insane action, the player moves to the gas station and pumps 2 rounds into Sparky's head.  Morale at zero.  He was secret betrayer, even added medicine to the goal to make us think he was good.  So many emotions...

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Not quite the BSG killer as I was led to believe, but it doesn't have to be.  It brings a different flavor entirely and I enjoy it.  Some don't like the very semi-coop nature of the game can lead to some tanking the game if they can't get their private win condition.

The game is more enjoyable when you try to 'partially win'.  Ex. If you're not a betrayer, even if you can't get your private victory of say "have 3 gas and 2 food" but your other victory condition is "the colony must survive".  I would try to make sure the colony survives as a #1 priority and private victory would be #2.  The colony might not do well because I'm also going for my private victory condition, but I would never make the entire colony die just because I can't get my private victory condition.
I see it as "we all survived, but we're not all happy."

The game can be a bit long, even BSG long, but it's easier to explain and there's always something to do unlike BSG that sometimes has issues with lack of things to do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
If you look through my collection you'll notice that games with a strong narrative often get good scores from me. Dead of Winter has it in spades, and I've never had a dud game yet.

Personally, this is the ONLY zombie game anyone should ever need. It's the only one that captures the feeling of what it would be like as a survivor of the zombiepocalypse, and has a focus on the human character.

A great game, and one of my favourites.

RATING: 5.5
Based on my only play, I was a bit underwhelmed. It has too much luck for a seemingly strategic game. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What I like: 

-Very unique game. Between crossroad cards, traitor and semi co-op with personal goals, this is unlike anything I have tried before. 
-The theme is amazing. It truly puts you in the shoes of your group. The cards paint a great picture, and the mechanics really create that feeling of struggle both with the group and with yourself. I love it.
-I like the different main objectives and characters. Its easy to imagine having to be that character in that situation and maybe even role-playing abit. The game just puts you in that mood. 

What I dislike
-You gotta play with the right group and the right midset. If all you care about is being strategic and making sure you and only you win, then this won't work. Please don't tank the game just cause you cannot win - sacrifice yourself nobly for the good of the group at least then. If you don't want story bids and role-playing-ish, then it isn't for you. 
-The downtime and playing time is abit much. The wait becomes even longer if people think they have to be extremely efficient with their actions. 
-If English isn't the first language in your country then it can be a bit rough if everyone at the table hasn't mastered that darn language
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Designer: Jonathan Gilmour, Isaac Vega    
Artist: David Richards, Fernanda Suárez, Peter Wocken    
Publisher: Plaid Hat Games

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I don't consider myself a totally boardgamer, but I've played complex games. Well, for me, this is the BEST GAME I've ever played. Didn't play a game with SUCH AMOUNT OF TENSION. 

Rules are very difficult to explain to other people, they are easy to learn and at last, they are very very easy to play. Theres no victory point track, complex score rules, intrincated actions. The system is very simple (number of actions in one turn) but every action has his mechanich, very very very simple mechanich. The win conditions iare so intuitive and easy to understand, the much you are going to calculate is Moral track, that is so intuitive again (someone dies, Moral goes down one, etc) and thats the las thing you are going to calculate about points or something like that. This doesnt mean theres no mathemathical thinking in this game, because you have to have control over everything, the number of survivors, the zombies they are going to reach the School, The meal tokens, etc. But everything is like very intuitive, very themathic, very easy to learn. So themathic and intuitive.

The Traitor is the key of the game. I didnt played a game that is co-op but CAN have a traitor. And I say CAN have a traitor because is not sure there is one. Is not Battlestar Galactica, in wich you know there is surely one, or Archipiélago, in wich theres no traitor, but is not actually a co-op game, theres only some wining conditions.. THIS is a co-op game, everyone is against the game, even the traitor, but the traitor is also Against the other people, and even the normal people have their own secret objective. So you can imagine, is all about TENSION. Even when there is no traitor in the game, you have TENSION because it could be a traitor. Only the possibility of having a traitor despite it is really in game or not gives a lot of TENSION. And of course, apart from the traitor, there are lots of things to be stressed at, like zombies, crisis, hunger...

The other great thing about this game is the Crossroad cards. There are 80, and its not easy to activate them. So prepare to discover a new Crossroad card in the 10th game. This makes the definitive touch of luck, of chaos, and the touch of narrative history. Is not a role game, but with imagination this well-written cards get you inmerse, diving in the game. The decisions to make with this cards are so dificult sometimes...

Its definitivle replayable. Theres 10 differents scenarios with each scenario two levels of difficulty, so 20 base games, BUT every game you'll have different secret objective, that will change everything about your decisions, beaing the traitor a different player (or the same one, or no one), with different survivors each time each player, different crisis along the game, even the crossroad cards that appears different each game, that can even change the main objective for everyone. So prepare for a lot a lot of replayable. Even more: each game I had the sensation of a story. Theres no worker placement, theres no victory points (wich for other games is a good mechanich) but this has caracters, people you began to concern about, the secret objective affects you in a story way, and the interaction with the other players is so memorable, you will remember the games, you will remember because its like a story, but without legacy, role, written campaign or anything like that. Only playin makes this a story.

For that all, I strongly recomend this game and I give it a 10. I recomend it to people that want a not so easy game but at the same time not so super difficult and complex game. For the ones that love Zombie games, or (like me) the ones that doesnt think if the theme will be good or not but if the game is good or not.  I recommend this for the people that are looking for something VERY different. Not the typical co-op. Not the typical two teams game (everyone against one player), not the typical everyone against everyone, not the typical euro game, not the typical narrative game, not the typical action game, even not the typical suspicious game with traitor (cause it could be not traitor!!), for the ones that look a well designed rules, an excellent art and quality of components, an inmersive game, but most importantly: i would recommend this game for the ones that want a strong interaction between players but not being a party game. A strong strong interaction when everything you do affect the colony, but you have your own goals, but the colony goals are necessary , and even though there is a traitor there that you cant trust.... or mabye there isnt, and you have triggered a croosroad and you have to decide the good of your group or the good of the colony and............

Fantastic game. better for 4 people, 3 is great, five is great if the people is not impatient and if you have time. 2 is not so great, without the traitor the game is not the same.

And i finally recomend this game to those who want a lot of TENSION in the game. A lot of TENSION AND TENSION AND SUSPICIOS AND MISTRUST AND CRISIS AND SUDDEN DEATHS AND LUCK AND DECISIONS AND MORE AND MORE TENSION. :-P
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow, what an experience... if you stick to the theme and read the cards out loud, your in for a treat! Don't really like zombies.

Make sure you try the companion app!

RATING: 9
10/10 Waterproof. I spilt half a cup of water onto the game, but the board and non-colony locations did not absorb the water, and the cards were sleeved. We had the tokens on another table, so they were safe. Thank you Plaid Hat. You saved me from my friend's wrath.

Lots of fun. I thought hard about whether Battlestar Galactica or Dead of Winter was a batter game, but I came to the conclusion that they are different enough from each other to be incomparable. BG has more crises and the group is definitely looking for a traitor while DOW is more of a co-op survival game where if someone makes a fishy move, you immediately exile him.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Teresa Gen Con 2016 August 5, 2016
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first impressions review in English is [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1326461/dead-winter-crossroads-game-review-q-and]here[/url].

My first impressions review in Portuguese is [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1326303/dead-winter-crossroads-game-primeiras-impressoes-f]here[/url].

The Q and A:

[b]Q - The game works thematically?[/b]
A - Yes. The crisis follow a logic in what they are, do and require, and the same is true for the things the players do (moving around, searching for resources, trying to avoid zombies, surviving the cold). The Crossroads events, though they happen unannounced, due to the conditions they have, the events will make sense: only a person in the game will do something. You won't be able to have an event in the colony if you don't have someone there, for instance. By the way, the votes, when they happen for the group, can only be given by players that have people in the colony, otherwise the discussion will happen without you (as your group is outside). A player commented that one thing he didn't find thematic was the personal objective, since no matter who you find or die, the objective remains the same. But this is clear to me: isn't really a [i]personal[/i] goal, as much as a group objective, but [i]your[/i] group. Or, if it is indeed personal, is the objective of the leader of the group (you), and you don't die or leave in the game, so the objective remains.

[b]Q - How much luck there is in the game?[/b]
A - A good deal, but is smaller than I expected. [thing=150376][/thing] has less luck built in than its colleagues like [thing=2471][/thing], [thing=113924][/thing] and [thing=29368][/thing]. Sure, you roll dice at the start of your turn and they restrain somewhat your actions, but the use of them is given, there won't be any surprises here. If I rolled a 4 and my character attacks with 3+, I will surely kill a zombie if I want to. The same if I want to search and a character has 4+ to search - I will surely find [i]something[/i]. But there is still plenty of luck - in the search you don't know what you will find, however each outside location has a chart showing which things are more likely to be found there - so, if I sent someone to the School, I know that I have a good chance of finding food and books, but a low chance of finding people. There is also chance in the Crossroads events - the conditions are arbitrary, you can't control them or prepare for them, but, at least, several of them, when they happen, give the player a choice. Also, there is luck in the objectives and crisis: sometimes you will search the whole game and won't find what you need, in others you will start the game with the objective completed (as I did in my second play: my objective required 3 medicine, and I started with three). And in some plays the crisis won't hit as hard in the very thing you want (personal or for the main objective), but others, as I mentioned above, you will want to stock food and three food crisis will turn up. Now, the main point of action of luck is in the exposure die, that you roll when a character moves or attacks a zombie. As any die worth its spurs, it is possible to pass a whole game rolling blanks, and in other (as again happened to me) you start your first turn, move a character and rolls a tooth - character dead. You have to accept this and just have fun. This is a game you must first play for the experience, not the end result.

[b]Q - And how are miniatures?[/b]
A - The game doesn't have any.

[b]Q - But I want miniatures![/b]
A - Cardboard standees will do?

[b]Q - Miniatures!!!!![/b]
A - Well, [thing=150376][/thing] comes with 30 different characters. Thirty! Imagine the cost to make 30 different moulds (even more, because you would have to make at least one more for the zombies) and the size of the box to include everything plus 60 miniatures (30 characters plus 30 zombies). And I can only wonder what the MSRP would be. What I can't even think is the hassle to look for a specific character among 30 equal color miniatures (even if it was 30 different colors). Cardboard standees do the job just fine.

[b]Q - If I don't think I will fulfill my objective, can I sink the whole game?[/b]
A - Hum, yes, yes you can. Now if you should do this is another question.

[b]Q - Should I do this?[/b]
A - Well, ok, this is indeed another question. Anyway, only you can truly judge this. Thematically I can see it going both ways. For one side, if the colony survive, your group survives, which is, I guess, a good thing. And, being loyal, I think is expected of you (and the game) that you will do your part to help. But, on the other hand, people in desperated situations do stupid things, they don't think straight, choose wrong and are paranoid. So it would really go against the theme to not help as much as you can. However, as I said, I think it would go against the spirit of the game, which is that the loyals will be, well, loyal. So, even if you group didn't win, you still survive, you beat the game, the challenge of the colony, and this is worth something right here. After the celebration is that Rick will shake the hand of someone else other than you, saying they did a fine job - maybe next time for you. For the betrayer, is expect that he won't help too much, and even disturb, confuse, when you can. Can the betrayer help the colony in the last turn, when he knows he won't fulfill his objective? I guess so. Live to fight another day and things like this. Even in the game spirit I feel it works. But if the person sees the defeat of the colony, the destruction of its Moral, as a little win, well, go for it also.

[b]Q - Can I play with green?[/b]
A - In spirit, yes, you can. In the game the players don't use color to represent them. They use characters. But some of these can indeed use more green than others. There are definitely some that go heavy on red.

[b]Q - Can I attack the others? Because, you see, I so want to attack others. Is really important to me.[/b]
A - Sure! Is indeed possible. But mind that there is a good chance for your group to be exiled shortly after.

[b]Q - Is language dependent?[/b]
A - Yes. The Crossroads cards have a lot of text; each character have text describing their special skill. Even though the game says is the person to your right that reads the Crossroads, you can have one player to read all of them (except their own, of course). But since there is a betrayer in the game, you can really ask to someone else in the table to help you read or understand something in a card, since no other player can know what cards you have.

[b]Q - Is the game long?[/b]
A - It can be. The scenarios are divided into short, medium and long. I played two medium scenarios, and the first lasted around 90 minutes, and the other around two hours.

[b]Q - Is the set up long?[/b]
A - If you compare it to [thing=31563][/thing] or [thing=15987][/thing], no. If you compare it to [thing=11][/thing] or [thing=18803][/thing], yes. It is a little faster than the one for [thing=113924][/thing], as you don't have to built the scenario.

[b]Q - Is the art cool?[/b]
A - I liked. Isn't super awesome for me, but it do its job fine and, in general, I found it to be well made, and with a good graphic design for the components.

[b]Q - Is the game complex?[/b]
A - Not much. The set of available actions isn't huge, and most of the time you will only use two: search and attack. Controlling several characters isn't too hard, because even with more dice (thus, more actions) you don't have to use everyone - the dice can be use just for one character if you want. Isaround the complexy level of is siblings in theme: [thing=113924][/thing] and [thing=29368][/thing].

[b]Q - What should I take to the zombie apocalypse?[/b]
A - A crowbar.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
***Update 27th August 2015

I've moved this down to a 7 (from an 8) now.  This is because it's basically just an OK game hidden behind a great theme (and I don't like zombies!).  The theme carries this game.

Essentially it's just a game where you collect cards.  That's it.  And the mechanics of the game don't really change that.  No matter what the situation, you'll still stay in the area that offers the best odds at giving you the cards you need, and you'll just lie about why you're there if so.  Or just say it straight.  Then you'll move to the next place that gives you the items you need etc.  

It doesn't really matter what the main mission needs or the turn needs, as almost 100% of the time someone else will already be at the location that gives the best odds for that, and you moving there will just attract more zombies, so you have an excuse not to go.  And the place you're at will already offer reasonable odds as well on top of that.

Triggered Event "Crossroads" cards are meant to mix thins up, but they don't really, as they don't often fire, or do much to affect anything.  Also, the fact that you know the outcomes of any choices these cards give you before you make your choice is pretty poor.  

I don't think this game has a lifespan of much more than 5 plays (after which point, you'll be happy to play other games instead), regardless of the mission you're doing - the missions are all the same, just collecting cards...but you may have a harder time depending on which one you do.  But that's not variety.

I don't mind the traitor mechanic in this, and don't think it's a sleeper agent type affair as people say.  You can act right from the go.

I can see myself reducing this game to a 5 "average" before long, and won't be surprised to see others do the same.

***original comments:

Great semi-coop, which gets around the alpha gamer problem because you're all working for your own hidden objective as well as the groups' one.

You can also be a hidden betrayer in the group, where you want the group to fail.

Many great game mechanics, but the main issue for me is that you're basically just looking for items from several decks of cards.  There are some other objectives you can have, but quantities of items is the main gist.  

More variety would be welcome, then it'd be a 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not a game for everyone. But if you like zombies, love hidden agendas, and can tolerate a bit of randomness this game is a must play for the experiences it offers.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I'm not a fan of cooperative games in general, but I decided to take a chance on this one based on the acclaim it gets.  I was also intrigued by the crossroads cards, and although it's a great idea, the implementation of it here is underwhelming in my opinion.  There are a lot of cards that are extremely unlikely to happen and others that almost always happen.  The cards are supposed to create a sense of story and adventure, but all it felt like to me was randomly adding extra rules.  Gameplay is typical action selection but even that felt fiddly and overly complicated.  Although the character artwork and stands are fantastic, the rest of the presentation is meh.  I played three games with three different groups and we never even came close to completing the main objective before morale hit zero; I can't imagine what the hard objectives would be like.  I really wanted to like this game, but it just isn't for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
DoW's engaging structure, artistic design, and game flow sit on the top tier. With the apex in mind, the following comments are about the elements that drag it down from euphoric to earthly.

DoW hit all the marks for a zombie survival game but may be too easy on it's victims to be truly great.  The random events: "Crossroads* cards" do not do enough to make the lives of the living miserable.  

Let me put this into context: Zombie themed games should have less than a 50% win ratio to really be in line with the overarching theme of the genre.  But since that sells less units than a 60% win ratio then Plaid Hat decided to take the path of least resistance.

I wish the game was harder on a corrosive level, that it destroyed hope and killed favorite characters. I do not feel the urgency and dread that I do playing Dawn of the Zeds.  Never once while playing DoW did I think that the end of the world was here and I was a hopeless piece of shite floating in the mire.

I enjoyed the experience for the role playing, relaxed, coop atmosphere among typically competitive gamers.  This is a game I would play again but would not pick out of a crowd... even a crowd of zombies...


*Victory Point Games: Dawn of the Zeds, uses Fate cards far more effectively as additional random hindrances to the progress of the survivors.

cons: even cards can be a bit tedious and difficult to understand. text on card is a bit too close together and makes it difficult to read. If a player has a bad poker face or can't hide his actions well, betrayer can be easily spotted.

RATING: 6

But overall it is a fun game. My biggest problem with it is I felt the creators tried to do too much. It gets annoying reading encounter cards every turn and slows down the gameplay. You need an interactive group willing to banter and take risks...but it can be fun.

RATING: 8

RATING: 8

The zombies? That's just the visuals - this game transcends the zombie theme.

RATING: 8.5

RATING: 2
Man, I couldn't stand this one. I'm sure it didn't help that I generally dislike Ameritrash and cooperative games, but even though I didn't have high expectations at all I still thought this was a huge disappointment. The fact that you only win if you meet your objective is problematic as sometimes the circumstances prevent you from meeting your objective so you have no incentive to help the other players win. My goal was have the most survivors and I never drew another survivor the entire time. This seems like playing Shadows over Camelot but saying that the knights only win if they also meet a specific condition, like playing the most grails or something. I honestly didn't like anything about this game. Although this sort of game play would be suitable for an RPG, this is listed as a board game so is rated as a strategy game.

RATING: 1.5
I don't like cooperative games at all and this one neither. Basically in your turn you just roll dice. If they are high enough you will search for items or kill a zombie and if they are too low, you check if you can modify the result with food, if not you just empty the trash. And at the end you discard a card in order to avoid any bad scenarios for the group.
To me it was horrible to play this one especially since you have HUGE downtimes. And it is not interesting to watch the other ones play cause it does not effect your turn at all. 
I can't understand the hype for this game and I hope next time I play it I can modify my rating in the other direction

RATING: 4.5
Still have yet to see competitive + co-op ever work out to be a good thing, though it at least *sort of* works here.  Traitors can hide a little bit because everyone always has the excuse 'I have to do this for my personal goal', but good players will out them easily enough or they will just lose because their goals are so difficult.

Several counter-intuitive, non-thematic plays end up being strong strategies.  Game also has the potential to proceed at a glacial pace.

RATING: 7
Having trouble settling on a rating.  So far every game I've played has had to be a teaching game, so it's hard to really explore the game and kick back.  It really can be something special though.  Just the idea of hidden agenda's in a co-op I absolutely love.  It breeds contempt and paranoia and it's beautiful.

The gameplay can be a bit fiddly and sometimes drawn out when one person gets a ton of Survivors, especially if you are down to one survivor and can hardly do anything on your turn.  This is one of the flaws with the game I think, experiences can be very inconsistent from one game to the next depending on how the cards come out.

RATING: N/A
Players are working together toward one common victory condition — but for each individual player to achieve victory, he must also complete his personal secret objective. Each player leads a faction of survivors, and must find a way to work together to fight off outside threats, resolve crises, find food and supplies, and keep the colony's morale up.

3-5 (best 4)

Cooperative, horror, dice rolling, hand management

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The most fun I've ever had in a nights gaming playing Dead of Winter...
Colony morale was low, time was short, food was low. And one of my friends was a filthy lying traitor. And a good one at that. All game long he'd been laughing in our faces. Finally, a mistake was made. He slipped up and played a card that was traceable. And trace it we did right to the Police Station, which he was the only one searching at. We all shouted at the startling revelation, and then we all lost because it was too late and the damage was done.
I've never seen the traitor mechanic done so well in a game. At one point I'd have given this game a 10, but it seems replay-ability does suffer a bit over time and it is a bit of a numbers game since you need to be aware of EXACTLY how many foods will be eaten and zombies added so you can play to those numbers specifically.
Also this is a heavy game so it's a game your group may only feel like occasionally playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The 2 things that really make this game great is the ever present theme and the innovative system of crossroad cards; the game system itself (as a coop with card management) is not super great but all the thematic tidings really make the game shine (secret objectives, characters personality, possibility of a traitor, etc.); 

[+] the Crossroad system! lots of characters with personality, scenario & story telling elements = very very thematic, very involving & tense game, pranoia induced by traitor mechanic; exile does not meen losing the game, sometimes it is really helpful.
[-] with 4/5p it becomes a long game; difficulty can be swingy (pure coop in normal is way too easy; a traitor in hard is way too hard for the good guys); the traitor mechanic does not work so well: the traitor just needs to wait and strike hard to tank the morale in 1 turn and there's not much you can do to prevent it... passing first player in reverse turn order is very weird (double turns)

gone in MathTrade Dec14

RATING: 8
Lots of fun and balanced well -- not too easy, not too hard. The not-quite a traitor, but not quite altruistic, mechanic is really good.

The wrapper works really well -- I always feel cold and slightly desperate when playing this game, and it is one of the few board games in which I use a sonic background during play.  Wind sounds and zombie moans, with a backdrop of ominous music, help round out this experience.

RATING: 6
Initial Rating: 6

The game seemed fine, but I was not really engrossed in it. Probably didn't help that I'm not interested in Zombies. It may have just been our scenario being too easy. Everybody won, no traitor and there was no tension. Decisions were obvious.

The crossroads cards is a neat idea. For us, most of the conditions were either immediately triggered or had no chance at all of being met, so it felt not as well utilized as it could have been.

IMO, The exposure die is a lame mechanism.

RATING: 5
Didn't work with our group at all (four player and two player) with the Need more Samples scenario. There was significant downtime with multiple survivors, we couldn't discuss much to avoid giving away personal objectives, and it was too fiddly/complex for a fun traitor game.

The moral decisions/crossroad cards didn't really work for us. It seemed far too easy to make a vindictive choice - leaving children to die, etc. There didn't seem to be a real moral choice. We tried livening it up by not reading the full options - like Choose your own Adventure - but that often felt incoherent or confusing, not tense.

RATING: 6
So far not so good; I think we need to play more (currently 3 plays). Have had to refer to the rule book several times during play. Some things don't seem to make sense - eg a "2 food" card is worth 2 food to the colony needs but only 1  food to the crisis contribution. First 2 plays we got rules wrong which undoubtedly made game worse (eg we thought crisis contributions had to be one per character in play instead of per player). Also not sold on the crossroads cards - reading the story and offering the choice is great, but it feels like you should have to make the decision without having full knowledge of both outcomes; but if you played like that then the game would be even harder.
Also it plays long and we don't think we can ever play it at home on an evening again because of the playtime, which further limits it's likelihood of coming of the shelf.
We'll give it a chance...but...not sure it's for us...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a nifty entry into the "semi-cooperative but there might be a traitor" genre. It does a nice job of forcing everyone to do things that seem a tad bit destructive, to achieve their personal win conditions. This sort of game has been explored quite a bit of late, but what makes this one special are the crossroads cards. They interject a ton of story into the game, as well as some gut wrenching decisions...especially if everyone is buying into the theme, which they should, to get the most out of it.

Like the best of zombie apocalypse fiction, the point this game tries to make is that the other people, the survivors...They are often the most dangerous monsters, not the mindless zombies. Focusing on those survivors, not the monsters, is this game's biggest strength.
 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good game, unless you get bad turns then your screwed.

RATING: 7.5
I really really hate zombies. I highly recommend the iOS app that has voice recordings of all the crossroads cards!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A co-op game of survival in a zombie apocalypse.  Players control human characters that fight off zombies while gathering medicine, food, and tools.  The collective need is everyone's primary concern, but individual victory conditions and "crossroad" events provide more selfish opportunities.  A traitor player may randomly be included at the start of the game.  That combined with the random starting objectives, large number of available characters, random events, and die rolls makes for a very variable game where a fun narrative is spun.  But the choices in the game feel narrower than the menu of choices would suggest and there is a sameness after a while.  Be prepared for a longer game if playing with those who want to collectively discuss their moves.  An enjoyable social game even though I'm not much interested in co-op or zombies.

RATING: 8.9
You lead a faction of survivors in a small, weakened colony of survivors in a world where most of humanity is either dead or diseased. A semi co-op psychological survival game. You work together toward one common victory condition, but must also each complete your own personal secret objective. One of you could be a betrayer, that works against the group. You make frequent difficult decisions that often have you deciding between what is best for the colony and what is best for you.

RATING: 7
The game CAN offer a very fun experience; I certainly had a blast, but mostly because I did a lot of research before bringing it to a table; I took very short turns, did not bother to optimize my moves, and made sure there was a betrayer (via false shuffling).

Overall, BSG is in almost every way a much better semi-coop game than DoW, except that DoW is simpler and friendlier for light gamers to enjoy.

The game feels somewhat incomplete in many ways, but the worst part is the balance. The secret mission cards aren't diverse enough, and don't scale well across different player counts or missions. It feels like the rules should include that you can win only if the rest of the players fail to guess your secret mission. It's unclear how to get around the issue of people blatantly pursuing their secret objective.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
thematic and story driven greatness. an experience as much as a game. anything holding it back is a bit of luck. searching areas for cards you need, and action dice flirt with disaster, but are done very well. They feel more like a challenge than a crippling force of chaos. Many actions don't care what numbers you rolled and the ones that do require a certain number you can still usually do once or twice. The location decks are balanced appropriately to theme and have their balance of items printed right on the board. If there's anything I hate it's that **** exposure die.

RATING: 6
Since this has been all the rage since summer (currently rankes #17 overall) I naturally had to check it out. I think it's a fine game, though it is dependent on luck wheather it's rather easy, or wheather people die away because of the exposure-die. I found the story element to be nice, but not as overwhelming as everyone made it out to be. The crossroads cards are a neat thing, but: when having I choice we always picked what helped us survive, not what was moraly right. Even if I rollplayed this my characters, hardend by the apocalypse and intent on survival, would not have picked the moral thing to do. So really, in almost all of the crossroads cards you choose survival and everything else is not your concern. I personally didn't care as much for the semi-coop nature. I did not mind the traitor element. We had a traiter who was banned because he gave himself away. We won. Well, two of the three non-traitors did, because the third one was unable to fulfill his hidden objective. I told him, that I counted it as a win for him, because he did work towards the group objective with effort and even stopped crises, so why should he not win? Also, the hidden objectives are very different in difficulty. Anyways, nice game, but surely not deserving of a Top 100 spot.

RATING: 6

I've only played once, but there's definitely a lot of fun in this game, not necessarily knowing who's on your side and who's not. March 5, 2015: The more I think about this game, the less I want to play it. It has a lot of interesting ideas, but the balance just isn't there and I'm not so staunch about balance (I love Cosmic Encounter for goodness sake). I think the worst part is that the people who have the most survivors get more survivors and the people that lose survivors get fewer survivors because they have fewer actions to search with.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Semi co-op zombie hunt. For good or for bad my group are suckers for anything zombie (Sigh). Despite all the zombie games in my closet, this is a must add.  Dead of winter does all the basic zombie stuff; complete the scenarios by going to locations, searching for items, and destroying zombies. BUT it adds another layer of depth which I love; individual player sub goals which cause a juicy conflict of interest within the main objective,  a crossroad deck that adds events in a very entertaining and exciting way through storytelling, a betrayer element which creates an immediate off balancing distrust, and a clever exile system for dealing with suspected betrayers that allows them to stay involved in the game. I also dig the noise mechanic, and the crisis resource mechanic for collecting the scenario resource which adds an unknown factor and a deduction element to ferreting out the betrayer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I'm not a fan of Arkham, Eldrich or any of the Flying Frog games. When I saw this I was certain I'd dislike it as the style just isn't entertaining. However, I was pleasantly surprised at how streamlined and enjoyable this was and would consider picking it up.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6
Even if you don't like zombie themes you may end up loving this game anyway, as I do. Zombies are a prominent feature but the game is really about surviving a post-apocalyptic winter with other clans of humans that you may not be able to trust, at least not entirely. And the cartoonish art and humorous elements make "Dead of Winter" more fun than scary.

There are some unique mechanics that are fun and fluid. The Crossroads cards in particular are a nice way to keep everyone involved. If your group doesn't mind a little card text reading to get into the flavor of a game, you're probably going to like this one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I can not in good conscience recommend this game for 2 players.

I found the game simply an exercise in 'lasting it out'... not building any strength, nor gaining any ground, but just doing the same things every turn...either searching a deck, or moving a character to another spot, ect.

The crossroad cards were not effective through much of the game, and in fact felt disjointed from the game. Decisions on the crossroad cards were somewhat obvious for us both. No real drama at all.

There was little tension from the 'zombie' side of things since they were fairly easy to handle.

We had no reason to excuse the fate die. It was atrocious. Simply, "you might die, you might not" just because. 

I have not played this with more than 2 players, but my real qualm with this game is that it specifies '2-4' players right on the box, and this is really not a 2 player game in my opinion, especially sans the traitor mechanism.

While I adore the game, I would recommend just getting the Longest Night.

RATING: 9
Review Date: May 2017

Positives: The production is beautiful, such an immersive game that captures the pressure every turn of the challenges facing the group. The crossroad cards add lovely flavour to an already good game and diversity for pleasing replay-ability. The traitor or not mechanic, whilst not unique is realised perfectly here. Co-op but with solo objectives, deliver team work and selfish goals setting all at the same time. 

Negatives: Some don''t like being a traitor and find it to hostile. Some are over the zombie end of the world theme. Some of the depth in the add on is needed for longer replay ability

Conclusion: Excellent game with a real deep immersive game style that you will remember long after the game ends. 

Score 9 if you can overcome the repeated zombie theme!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Zombies are no longer as entertaining as they used to be, and as such this may be the last zombie-themed game that I ever play.  I'm just plain burnt out.  Though if this one is really good, it will be the last one that I need anyway.  Right?

With its Crisis cards and traitor mechanic, the game is a clear offshoot of Battlestar Galactica, but I imagine that's common knowledge by now.  Thankfully, I think it's a bit shorter than BSG, depending on the scenario.

Criticisms and comments:

Having all players pre-roll their dice speeds up the game and allows for careful planning, but it also drains some of the tension from the game.

My biggest complaint, strangely, is that the flavor text doesn't appear frequently enough, but when it does it tends to be a bit too long. I also wish that players weren't aware of the possible outcomes of their Crossroads decisions, since it's more fun (Arkham Horror style) when decisions lead to unexpected and/or funny results.  That would make Dead of Winter less of a game and more of a story, however.

[i]Update:[/i]

I need to spend more time thinking about DoW, but I'm leaning towards the idea that the system is deeply screwed up. The semi-coop nature of the game, where every player - even the "good guys" - has his or her own secret agenda leads to seriously wonky behavior.

I usually find semi-coop games extremely amusing (e.g., Terra, LOTR dice-building game, Gloria Mundi) because truthfully they're social experiments that barely even count as games. The difference between Terra and DoW, though, is that DoW is a lot longer. Watching a game crash and burn after 30 minutes, to me, is pretty darn funny, but I've learned that watching the same thing happen after 2-3 hours is not much fun. Even if I'm the one causing the game to crash.

An interesting point, which has now been debated on BGG at length, is that a "good" player who can't win (i.e., their secret goal is essentially beyond reach) can tank the game in such a way that no one wins. Though this only makes sense if that player is convinced that there is no betrayer, since tanking the game otherwise could lead to "betrayer" kingmaking.

A valid justification for imploding the game in the face of certain defeat - in my opinion - is that it causes the game to end much more quickly, which in turn allows me play something else with my crazy friends.

I would probably like DoW more (as a game, not experiment) if it were genuinely an "us vs. betrayer" coop where, to win as a group, the good guys had to beat the main objective AND all good players had to achieve their secret goals. Though this would lead to all sorts of "secret information" problems, since players would simply tell each other what they needed to fulfill their secret (well, not anymore) objectives. Also, for this to work, the game would need to be fine-tuned so that the main objectives were easier to accomplish in the first place.

Anyway, I think there are numerous things that are wrong with DoW (balance, gamey play, general design), but it'll take time for me to sort them out in such a way that I can communicate them clearly. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Theme/Art:
I love both. The art is really good and the theme very immersive. It surprised me how dark the game is, some crossroads cards are really intense with cruel decisions to make.

Production quality:
No miniatures (but none needed), all standees and lots of token. The location cards could be thicker, but aside from the it's very good.

Replayability:
There are many crossroads cards, different personal goals, different team goals, different crises, etc. so replayablity should be no problem.

Depth/Difficulty:
It takes a bit to explain and to get all of it, but it's not the heaviest game I own. I weight it a 3/5.

Strategy:
Depending on you being the traitor or now you have to plan your steps. You have to avert crises, achieve your personal goal, and also achieving the team goal. And you have to kill zombies. A lot.

Luck:
There are dice involved and the crossroads cards are random and you don't know the trigger, but it's not too much dependent on luck for my taste.

Dead of Winter is a great game and depending on the mission takes between 30 and 180 minutes to play.

I really like the crossroads mechanism and the dark theme and if you like zombies, I recommend getting the game.

The only complaint I have is that during short missions one player can be lucky and do all the work while the others can't do much. But that only happened once.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I love the atmosphere that this game can bring to the table. We've had some standup moments due to the exposure die, deciding the fate of characters and at one time a game even (woman needed to return to the colony for the win, but she turns zombie on us and kills another in the process dropping morale to 0).

The game requires some time dedication but I've always found that worth it. However, that does make it harder to get the game to the table in some cases.

One definite mark I have against the game is that it can sour people in tanking the game when they are unable to win themselves as a loyalist. Given that the rules say that you lose the game if you cannot meet your personal goal, people who are too focused on winning themselves sometimes justify ensuring everybody else loses as well by rationalizing it in some way ("that is what my character would do!"). It's more of a player mentality problem than really the game's fault, but as the game seems to facilitate this behavior it sours my view of the game itself a bit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

65 x 90 : 353

RATING: 8
Love the theme!  Takes a little bit to teach all the players all the different rules but it's worth it!

RATING: 6
Looks more intimidating on the table than it actually is. There's some goofy rules in parts, but each player's turn is actually pretty straightforward. As it turns out, the hard missions are actually hard, we lost before round 2 was done even with some experienced players in the group. With the right group and setting, could be a fun experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This is not really so much as game as a social activity.  As a game, I would rate this much lower.  Even as a social activity, it has a few problems.  It drags and takes much too long for what it is.  If it played faster, then it would be a lot more fun, but there is a lot of fiddling around with bits and a LOT of waiting between turns.  This is made worse by the fact that players take all of their actions at once.  Also, you kind of need to pay attention to what people are doing, to glean their real intentions.  That's tough, because it is so incredibly repetitive.  I expected a lot more space to explore, and to be surprised from time to time.  That never happens.

On the plus side, it does have a few novel mechanisms.  The traitor thing is kind of cool.  With the right group, this game could be really good.  But that is the thing with DoW which for me is at an odds with its popularity.  It just doesn't seem like it should work for every group.

Theme: I really, really expected this to evoke a feel like the "Walking Dead" show.  That never happened, not in the least.

As a game, it suffers from all of the usual problems of semi-coops, and coops in general.  If that is not your thing, DoW is not going to be that exception to the rule.  If you like social games like Werewolf or BSG, then this will likely work well for you.  So as a social activity, it's not bad.  As a game, lower my score by 1 to 2 points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Engrossing cooperative game with potential traitor. I wouldn't recommend a traitor unless you're playing with 4-5. My only real grips is that after several plays, it begins to feel like the game of "go to location, mill its' deck". Still a solid game that I enjoy playing occasionally.

RATING: 8
A 2-5 player semi-coop survival game. Players are the last survivors of a zombie apocalypse, trying to survive the winter. All players share a main objective, but must also complete side objectives. There's also a chance one player is a betrayer, trying to doom you all.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
GAME
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
Very tense cooperative game set in a zombie apocalypse. Players have to survive and complete variable common goals while each player is at the same time trying to complete his secret objective, which might be betraying the rest of the group. This game is very suspenseful und the possibility of having a traitor among the players makes the communication around the table very interesting and the game a lot of fun to play.
Another thing that adds to the atmosphere of the game are the crossroads cards. The player does not know if he might be triggering the card by certain actions and therefore make certain events happen that might change the game completely.
Would definitely recommend.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I had the pleasure to play Dead of Winter at a small gaming retreat together with one of my best friends, who now owns the game. Its looks finally won me over, as the main boards, locations, and standees all look better on the table than pictures and videos do them justice.

The semi coop element breaks it for me. If I cannot win, I will certainly not help another player to get the win. In this sense you can end up with a whole bunch of people working against you completing the game's main objective. I prefer the game in full cooperative play, with the advanced side of the missions. I wish the rules told you to play this way until you master the gameplay.

A cooperative game must be difficult to win in my opinion, and Dead of Winter does a great job in this respect. This game is very difficult.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.825
I love Dead of Winter. I love the huge amount of storytelling the game offers and the artwork is simply gorgeous. The crossroad cards are great, the atmosphere and the story just sucks you in. The possibility of a traitor adds to the tension and paranoia. You start to ask yourself why people had to make noise or why they're not cleaning up. There's small ways to sabotage the others during the game, you don't have to show them outright that there's a traitor. I actually think it's nice to have personal objectives, sometimes I think they could be a little bit more thematic, but it just shows, that everyone or every group has their own agenda, even if working together. There's not only the zombies to worry about. This game is my favourite of 2014. 


If you're into story-telling (and zombie) board games this game is a must-have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My friends who know my zombie aversion will probably be surprised at this high rating (the folks I gamed with were certainly surprised I was game to join in) but this is simply a really good co-op game which happens to use zombies as a threat.  I think having a general goal and personal goals is genius as it makes the game more tense whether the potential traitor shows up or not as everyone has at least one moment where they have to decide between losing ground on their personal goal and screwing over the colony.  The crossroads cards are pretty wordy, but I really liked the added story elements they added to the game... though I wish the results weren't read until after someone chose what they were going to do.  I know that sort of thing is there so people that have memorized the cards can't unfairly benefit... but it would be more fun not to simply be able to chose the better option for your situation.

So... its long and fiddly and gives you significant downtime... but I found the story and what other people were doing engaging enough that I didn't notice any of that.  All in all if you like co-ops... particularly find the traitor co-ops... and especially if you like post-apocalyptic survival themes... you will certainly enjoy Dead of Winter.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is by far my favorite co-operative game out there! Don't shy away from this game because it's a co-op. Think playing The Walking Dead on a board game. Each player starts off with two characters and other characters can be added during game play. Collect resources such as food, weapons, gadgets, and fuel to help the group and also to meet your own personal objectives. There's lots of twists and turns. There might even be a betrayer amongst the group! If you get exiled your objective changes too. Plays really great with 3-5 players. Can take anywhere from 2-3 hours to 4-5 hours if there are complications in the plot. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game of Horror Co-op RPG is rather simple to follow but people do tend to forget the crossroad cards, missions and their own secret missions during the heat of battle. The game is designed to fail the group specially with the Betrayal secret mission card on top of the already nearly unmanageable crisis every round. [I don't recommend to unbox and play right away with friends. The setup took the four of us over 15 minutes. By the time we are done, some of us already grew tired. And after the setup, It's very difficult to close the box flush with everything inside because the plastic stands are hard to put it on and off without bending the figurines and therefore took much space. This is the faulty design of the game itself.]

RATING: 7.5
pretty cool game.  reminded me a little of last night on earth, only with more story elements.  I really liked the crossroads deck.  There's a lot to like here, and lots of replayability.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
DoW manages to paint a wonderfully believable and mature apocalypse, it's just too bad you don't get to experience it all that much. The main objective often dictates the game's direction too much IMO, while leaving little in the way of exploring the wonderful encounters and other scenarios that can happen. The main objectives can also be very unintuitive, such as sitting on the same two locations and depleting their item decks? That's not exactly what I would call "fun." Many of the main objectives can be achieved by moving all characters to where they need to be in the first round of play, then simply completing the necessary actions to win, with minor movements here and there. Many of the characters are relegated to the exact same set of tasks every round, such as the cook who can make food (and is an excellent defender of the colony as well). But this means that the player who has the cook must use 2 of their die every round just doing "upkeep," and they don't get to explore the game. At a certain point you have to wonder why that person even needs to "play" when you could have their character do what they're doing without anyone playing them at all. Without going overboard, I'll just say that DoW could do a lot more to give individual players options and make them feel like they are a part of the game, rather than making them feel like an action die drone, relegated to the same actions every round.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
2 session with 2 players, and 5 session with 4 players.

Not recommended to play with 2 players, only if you want to learn the flow of the game. The 2 player mode is a coop game, but without a traitor it's not really exciting.

I had 1 session with 4 players, and it was really intens. We exiled the traitor on the last round, but couldn't save the colony. The traitor also didn't get his personal objective. So... We all lost :-)

I really like the suspense, nobody is to be fully trusted in the beginning. Expect alot of fingerpointing.
The "exposure" die is great, and forces you sometimes to take hard decisions: "I got bitten: Should I kill myself isntantly and be sure not to infect my fellow survivors, or should I roll again and risk to infect my fellow mates".

There's some storytelling involved, and gives extra flair to the game, but it's not the core of the game.
The Crossroadcards are part of the story telling aspect, and are easy to forget (it needs to be read before a player starts his turn).

In short: I like the game alot for 4 players, and will play it again!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I really like this game.  Playing the full version, there are so many ways to lose and win its a challenge for sure.  The individual missions (or betrayal card) has your every move scrutinized by your fellow players, and you really have to decide between your own goals and the needs of the group.  Even if you are the betrayer, your mission insures that you will need to play along most of the time to win, and sometimes force you to do things that appear counter productive to your fellow players when you are not.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Some of my thoughts on this game are in the BSG review. I love the crossroads cards, I love a lot of the theme. I love how HARD this game is. Having to complete a side objective while also working towards the main objective while ALSO working to not look like a betrayer is difficult to balance, and makes the decisions another layer of difficult. It's brutal, with a 1/12 chance one of your characters will die from doing much of anything of value. If anything, it's so difficult being the betrayer is almost too easy. I really like this game though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

RATING: 7.5
The traitor mechanic is always a hit or miss in my group, but with this one it doesn't matter: my group loves the standard co-op rules. Whether we're in the mood for betrayal or co-op survival, this baby fills the need.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Take some Battlestar Galactica and some Robinson Crusoe, then throw it into a post apocalyptic, frozen landscape filled with zombies and challenge the players to survive.
Numerous plots to play through making each game different, tons of characters, crossroad cards that keep the story alive - seriously, what's not to like!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A really good thematic and story-bringer game (if that is even a word). The exposure die is the meanest, baddest zombie out there..
